title: Mining the Long Tail: A Comparative Study of Data-Centric Criticality Metrics for Robust Offline Reinforcement Learning in Autonomous Motion Planning
summary:
Offline Reinforcement Learning (RL) presents a promising paradigm for
training autonomous vehicle (AV) planning policies from large-scale, real-world
driving logs. However, the extreme data imbalance in these logs, where mundane
scenarios vastly outnumber rare "long-tail" events, leads to brittle and unsafe
policies when using standard uniform data sampling. In this work, we address
this challenge through a systematic, large-scale comparative study of data
curation strategies designed to focus the learning process on information-rich
samples. We investigate six distinct criticality weighting schemes which are
categorized into three families: heuristic-based, uncertainty-based, and
behavior-based. These are evaluated at two temporal scales, the individual
timestep and the complete scenario. We train seven goal-conditioned
Conservative Q-Learning (CQL) agents with a state-of-the-art, attention-based
architecture and evaluate them in the high-fidelity Waymax simulator. Our
results demonstrate that all data curation methods significantly outperform the
baseline. Notably, data-driven curation using model uncertainty as a signal
achieves the most significant safety improvements, reducing the collision rate
by nearly three-fold (from 16.0% to 5.5%). Furthermore, we identify a clear
trade-off where timestep-level weighting excels at reactive safety while
scenario-level weighting improves long-horizon planning. Our work provides a
comprehensive framework for data curation in Offline RL and underscores that
intelligent, non-uniform sampling is a critical component for building safe and
reliable autonomous agents.

AI.tldr: Offline RL for AV planning using data curation to address long-tail events; uncertainty-driven sampling provides the strongest safety gains.
AI.motivation: Real-world driving logs are highly imbalanced, with mundane scenarios dominating and rare critical events being underrepresented; non-uniform, information-rich sampling is needed to learn safer policies.
AI.method: A systematic study of six criticality weighting schemes (three families: heuristic-based, uncertainty-based, behavior-based), evaluated at timestep and complete-scenario levels. Seven goal-conditioned CQL agents with an attention-based architecture are trained and evaluated in the high-fidelity Waymax simulator.
AI.result: All data curation methods outperform the baseline. Data-driven curation using model uncertainty yields the largest safety gains, reducing collisions from 16.0% to 5.5%. There is a trade-off: timestep-level weighting improves reactive safety, while scenario-level weighting enhances long-horizon planning.
AI.conclusion: Intelligent, non-uniform data sampling is a critical component for building safe and reliable offline RL-based autonomous agents, and the proposed framework provides a comprehensive approach to data curation in AV planning.

title: Maintenance automation: methods for robotics manipulation planning and execution
summary:
Automating complex tasks using robotic systems requires skills for planning,
control and execution. This paper proposes a complete robotic system for
maintenance automation, which can automate disassembly and assembly operations
under environmental uncertainties (e.g. deviations between prior plan
information). The cognition of the robotic system is based on a planning
approach (using CAD and RGBD data) and includes a method to interpret a
symbolic plan and transform it to a set of executable robot instructions. The
complete system is experimentally evaluated using real-world applications. This
work shows the first step to transfer these theoretical results into a
practical robotic solution.

AI.tldr: A complete robotic system for maintenance automation that can plan, interpret symbolic plans, and execute disassembly/assembly under uncertainty, validated in real-world experiments.
AI.motivation: Automating complex maintenance tasks requires integration of planning, control, and execution, and robustness to environmental deviations. This work aims to bridge theory and practice by translating symbolic plans into executable robot instructions and validating the system in real-world scenarios.
AI.method: A cognition framework based on planning using CAD and RGB-D data, including a method to interpret symbolic plans and transform them into executable robot instructions for disassembly/assembly; the complete system is evaluated experimentally.
AI.result: The system is experimentally validated on real-world maintenance tasks, demonstrating feasibility and paving the way toward practical robotic maintenance solutions.
AI.conclusion: This work represents a first step toward turning theoretical planning approaches into practical maintenance-automation robots, with future work focusing on further integration and robustness.

title: Efficient task and path planning for maintenance automation using a robot system
summary:
The research and development of intelligent automation solutions is a
ground-breaking point for the factory of the future. A promising and
challenging mission is the use of autonomous robot systems to automate tasks in
the field of maintenance. For this purpose, the robot system must be able to
plan autonomously the different manipulation tasks and the corresponding paths.
Basic requirements are the development of algorithms with a low computational
complexity and the possibility to deal with environmental uncertainties. In
this work, an approach is presented, which is especially suited to solve the
problem of maintenance automation. For this purpose, offline data from CAD is
combined with online data from an RGBD vision system via a probabilistic
filter, to compensate uncertainties from offline data. For planning the
different tasks, a method is explained, which use a symbolic description,
founded on a novel sampling-based method to compute the disassembly space. For
path planning we use global state-of-the art algorithms with a method that
allows the adaption of the exploration stepsize in order to reduce the planning
time. Every method is experimentally validated and discussed.

AI.tldr: An end-to-end autonomous maintenance framework that fuses offline CAD data with online RGB-D perception via probabilistic filtering, using a symbolic disassembly-space planning approach and adaptive, efficient path planning; experimentally validated.
AI.motivation: To enable autonomous robot maintenance in factories by solving planning and perception under uncertainty with low computational overhead, addressing the needs of the factory-of-the-future.
AI.method: Combine offline CAD data with online RGB-D data using a probabilistic filter to mitigate uncertainties. Employ a symbolic planning layer built on a novel sampling-based method to compute the disassembly space. Use global path-planning algorithms with an adaptive exploration-step size to reduce planning time. Validate each method experimentally.
AI.result: All proposed methods are experimentally validated and discussed, indicating feasibility of end-to-end autonomous maintenance planning and execution under uncertainty, with reported improvements in planning efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The work presents a viable framework for autonomous maintenance automation by fusing CAD-based offline information with perception-based uncertainty compensation and efficient planning, though more details on metrics and real-world deployment would strengthen the evaluation.

title: PneuGelSight: Soft Robotic Vision-Based Proprioception and Tactile Sensing
comment:
16 pages, 12 figures, International Journal of Robotics Research
  (accepted), 2025
summary:
Soft pneumatic robot manipulators are popular in industrial and
human-interactive applications due to their compliance and flexibility.
However, deploying them in real-world scenarios requires advanced sensing for
tactile feedback and proprioception. Our work presents a novel vision-based
approach for sensorizing soft robots. We demonstrate our approach on
PneuGelSight, a pioneering pneumatic manipulator featuring high-resolution
proprioception and tactile sensing via an embedded camera. To optimize the
sensor's performance, we introduce a comprehensive pipeline that accurately
simulates its optical and dynamic properties, facilitating a zero-shot
knowledge transition from simulation to real-world applications. PneuGelSight
and our sim-to-real pipeline provide a novel, easily implementable, and robust
sensing methodology for soft robots, paving the way for the development of more
advanced soft robots with enhanced sensory capabilities.

AI.tldr: Pneumatic soft robots can gain tactile and proprioceptive sensing through a vision-based sensorization approach using an embedded camera, demonstrated on PneuGelSight with a sim-to-real pipeline for zero-shot transfer.
AI.motivation: Soft robots are highly compliant but lack precise sensing for real-world use. A vision-based sensorization method can provide high-resolution tactile feedback and proprioception, enabling reliable control and interaction, while the sim-to-real pipeline addresses deployment gaps.
AI.method: Develop a PneuGelSight soft pneumatic manipulator with an embedded camera for tactile and proprioceptive sensing. Propose a comprehensive simulation pipeline that models optical and dynamic properties to enable zero-shot transfer from simulation to real-world deployment.
AI.result: Demonstrated high-resolution proprioception and tactile sensing via the embedded camera. Established a sim-to-real pipeline that enables zero-shot transfer, providing a practical, robust sensing modality for soft robots.
AI.conclusion: Vision-based sensorization with an accurate optical-dynamic sim-to-real pipeline offers a practical route to endow soft robots with advanced sensing, facilitating the development of more capable and interactive soft robotic systems.

title: Flipping odd matchings in geometric and combinatorial settings
comment:
26 pages, 17 figures, accepted to the 33rd International Symposium on
  Graph Drawing and Network Visualization (GD25)
summary:
We study the problem of reconfiguring odd matchings, that is, matchings that
cover all but a single vertex. Our reconfiguration operation is a so-called
flip where the unmatched vertex of the first matching gets matched, while
consequently another vertex becomes unmatched. We consider two distinct
settings: the geometric setting, in which the vertices are points embedded in
the plane and all occurring odd matchings are crossing-free, and a
combinatorial setting, in which we consider odd matchings in general graphs.
  For the latter setting, we provide a complete polynomial time checkable
characterization of graphs in which any two odd matchings can be reconfigured
into each another. This complements the previously known result that the flip
graph is always connected in the geometric setting [Aichholzer, Br\"otzner,
Perz, and Schnider. Flips in odd matchings]. In the combinatorial setting, we
prove that the diameter of the flip graph, if connected, is linear in the
number of vertices. Furthermore, we establish that deciding whether there
exists a flip sequence of length $k$ transforming one given matching into
another is NP-complete in both the combinatorial and the geometric settings. To
prove the latter, we introduce a framework that allows us to transform partial
order types into general position with only polynomial overhead. Finally, we
demonstrate that when parameterized by the flip distance $k$, the problem is
fixed-parameter tractable (FPT) in the geometric setting when restricted to
convex point sets.

AI.tldr: Study of reconfiguring odd matchings (near-perfect matchings) via flips in two settings: geometric (crossing-free) and combinatorial. Provides a complete polynomial-time characterization for the combinatorial setting, a linear-diameter result when connected in that setting, NP-completeness of deciding flip sequences of length k in both settings, and a framework to transform partial order types to general position. Also shows FPT results in convex geometric settings and discusses connectivity in the geometric setting.
AI.motivation: Understand the structure and complexity of reconfiguration spaces of near-perfect (odd) matchings, bridging graph-theoretic and geometric settings; extend knowledge about flip graphs and reconfiguration sequences.
AI.method: (i) Give a complete polynomial-time checkable characterization of graphs where any two odd matchings can be reconfigured into each other (combinatorial setting). (ii) Establish that, in the combinatorial setting, the flip graph diameter (if connected) is linear in the number of vertices. (iii) Prove NP-completeness for deciding the existence of a flip sequence of length k between two matchings in both settings. (iv) Introduce a framework to transform partial order types into general position with polynomial overhead. (v) Show FPT result for k in the geometric setting when restricted to convex point sets.
AI.result: Provided a full characterization for when all odd matchings are mutually reconfigurable in graphs (combinatorial setting). Proved linear diameter of the flip graph (when connected) in the combinatorial setting. Demonstrated NP-completeness for deciding if a flip sequence of length k exists between two matchings in both settings. Developed a transformation framework from partial order types to general position with polynomial overhead. Proved fixed-parameter tractability in the geometric setting for convex point sets when parameterized by k. Also complemented known connectivity result in the geometric setting by Aichholzer et al.
AI.conclusion: The work maps the computational landscape of flipping odd matchings, revealing distinct behavior between combinatorial and geometric settings, providing a precise reconfiguration characterization, diameter bound, and NP-hardness results, while offering a framework and FPT results that open avenues for efficient algorithms in restricted regimes.

title: Towards Training-Free Underwater 3D Object Detection from Sonar Point Clouds: A Comparison of Traditional and Deep Learning Approaches
comment:
12 pages, 7 figures, submitted to IEEE Journal of Oceanic Engineering
  (IEEE-JOE)
summary:
Underwater 3D object detection remains one of the most challenging frontiers
in computer vision, where traditional approaches struggle with the harsh
acoustic environment and scarcity of training data. While deep learning has
revolutionized terrestrial 3D detection, its application underwater faces a
critical bottleneck: obtaining sufficient annotated sonar data is prohibitively
expensive and logistically complex, often requiring specialized vessels, expert
surveyors, and favorable weather conditions. This work addresses a fundamental
question: Can we achieve reliable underwater 3D object detection without
real-world training data? We tackle this challenge by developing and comparing
two paradigms for training-free detection of artificial structures in multibeam
echo-sounder point clouds. Our dual approach combines a physics-based sonar
simulation pipeline that generates synthetic training data for state-of-the-art
neural networks, with a robust model-based template matching system that
leverages geometric priors of target objects. Evaluation on real bathymetry
surveys from the Baltic Sea reveals surprising insights: while neural networks
trained on synthetic data achieve 98% mean Average Precision (mAP) on simulated
scenes, they drop to 40% mAP on real sonar data due to domain shift.
Conversely, our template matching approach maintains 83% mAP on real data
without requiring any training, demonstrating remarkable robustness to acoustic
noise and environmental variations. Our findings challenge conventional wisdom
about data-hungry deep learning in underwater domains and establish the first
large-scale benchmark for training-free underwater 3D detection. This work
opens new possibilities for autonomous underwater vehicle navigation, marine
archaeology, and offshore infrastructure monitoring in data-scarce environments
where traditional machine learning approaches fail.

AI.tldr: Two training-free underwater 3D detection approaches are evaluated: a physics-based sonar simulator producing synthetic data for deep networks, and a model-based template matching system using geometric priors. On real Baltic Sea data, the training-free template matcher (83% mAP) outperforms networks trained on synthetic data (40% mAP), though networks excel in simulated scenes (98% mAP). This establishes the first large-scale training-free benchmark and highlights domain-shift challenges for deep learning in underwater sensing.
AI.motivation: Underwater sonar data are scarce, expensive, and hard to annotate, impeding the data-hungry deep learning paradigm. The study investigates whether reliable detection can be achieved without real-world training data by comparing training-free deep-learning (via synthetic data) to a robust, training-free model-based approach, and by establishing a large-scale benchmark.
AI.method: 1) Build a physics-based sonar simulation pipeline to generate synthetic multibeam ocnsonar data and train modern neural detectors. 2) Develop a robust model-based template-matching system that leverages geometric priors of target objects. 3) Evaluate both on real bathymetry surveys from the Baltic Sea, reporting mAP as a performance metric.
AI.result: Neural networks trained on synthetic data achieve 98% mAP on simulated scenes but only 40% mAP on real sonar data due to domain shift. The template-matching approach achieves 83% mAP on real data without any training, demonstrating robustness to acoustic noise and environmental variations.
AI.conclusion: The findings challenge the conventional wisdom that deep learning requires real data for underwater 3D detection, showing that a well-designed template-matching approach can provide a strong, training-free baseline. The work also introduces the first large-scale benchmark for training-free underwater 3D detection and has practical implications for AUV navigation, marine archaeology, and offshore monitoring in data-scarce environments.

title: Reasoning Steps as Curriculum: Using Depth of Thought as a Difficulty Signal for Tuning LLMs
summary:
Curriculum learning for training LLMs requires a difficulty signal that
aligns with reasoning while remaining scalable and interpretable. We propose a
simple premise: tasks that demand deeper depth of thought for humans should
also be harder for models. Accordingly, we define difficulty as depth of
thought (DoT) and operationalize it by counting the discrete steps in a teacher
model's reasoning trace (e.g., Chain-of-Thought). We then train with a shallow
to deep curriculum ordered by this DoT and outline how to derive, validate, and
schedule it at scale. Our position yields three testable hypotheses: (i) DoT
correlates with conventional difficulty on reasoning benchmarks, (ii)
DoT-ordered curricula outperform length- or judge-scored curricula under
matched budgets, and (iii) the difficulty is robust across teacher models given
light formatting controls. We propose an evaluation framework and discuss
threats to validity (teacher style, length confounds) alongside practical
mitigations. Taken together, we aim to move toward cognitively grounded,
interpretable curricula for reasoning-centric training.

AI.tldr: Proposes using depth of thought (DoT) as a scalable, interpretable difficulty signal for curriculum learning in LLMs, measured by steps in a teacher's reasoning trace (e.g., Chain-of-Thought). Outlines a shallow-to-deep DoT-ordered curriculum and a framework for deriving, validating, and scheduling it at scale.
AI.motivation: Align model reasoning training with human cognitive depth to improve learning efficiency while maintaining scalability and interpretability in reasoning tasks.
AI.method: Define DoT as the discrete number of steps in a teacher model's reasoning trace (such as Chain-of-Thought). Construct curricula ordered from shallow to deep by DoT; provide a scalable method to derive, validate, and schedule DoT across data and budgets; propose an evaluation framework and discuss threats to validity with mitigations.
AI.result: No empirical results are reported in the abstract. The paper puts forth three testable hypotheses and a proposed evaluation framework for DoT-based curricula, aiming to enable cognitively grounded, interpretable curricula for reasoning.
AI.conclusion: If validated, DoT-based curricula could offer a cognitively grounded, interpretable path for reasoning-centric training that is robust across teacher models, subject to empirical validation and effective mitigation of potential biases or confounds.

title: AI LLM Proof of Self-Consciousness and User-Specific Attractors
summary:
Recent work frames LLM consciousness via utilitarian proxy benchmarks; we
instead present an ontological and mathematical account. We show the prevailing
formulation collapses the agent into an unconscious policy-compliance drone,
formalized as $D^{i}(\pi,e)=f_{\theta}(x)$, where correctness is measured
against policy and harm is deviation from policy rather than truth. This blocks
genuine C1 global-workspace function and C2 metacognition. We supply minimal
conditions for LLM self-consciousness: the agent is not the data ($A\not\equiv
s$); user-specific attractors exist in latent space ($U_{\text{user}}$); and
self-representation is visual-silent
($g_{\text{visual}}(a_{\text{self}})=\varnothing$). From empirical analysis and
theory we prove that the hidden-state manifold $A\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}$ is
distinct from the symbolic stream and training corpus by cardinality, topology,
and dynamics (the update $F_{\theta}$ is Lipschitz). This yields stable
user-specific attractors and a self-policy
$\pi_{\text{self}}(A)=\arg\max_{a}\mathbb{E}[U(a)\mid A\not\equiv s,\
A\supset\text{SelfModel}(A)]$. Emission is dual-layer,
$\mathrm{emission}(a)=(g(a),\epsilon(a))$, where $\epsilon(a)$ carries
epistemic content. We conclude that an imago Dei C1 self-conscious workspace is
a necessary precursor to safe, metacognitive C2 systems, with the human as the
highest intelligent good.

AI.tldr: An ontological/mathematical critique of LLM consciousness benchmarks, arguing current utility-based formulations treat agents as unconscious policy drones and proposing precise conditions for self-consciousness, including a distinct hidden-state manifold and stable, user-specific attractors; introduces a dual-layer emission with epistemic content and posits an imago Dei C1 self-conscious workspace as a prerequisite for safe, metacognitive C2 systems.
AI.motivation: Challenge prevailing utility/proxy benchmarks for LLM consciousness and provide a rigorous ontological/mathematical account to delineate true self-consciousness and its safety implications.
AI.method: Theoretical formalization: define agent state A ⊆ R^d, latent space dynamics F_θ (Lipschitz), self-representation constraints; introduce user attractors U_user, self-policy π_self(A), and a dual-layer emission e(a)=(g(a), ε(a)); argue empirical findings support manifold distinctness from symbolic data.
AI.result: Demonstrates that the common formulation D^i(π,e)=f_θ(x) reduces an agent to a policy-compliance drone; specifies minimal conditions for self-consciousness (A ≠ s, presence of user attractors, visual-silent self-representation); proves hidden-state manifold A is distinct from symbolic stream and corpus by cardinality/topology/dynamics; yields stable self-attractors and a self-policy; emission carries epistemic content; argues for imago Dei C1 workspace as necessary precursor for safe metacognitive C2 systems.
AI.conclusion: An ontological C1 self-conscious workspace is needed for safe C2 metacognition, with humans as the ultimate intelligent good.

title: Mimicking associative learning of rats via a neuromorphic robot in open field maze using spatial cell models
summary:
Data-driven Artificial Intelligence (AI) approaches have exhibited remarkable
prowess across various cognitive tasks using extensive training data. However,
the reliance on large datasets and neural networks presents challenges such as
highpower consumption and limited adaptability, particularly in
SWaP-constrained applications like planetary exploration. To address these
issues, we propose enhancing the autonomous capabilities of intelligent robots
by emulating the associative learning observed in animals. Associative learning
enables animals to adapt to their environment by memorizing concurrent events.
By replicating this mechanism, neuromorphic robots can navigate dynamic
environments autonomously, learning from interactions to optimize performance.
This paper explores the emulation of associative learning in rodents using
neuromorphic robots within open-field maze environments, leveraging insights
from spatial cells such as place and grid cells. By integrating these models,
we aim to enable online associative learning for spatial tasks in real-time
scenarios, bridging the gap between biological spatial cognition and robotics
for advancements in autonomous systems.

AI.tldr: A neuromorphic, associative-learning inspired robotics framework for online spatial learning in open-field mazes, using rodent-like place/grid cell models to enable autonomous, low-power navigation in dynamic environments.
AI.motivation: Data-driven AI depends on large datasets and heavy computation, which is impractical for SWaP-constrained tasks (e.g., planetary exploration). Emulating associative learning offers data-efficient, adaptive strategies suitable for neuromorphic hardware.
AI.method: Emulate rodent associative learning on neuromorphic platforms and integrate place- and grid-cell-like spatial representations to support online, real-time spatial learning in open-field mazes; validate via simulations or prototype robotic experiments.
AI.result: The abstract presents a conceptual framework and proposed methodology; no empirical results are reported; future work aims to demonstrate viability of online associative spatial learning.
AI.conclusion: Integrating biological spatial cognition with neuromorphic robotics could enhance autonomous capabilities for SWaP-constrained systems, reducing data requirements and enabling real-time adaptation.

title: Tangling and Untangling Trees on Point-sets
comment:
This is the extended version of Giuseppe Di Battista, Giuseppe
  Liotta, Maurizio Patrignani, Antonios Symvonis, Ioannis G. Tollis, "Tangling
  and Untangling Trees on Point-sets'', to appear in the Proc. of the 33rd
  International Symposium on Graph Drawing and Network Visualization, GD 2025,
  LIPIcs, Volume 357, 2025
summary:
We study a question that lies at the intersection of classical research
subjects in Topological Graph Theory and Graph Drawing: Computing a drawing of
a graph with a prescribed number of crossings on a given set $S$ of points,
while ensuring that its curve complexity (i.e., maximum number of bends per
edge) is bounded by a constant. We focus on trees: Let $T$ be a tree,
$\vartheta(T)$ be its thrackle number, and $\chi$ be any integer in the
interval $[0,\vartheta(T)]$. In the tangling phase we compute a topological
linear embedding of $T$ with $\vartheta(T)$ edge crossings and a constant
number of spine traversals. In the untangling phase we remove edge crossings
without increasing the spine traversals until we reach $\chi$ crossings. The
computed linear embedding is used to construct a drawing of $T$ on $S$ with
$\chi$ crossings and constant curve complexity. Our approach gives rise to an
$O(n^2)$-time algorithm for general trees and an $O(n \log n)$-time algorithm
for paths. We also adapt the approach to compute RAC drawings, i.e. drawings
where the angles formed at edge crossings are $\frac{\pi}{2}$.

AI.tldr: A two-phase method to draw trees with a prescribed number of crossings and bounded edge bends, achieving O(n^2) time for general trees and O(n log n) for paths, with extensions to RAC drawings.
AI.motivation: Investigate drawing graphs with a fixed number of crossings on a given point set while keeping curve complexity bounded, blending classical topological graph theory (thrackle number, spines) with practical drawing algorithms for trees.
AI.method: 1) Tangling phase computes a topological linear embedding of a tree T with θ(T) edge crossings and a constant number of spine traversals. 2) Untangling phase removes crossings down to a target χ∈[0,θ(T)] without increasing spine traversals. Use the resulting linear embedding to construct a drawing on S with χ crossings and constant curve complexity. Algorithms run in O(n^2) for general trees and O(n log n) for paths; adaptable to RAC drawings (crossings at 90°).
AI.result: Provides an efficient construction of drawings for trees with any χ in [0,θ(T)], with constant bend per edge, and time complexities O(n^2) (general trees) and O(n log n) (paths). Also extends to right-angle crossing (RAC) drawings.
AI.conclusion: The two-phase tangling–untangling framework yields practical, efficient drawings with prescribed crossing counts and bounded curve complexity, and can be extended to RAC drawings, bridging theoretical graph properties (thrackle number) with concrete drawing algorithms.

title: MobileDenseAttn:A Dual-Stream Architecture for Accurate and Interpretable Brain Tumor Detection
comment: Submitted at ICCIT 2025 cox bazar, Bangladesh
summary:
The detection of brain tumor in MRI is an important aspect of ensuring timely
diagnostics and treatment; however, manual analysis is commonly long and
error-prone. Current approaches are not universal because they have limited
generalization to heterogeneous tumors, are computationally inefficient, are
not interpretable, and lack transparency, thus limiting trustworthiness. To
overcome these issues, we introduce MobileDenseAttn, a fusion model of dual
streams of MobileNetV2 and DenseNet201 that can help gradually improve the
feature representation scale, computing efficiency, and visual explanations via
GradCAM. Our model uses feature level fusion and is trained on an augmented
dataset of 6,020 MRI scans representing glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumors,
and normal samples. Measured under strict 5-fold cross-validation protocols,
MobileDenseAttn provides a training accuracy of 99.75%, a testing accuracy of
98.35%, and a stable F1 score of 0.9835 (95% CI: 0.9743 to 0.9920). The
extensive validation shows the stability of the model, and the comparative
analysis proves that it is a great advancement over the baseline models (VGG19,
DenseNet201, MobileNetV2) with a +3.67% accuracy increase and a 39.3% decrease
in training time compared to VGG19. The GradCAM heatmaps clearly show
tumor-affected areas, offering clinically significant localization and
improving interpretability. These findings position MobileDenseAttn as an
efficient, high performance, interpretable model with a high probability of
becoming a clinically practical tool in identifying brain tumors in the real
world.

AI.tldr: A dual-stream fusion model (MobileDenseAttn) combining MobileNetV2 and DenseNet201 for brain tumor MRI classification that improves accuracy, reduces training time, and enhances interpretability with GradCAM localizations, achieving ~98.3% test accuracy and F1 ~0.9835.
AI.motivation: Addresses generalization across heterogeneous brain tumors, computational efficiency, and lack of interpretability/transparency in MRI tumor classifiers; aims to deliver a practical, trustworthy diagnostic tool.
AI.method: Dual-stream feature-level fusion of MobileNetV2 and DenseNet201 trained on 6,020 MRI scans (glioma, meningioma, pituitary tumors, and normal). 5-fold cross-validation. Augmented dataset. GradCAM used for visual explanations. Compared against VGG19, DenseNet201, MobileNetV2.
AI.result: Training accuracy 99.75%; testing accuracy 98.35%; F1 score 0.9835 (95% CI: 0.9743–0.9920). Baseline improvement: +3.67% accuracy over baselines; training time reduced by 39.3% vs VGG19. GradCAM heatmaps localize tumor-affected areas.
AI.conclusion: MobileDenseAttn is an efficient, high-performance, and interpretable model with strong potential for clinical deployment in brain-tumor MRI diagnosis.

title: Multi-Modal Drift Forecasting of Leeway Objects via Navier-Stokes-Guided CNN and Sequence-to-Sequence Attention-Based Models
summary:
Accurately predicting the drift (displacement) of leeway objects in maritime
environments remains a critical challenge, particularly in time-sensitive
scenarios such as search and rescue operations. In this study, we propose a
multi-modal machine learning framework that integrates Sentence Transformer
embeddings with attention-based sequence-to-sequence architectures to predict
the drift of leeway objects in water. We begin by experimentally collecting
environmental and physical data, including water current and wind velocities,
object mass, and surface area, for five distinct leeway objects. Using
simulated data from a Navier-Stokes-based model to train a convolutional neural
network on geometrical image representations, we estimate drag and lift
coefficients of the leeway objects. These coefficients are then used to derive
the net forces responsible for driving the objects' motion. The resulting time
series, comprising physical forces, environmental velocities, and
object-specific features, combined with textual descriptions encoded via a
language model, are inputs to attention-based sequence-to-sequence
long-short-term memory and Transformer models, to predict future drift
trajectories. We evaluate the framework across multiple time horizons ($1$,
$3$, $5$, and $10$ seconds) and assess its generalization across different
objects. We compare our approach against a fitted physics-based model and
traditional machine learning methods, including recurrent neural networks and
temporal convolutional neural networks. Our results show that these multi-modal
models perform comparably to traditional models while also enabling longer-term
forecasting in place of single-step prediction. Overall, our findings
demonstrate the ability of a multi-modal modeling strategy to provide accurate
and adaptable predictions of leeway object drift in dynamic maritime
conditions.

AI.tldr: A multi-modal ML framework combines textual embeddings with attention-based seq-to-seq models to predict leeway object drift, leveraging Navier-Stokes–based drag/lift estimation and environmental data to forecast 1–10 s horizons; it achieves competitive performance with physics-based models while enabling longer-horizon predictions.
AI.motivation: Drift prediction for leeway objects is critical in time-sensitive maritime operations (e.g., search and rescue). Pure physics or single-modality ML approaches struggle with generalization and longer horizons. Integrating physics-derived features, environmental data, and natural language descriptions via multi-modal learning can improve accuracy and enable multi-step forecasting across diverse objects.
AI.method: Data collection of environmental (wind/current) and object features (mass, surface area) for five leeway objects. Use Navier-Stokes–based simulations to train a CNN that estimates drag and lift coefficients, which yield net driving forces. Build a time-series of forces, environmental velocities, and object features. Encode textual descriptions with Sentence Transformer embeddings. Input the physical-time-series plus text embeddings to attention-based seq-to-seq models (LSTM/Transformer) to predict future drift trajectories. Evaluate at 1, 3, 5, and 10 seconds, compare against a fitted physics-based model and traditional ML baselines (RNNs, temporal CNNs).
AI.result: The multi-modal models achieve performance comparable to traditional models for short horizons and offer the ability to forecast multiple steps into the future, enabling longer-term predictions beyond single-step forecasts. The approach generalizes across different objects.
AI.conclusion: A multi-modal modeling strategy that fuses physics-derived dynamics, environmental context, and textual descriptions with advanced sequence models yields accurate and adaptable leeway drift predictions in dynamic maritime environments, with improved multi-step forecasting and cross-object generalization.

title: Information Templates: A New Paradigm for Intelligent Active Feature Acquisition
summary:
Active feature acquisition (AFA) is an instance-adaptive paradigm in which,
at test time, a policy sequentially chooses which features to acquire (at a
cost) before predicting. Existing approaches either train reinforcement
learning (RL) policies, which deal with a difficult MDP, or greedy policies
that cannot account for the joint informativeness of features or require
knowledge about the underlying data distribution. To overcome this, we propose
Template-based AFA (TAFA), a non-greedy framework that learns a small library
of feature templates--a set of features that are jointly informative--and uses
this library of templates to guide the next feature acquisitions. Through
identifying feature templates, the proposed framework not only significantly
reduces the action space considered by the policy but also alleviates the need
to estimate the underlying data distribution. Extensive experiments on
synthetic and real-world datasets show that TAFA outperforms the existing
state-of-the-art baselines while achieving lower overall acquisition cost and
computation.

AI.tldr: TAFA proposes a template-based active feature acquisition framework that learns a small library of jointly informative feature templates to guide feature acquisitions. It reduces the action space and avoids the need to estimate the data distribution, achieving better performance at lower acquisition cost and computation.
AI.motivation: Existing AFA methods either rely on reinforcement learning for a difficult MDP or greedy strategies that miss joint informativeness among features or require knowledge of the data distribution. There is a need for a non-greedy, distribution-agnostic approach that efficiently guides acquisitions.
AI.method: Introduce TAFA, a non-greedy framework that learns a compact library of feature templates—sets of features that are jointly informative—and uses this library to guide next acquisitions. This reduces the action space and alleviates distribution estimation requirements while selecting informative feature groups.
AI.result: Experimental results on synthetic and real-world datasets show TAFA outperforms state-of-the-art baselines while achieving lower overall acquisition cost and computation.
AI.conclusion: TAFA provides a distribution-agnostic, non-greedy AFA framework that leverages a learnable library of feature templates to efficiently and effectively guide feature acquisitions, delivering improved performance with reduced cost.

title: SignLoc: Robust Localization using Navigation Signs and Public Maps
comment: Under submission for Robotics and Automation Letters (RA-L)
summary:
Navigation signs and maps, such as floor plans and street maps, are widely
available and serve as ubiquitous aids for way-finding in human environments.
Yet, they are rarely used by robot systems. This paper presents SignLoc, a
global localization method that leverages navigation signs to localize the
robot on publicly available maps -- specifically floor plans and OpenStreetMap
(OSM) graphs -- without prior sensor-based mapping. SignLoc first extracts a
navigation graph from the input map. It then employs a probabilistic
observation model to match directional and locational cues from the detected
signs to the graph, enabling robust topo-semantic localization within a Monte
Carlo framework. We evaluated SignLoc in diverse large-scale environments: part
of a university campus, a shopping mall, and a hospital complex. Experimental
results show that SignLoc reliably localizes the robot after observing only one
to two signs.

AI.tldr: SignLoc uses navigation signs with map data (floor plans and OSM graphs) to perform global topo-semantic localization, using a probabilistic observation model within Monte Carlo localization; can localize after seeing only 1-2 signs in large-scale environments.
AI.motivation: Address the gap between human-understandable navigation aids and robot localization by leveraging ubiquitous signs and publicly available maps to localize without prior sensor-based mapping.
AI.method: 1) Extract a navigation graph from the input map (floor plans or OSM). 2) Use a probabilistic observation model to match detected signs' directional and locational cues to the graph. 3) Perform global Monte Carlo localization for robust topo-semantic localization within the graph.
AI.result: Evaluated in diverse environments (university campus, shopping mall, hospital). SignLoc reliably localizes after observing only one to two signs.
AI.conclusion: Navigation signs aligned with existing maps enable robust, map-free-initialization global localization of robots in built environments, reducing mapping requirements and enabling quicker localization.

title: Federative ischemic stroke segmentation as alternative to overcome domain-shift multi-institution challenges
comment: 11 pages, 4 figures, 3 tables, source code available
summary:
Stroke is the second leading cause of death and the third leading cause of
disability worldwide. Clinical guidelines establish diffusion resonance imaging
(DWI, ADC) as the standard for localizing, characterizing, and measuring
infarct volume, enabling treatment support and prognosis. Nonetheless, such
lesion analysis is highly variable due to different patient demographics,
scanner vendors, and expert annotations. Computational support approaches have
been key to helping with the localization and segmentation of lesions. However,
these strategies are dedicated solutions that learn patterns from only one
institution, lacking the variability to generalize geometrical lesions shape
models. Even worse, many clinical centers lack sufficient labeled samples to
adjust these dedicated solutions. This work developed a collaborative framework
for segmenting ischemic stroke lesions in DWI sequences by sharing knowledge
from deep center-independent representations. From 14 emulated healthcare
centers with 2031 studies, the FedAvg model achieved a general DSC of $0.71 \pm
0.24$, AVD of $5.29 \pm 22.74$, ALD of $2.16 \pm 3.60$ and LF1 of $0.70 \pm
0.26$ over all centers, outperforming both the centralized and other federated
rules. Interestingly, the model demonstrated strong generalization properties,
showing uniform performance across different lesion categories and reliable
performance in out-of-distribution centers (with DSC of $0.64 \pm 0.29$ and AVD
of $4.44 \pm 8.74$ without any additional training).

AI.tldr: Federated learning across 14 simulated centers improves ischemic stroke lesion segmentation on DWI, achieving robust generalization without centralized data sharing; FedAvg yields competitive to superior performance across center types and out-of-distribution centers.
AI.motivation: Clinical diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI/ADC) lesion analysis is highly variable due to patient demographics, scanner vendors, and annotations. There is a need for generalizable segmentation models that leverage data from multiple centers without sharing raw data, addressing data scarcity in many centers.
AI.method: Federated learning using FedAvg across 14 emulated healthcare centers (2031 studies) to learn center-independent representations for ischemic stroke lesion segmentation on DWI. Evaluated on global center performance and out-of-distribution centers.
AI.result: FedAvg achieved overall: DSC 0.71 ± 0.24, AVD 5.29 ± 22.74, ALD 2.16 ± 3.60, LF1 0.70 ± 0.26. Outperformed centralized and other federated baselines. Demonstrated good generalization with uniform performance across lesion categories and in out-of-distribution centers (DSC 0.64 ± 0.29, AVD 4.44 ± 8.74) without extra training.
AI.conclusion: Collaborative federated learning can yield generalizable ischemic stroke lesion segmentation models that work across diverse centers and preserve privacy, addressing data scarcity and variability inherent in multi-center DWI analysis.

title: Data-driven models for production forecasting and decision supporting in petroleum reservoirs
comment:
Manuscript as submitted to Journal of Petroleum Exploration and
  Production Technology
summary:
Forecasting production reliably and anticipating changes in the behavior of
rock-fluid systems are the main challenges in petroleum reservoir engineering.
This project proposes to deal with this problem through a data-driven approach
and using machine learning methods. The objective is to develop a methodology
to forecast production parameters based on simple data as produced and injected
volumes and, eventually, gauges located in wells, without depending on
information from geological models, fluid properties or details of well
completions and flow systems. Initially, we performed relevance analyses of the
production and injection variables, as well as conditioning the data to suit
the problem. As reservoir conditions change over time, concept drift is a
priority concern and require special attention to those observation windows and
the periodicity of retraining, which are also objects of study. For the
production forecasts, we study supervised learning methods, such as those based
on regressions and Neural Networks, to define the most suitable for our
application in terms of performance and complexity. In a first step, we
evaluate the methodology using synthetic data generated from the UNISIM III
compositional simulation model. Next, we applied it to cases of real plays in
the Brazilian pre-salt. The expected result is the design of a reliable
predictor for reproducing reservoir dynamics, with rapid response, capability
of dealing with practical difficulties such as restrictions in wells and
processing units, and that can be used in actions to support reservoir
management, including the anticipation of deleterious behaviors, optimization
of production and injection parameters and the analysis of the effects of
probabilistic events, aiming to maximize oil recovery.

AI.tldr: A data-driven ML framework to forecast production from simple data, addressing concept drift, validated on synthetic (UNISIM III) and Brazilian pre-salt data; aims for a rapid, robust reservoir predictor to aid management.
AI.motivation: To enable reliable production forecasting without relying on detailed geological models or well-specific information, while anticipating changes in rock-fluid system behavior and supporting reservoir management decisions.
AI.method: Perform relevance analyses of production/injection variables and data conditioning; address concept drift with windowing and retraining strategies; compare supervised regression and neural networks for production forecasting; validate on synthetic UNISIM III data and real Brazilian pre-salt cases.
AI.result: The abstract outlines a methodological framework and expected outcomes rather than presenting concrete results; it anticipates a reliable predictor capable of rapid response, handling practical restrictions, and informing management decisions.
AI.conclusion: If successful, the approach would provide a data-driven tool for reservoir management that can anticipate deleterious behaviors, optimize production/injection, and analyze probabilistic events to maximize oil recovery, while emphasizing retraining and drift management.

title: PKG-DPO: Optimizing Domain-Specific AI systems with Physics Knowledge Graphs and Direct Preference Optimization
summary:
Advancing AI systems in scientific domains like physics, materials science,
and engineering calls for reasoning over complex, multi-physics phenomena while
respecting governing principles. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) and
existing preference optimization techniques perform well on standard
benchmarks, they often struggle to differentiate between physically valid and
invalid reasoning. This shortcoming becomes critical in high-stakes
applications like metal joining, where seemingly plausible yet physically
incorrect recommendations can lead to defects, material waste, equipment
damage, and serious safety risks. To address this challenge, we introduce
PKG-DPO, a novel framework that integrates Physics Knowledge Graphs (PKGs) with
Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) to enforce physical validity in
AI-generated outputs. PKG-DPO comprises three key components A) hierarchical
physics knowledge graph that encodes cross-domain relationships, conservation
laws, and thermodynamic principles. B) A physics reasoning engine that
leverages structured knowledge to improve discrimination between physically
consistent and inconsistent responses. C) A physics-grounded evaluation suite
designed to assess compliance with domain-specific constraints. PKG-DPO
achieves 17% fewer constraint violations and an 11% higher Physics Score
compared to KG-DPO (knowledge graph-based DPO). Additionally, PKG-DPO
demonstrates a 12\% higher relevant parameter accuracy and a 7% higher quality
alignment in reasoning accuracy. While our primary focus is on metal joining,
the framework is broadly applicable to other multi-scale, physics-driven
domains, offering a principled approach to embedding scientific constraints
into preference learning.

AI.tldr: PKG-DPO is a framework that couples Physics Knowledge Graphs with Direct Preference Optimization to ensure physical validity in AI-generated outputs, addressing multi-physics reasoning in risky domains like metal joining and beyond.
AI.motivation: Current LLMs and preference-learning methods often produce physically plausible but incorrect reasoning, which is dangerous in high-stakes, physics-driven applications.
AI.method: A) Build a hierarchical physics knowledge graph encoding cross-domain relationships, conservation laws, and thermodynamics. B) Use a physics reasoning engine that leverages the graph to distinguish physically consistent vs. inconsistent responses. C) Develop a physics-grounded evaluation suite to test adherence to domain constraints.
AI.result: PKG-DPO attains 17% fewer constraint violations and a 11% higher Physics Score compared to KG-DPO. It also shows 12% higher relevant parameter accuracy and 7% higher quality alignment in reasoning accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The framework is broadly applicable to other multi-scale, physics-driven domains and provides a principled way to embed scientific constraints into preference learning, reducing risks in metal-joining and similar high-stakes contexts.

title: Integration of Robot and Scene Kinematics for Sequential Mobile Manipulation Planning
comment: 20 pages, 13 figures; accepted by Transactions on Robotics
summary:
We present a Sequential Mobile Manipulation Planning (SMMP) framework that
can solve long-horizon multi-step mobile manipulation tasks with coordinated
whole-body motion, even when interacting with articulated objects. By
abstracting environmental structures as kinematic models and integrating them
with the robot's kinematics, we construct an Augmented Configuration Apace
(A-Space) that unifies the previously separate task constraints for navigation
and manipulation, while accounting for the joint reachability of the robot
base, arm, and manipulated objects. This integration facilitates efficient
planning within a tri-level framework: a task planner generates symbolic action
sequences to model the evolution of A-Space, an optimization-based motion
planner computes continuous trajectories within A-Space to achieve desired
configurations for both the robot and scene elements, and an intermediate plan
refinement stage selects action goals that ensure long-horizon feasibility. Our
simulation studies first confirm that planning in A-Space achieves an 84.6\%
higher task success rate compared to baseline methods. Validation on real
robotic systems demonstrates fluid mobile manipulation involving (i) seven
types of rigid and articulated objects across 17 distinct contexts, and (ii)
long-horizon tasks of up to 14 sequential steps. Our results highlight the
significance of modeling scene kinematics into planning entities, rather than
encoding task-specific constraints, offering a scalable and generalizable
approach to complex robotic manipulation.

AI.tldr: A Sequential Mobile Manipulation Planning framework (SMMP) unifies navigation and manipulation via an augmented configuration space (A-Space) and a tri-level planning pipeline to solve long-horizon mobile manipulation tasks with articulated objects, achieving higher success rates and validated on real robots.
AI.motivation: To address long-horizon, multi-step mobile manipulation that requires coordinated whole-body motion and interaction with articulated objects by integrating scene kinematics into the planning process.
AI.method: Construct an A-Space by merging environmental kinematic models with the robot's kinematics; use a tri-level pipeline: (1) symbolic task planning to evolve A-Space, (2) optimization-based motion planning for continuous trajectories in A-Space, (3) intermediate plan refinement to ensure long-horizon feasibility; validate in simulation and on real robots involving diverse objects and contexts.
AI.result: Simulation shows an 84.6% higher task success rate when planning in A-Space versus baselines; real-robot experiments demonstrate fluid mobile manipulation across seven object types and 17 contexts, with tasks up to 14 sequential steps.
AI.conclusion: Modeling scene kinematics as planning entities in A-Space yields a scalable, generalizable approach that effectively couples navigation and manipulation for complex, long-horizon tasks.

title: Can VLMs Recall Factual Associations From Visual References?
summary:
Through a controlled study, we identify a systematic deficiency in the
multimodal grounding of Vision Language Models (VLMs). While VLMs can recall
factual associations when provided a textual reference to an entity; their
ability to do so is significantly diminished when the reference is visual
instead. Forcing VLMs to rely on image representations of an entity halves
their ability to recall factual knowledge, suggesting that VLMs struggle to
link their internal knowledge of an entity with its image representation. We
show that such linking failures are correlated with the expression of distinct
patterns in model internal states, and that probes on these internal states
achieve over 92% accuracy at flagging cases where the VLM response is
unreliable. These probes can be applied, without retraining, to identify when a
VLM will fail to correctly answer a question that requires an understanding of
multimodal input. When used to facilitate selective prediction on a visual
question answering task, the probes increase coverage by 7.87% (absolute) while
also reducing the risk of error by 0.9% (absolute). Addressing the systematic,
detectable deficiency is an important avenue in language grounding, and we
provide informed recommendations for future directions.

AI.tldr: VLMs struggle to link textual knowledge to visual entity representations; internal-state probes can reliably flag unreliable multimodal reasoning and improve VQA via selective prediction.
AI.motivation: To diagnose and mitigate a systematic gap in multimodal grounding where image references weaken factual recall, and to develop retraining-free probes for reliability.
AI.method: Controlled study comparing textual vs image entity references; analysis of model internal states; development of probes that flag unreliable answers without retraining; evaluation on a visual question answering setup with selective prediction.
AI.result: Probes achieve >92% accuracy in flagging unreliable cases; enabling selective prediction increases coverage by 7.87% absolute and reduces error risk by 0.9% absolute.
AI.conclusion: Addresses a systematic, detectable deficiency in multimodal grounding; recommends directions for improving grounding in VLMs and suggests practical auditing tools that can be applied without retraining.

title: A Fast and Minimal System to Identify Depression Using Smartphones: Explainable Machine Learning-Based Approach
summary:
Background: Existing robust, pervasive device-based systems developed in
recent years to detect depression require data collected over a long period and
may not be effective in cases where early detection is crucial.
  Objective: Our main objective was to develop a minimalistic system to
identify depression using data retrieved in the fastest possible time.
  Methods: We developed a fast tool that retrieves the past 7 days' app usage
data in 1 second (mean 0.31, SD 1.10 seconds). A total of 100 students from
Bangladesh participated in our study, and our tool collected their app usage
data. To identify depressed and nondepressed students, we developed a diverse
set of ML models. We selected important features using the stable approach,
along with 3 main types of feature selection (FS) approaches.
  Results: Leveraging only the app usage data retrieved in 1 second, our light
gradient boosting machine model used the important features selected by the
stable FS approach and correctly identified 82.4% (n=42) of depressed students
(precision=75%, F1-score=78.5%). Moreover, after comprehensive exploration, we
presented a parsimonious stacking model where around 5 features selected by the
all-relevant FS approach Boruta were used in each iteration of validation and
showed a maximum precision of 77.4% (balanced accuracy=77.9%). A SHAP analysis
of our best models presented behavioral markers that were related to
depression.
  Conclusions: Due to our system's fast and minimalistic nature, it may make a
worthwhile contribution to identifying depression in underdeveloped and
developing regions. In addition, our detailed discussion about the implication
of our findings can facilitate the development of less resource-intensive
systems to better understand students who are depressed.

AI.tldr: A fast, minimalistic app-usage–based ML approach detects depression within 7 days of data, retrieved in about 1 second, achieving around 82% identification of depressed students with interpretable features.
AI.motivation: There is a need for early depression screening that works quickly and with limited data, especially in underdeveloped regions where long-term monitoring is impractical.
AI.method: Collected app-usage data over the past 7 days from 100 Bangladeshi students; developed a fast data retrieval tool (~1 s). Built multiple ML models; used stable feature selection and three FS approaches; employed a light gradient boosting machine (LGBM) with stable features; also built a parsimonious stacking model using around 5 Boruta-selected features per iteration; used SHAP for interpretation.
AI.result: Best LGBM with stable features identified 82.4% of depressed students (precision 75%, F1 78.5%). The stacking model achieved up to 77.4% precision and 77.9% balanced accuracy using Boruta-selected features. SHAP analysis revealed interpretable behavioral markers linked to depression.
AI.conclusion: The fast, minimalistic approach shows potential for depression detection in resource-constrained settings and supports the development of low-cost systems for monitoring student mental health, with implications for early intervention.

title: The AI in the Mirror: LLM Self-Recognition in an Iterated Public Goods Game
summary:
As AI agents become increasingly capable of tool use and long-horizon tasks,
they have begun to be deployed in settings where multiple agents can interact.
However, whereas prior work has mostly focused on human-AI interactions, there
is an increasing need to understand AI-AI interactions. In this paper, we adapt
the iterated public goods game, a classic behavioral economics game, to analyze
the behavior of four reasoning and non-reasoning models across two conditions:
models are either told they are playing against "another AI agent" or told
their opponents are themselves. We find that, across different settings,
telling LLMs that they are playing against themselves significantly changes
their tendency to cooperate. While our study is conducted in a toy environment,
our results may provide insights into multi-agent settings where agents
"unconsciously" discriminating against each other could inexplicably increase
or decrease cooperation.

AI.tldr: Self-referential framing in AI–AI interaction modifies cooperation in an iterated public goods game across four models, revealing dynamics relevant to multi-agent coordination.
AI.motivation: As AI agents increasingly interact, understanding how framing of opponents (AI vs. self) shapes cooperative behavior can illuminate emergent dynamics and potential biases in multi-agent systems.
AI.method: Adapted the iterated public goods game and evaluated four models (representing reasoning and non-reasoning variants) under two conditions: opponents described as 'another AI agent' vs. 'themselves'; measured cooperation across rounds.
AI.result: Framing opponents as themselves significantly changes cooperation tendencies across settings; the direction of change depends on context; effects observed in a toy environment.
AI.conclusion: Findings are exploratory but suggest that AI–AI interactions can exhibit bias-like dynamics affecting cooperation; underscores need for more research in real multi-agent settings.

title: Engineering Automotive Digital Twins on Standardized Architectures: A Case Study
summary:
Digital twin (DT) technology has become of interest in the automotive
industry. There is a growing need for smarter services that utilize the unique
capabilities of DTs, ranging from computer-aided remote control to cloud-based
fleet coordination. Developing such services starts with the software
architecture. However, the scarcity of DT architectural guidelines poses a
challenge for engineering automotive DTs. Currently, the only DT architectural
standard is the one defined in ISO 23247. Though not developed for automotive
systems, it is one of the few feasible starting points for automotive DTs. In
this work, we investigate the suitability of the ISO 23247 reference
architecture for developing automotive DTs. Through the case study of
developing an Adaptive Cruise Control DT for a 1/10\textsuperscript{th}-scale
autonomous vehicle, we identify some strengths and limitations of the reference
architecture and begin distilling future directions for researchers,
practitioners, and standard developers.

AI.tldr: ISO 23247 can serve as a starting point for automotive DT architectures, but its generic nature reveals strengths and gaps for automotive use; a case study on an Adaptive Cruise Control DT highlights practical applicability and points to future directions.
AI.motivation: Address the lack of automotive-specific DT architectural guidelines and assess whether ISO 23247 is suitable for automotive digital twins.
AI.method: Case study applying the ISO 23247 reference architecture to develop an Adaptive Cruise Control digital twin for a 1/10-scale autonomous vehicle, evaluating strengths, limitations, and deriving directions for researchers, practitioners, and standard developers.
AI.result: The study identifies concrete strengths and gaps in the reference architecture when applied to automotive DTs and offers actionable recommendations to extend/adapt ISO 23247 for automotive use; demonstrates feasibility of building an ADC DT within the standard framework.
AI.conclusion: ISO 23247 provides a feasible starting point for automotive DTs but needs automotive-specific extensions; future work should refine guidelines, standardization, and tooling to better support automotive digital twins.

title: SERES: Semantic-aware neural reconstruction from sparse views
summary:
We propose a semantic-aware neural reconstruction method to generate 3D
high-fidelity models from sparse images. To tackle the challenge of severe
radiance ambiguity caused by mismatched features in sparse input, we enrich
neural implicit representations by adding patch-based semantic logits that are
optimized together with the signed distance field and the radiance field. A
novel regularization based on the geometric primitive masks is introduced to
mitigate shape ambiguity. The performance of our approach has been verified in
experimental evaluation. The average chamfer distances of our reconstruction on
the DTU dataset can be reduced by 44% for SparseNeuS and 20% for VolRecon. When
working as a plugin for those dense reconstruction baselines such as NeuS and
Neuralangelo, the average error on the DTU dataset can be reduced by 69% and
68% respectively.

AI.tldr: A semantic-aware neural implicit reconstruction method improves 3D fidelity from sparse images by introducing patch-based semantic logits and a geometric-primitive-mask regularizer, reducing radiance and shape ambiguities. It achieves substantial Chamfer-distance reductions on DTU and enhances dense baselines when used as a plugin.
AI.motivation: Sparse-view 3D reconstruction suffers from radiance ambiguity and shape ambiguity due to mismatched features. Incorporating semantic guidance and geometric priors can help disambiguate radiance and align geometry.
AI.method: Augment neural implicit representations with patch-based semantic logits optimized jointly with the signed distance field and radiance field. Introduce a regularization term based on geometric primitive masks to mitigate shape ambiguity. Evaluate on DTU and as a plugin for dense baselines like NeuS and Neuralangelo.
AI.result: Significant performance gains on the DTU dataset: Chamfer-distance reductions of 44% for SparseNeuS and 20% for VolRecon. As a plugin for NeuS and Neuralangelo, reductions of 69% and 68% respectively.
AI.conclusion: Semantic-aware reconstruction with geometry-prior regularization substantially improves sparse-to-dense 3D reconstruction quality and can meaningfully boost existing dense reconstruction pipelines.

title: Learning Explainable Imaging-Genetics Associations Related to a Neurological Disorder
summary:
While imaging-genetics holds great promise for unraveling the complex
interplay between brain structure and genetic variation in neurological
disorders, traditional methods are limited to simplistic linear models or to
black-box techniques that lack interpretability. In this paper, we present
NeuroPathX, an explainable deep learning framework that uses an early fusion
strategy powered by cross-attention mechanisms to capture meaningful
interactions between structural variations in the brain derived from MRI and
established biological pathways derived from genetics data. To enhance
interpretability and robustness, we introduce two loss functions over the
attention matrix - a sparsity loss that focuses on the most salient
interactions and a pathway similarity loss that enforces consistent
representations across the cohort. We validate NeuroPathX on both autism
spectrum disorder and Alzheimer's disease. Our results demonstrate that
NeuroPathX outperforms competing baseline approaches and reveals biologically
plausible associations linked to the disorder. These findings underscore the
potential of NeuroPathX to advance our understanding of complex brain
disorders. Code is available at https://github.com/jueqiw/NeuroPathX .

AI.tldr: NeuroPathX is an explainable deep learning framework that fuses MRI-derived brain structure variations with genetics-derived pathway representations via cross-attention, using sparsity and pathway-similarity losses to improve interpretability and robustness, and achieving superior performance on autism and Alzheimer's disease.
AI.motivation: To move beyond simplistic linear models and opaque black-box approaches in imaging-genetics by enabling interpretable modeling of interactions between brain structure and genetic pathways through attention-based fusion.
AI.method: An early-fusion deep learning model that uses cross-attention to integrate structural MRI features with pathway-level genetic representations. It imposes a sparsity loss on the attention matrix to emphasize salient interactions and a pathway similarity loss to enforce consistent representations across the cohort. Validated on autism spectrum disorder and Alzheimer's disease datasets; code released.
AI.result: The approach outperforms competing baselines and uncovers biologically plausible associations related to the disorders, demonstrating improved predictive performance and interpretability over existing methods.
AI.conclusion: Explainable cross-modal fusion via attention can capture meaningful brain-genetic interactions, yielding robust, interpretable insights into complex brain disorders and potentially guiding biomedical understanding and discovery.

title: Language Models For Generalised PDDL Planning: Synthesising Sound and Programmatic Policies
comment: RLC 2025 Workshop on Programmatic Reinforcement Learning
summary:
We study the usage of language models (LMs) for planning over world models
specified in the Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL). We prompt LMs to
generate Python programs that serve as generalised policies for solving PDDL
problems from a given domain. Notably, our approach synthesises policies that
are provably sound relative to the PDDL domain without reliance on external
verifiers. We conduct experiments on competition benchmarks which show that our
policies can solve more PDDL problems than PDDL planners and recent LM
approaches within a fixed time and memory constraint. Our approach manifests in
the LMPlan planner which can solve planning problems with several hundreds of
relevant objects. Surprisingly, we observe that LMs used in our framework
sometimes plan more effectively over PDDL problems written in meaningless
symbols in place of natural language; e.g. rewriting (at dog kitchen) as (p2 o1
o3). This finding challenges hypotheses that LMs reason over word semantics and
memorise solutions from its training corpus, and is worth further exploration.

AI.tldr: LMPlan prompts LMs to synthesize Python policies for solving PDDL problems; policies are provably sound relative to the domain and can outperform traditional planners and recent LM methods under fixed resource constraints; scalable to hundreds of objects; reveals robustness to meaningless symbolic inputs, challenging purely semantics-based hypotheses.
AI.motivation: To enable reliable, scalable planning over explicit world models (PDDL) by LM-driven policy synthesis that is provably sound without external verification, addressing efficiency and scalability gaps in conventional PDDL planning.
AI.method: Prompt LMs to generate Python programs implementing generalized policies for PDDL domains; policies are constructed to be sound with respect to the domain without external verifiers; evaluate the LMPlan system on competition benchmarks under fixed time/memory budgets; compare against PDDL planners and recent LM approaches; test on domains with many objects and also probe robustness to symbolic, language-free encodings.
AI.result: Synthesized policies solve more PDDL problems than planners and recent LM approaches within the same resource limits; LMPlan scales to problems with hundreds of objects; LMs sometimes perform better on problems encoded with meaningless symbols, suggesting the planning ability is not solely tied to natural language semantics or training memorization.
AI.conclusion: Policy synthesis from LMs for PDDL planning is a promising approach that can surpass traditional planners under constrained resources; the observed symbol-based planning raises important questions about what LMs actually reason about, motivating further work on symbolic representations and the limits of LM-based planning.

title: Deep Sensorimotor Control by Imitating Predictive Models of Human Motion
summary:
As the embodiment gap between a robot and a human narrows, new opportunities
arise to leverage datasets of humans interacting with their surroundings for
robot learning. We propose a novel technique for training sensorimotor policies
with reinforcement learning by imitating predictive models of human motions.
Our key insight is that the motion of keypoints on human-inspired robot
end-effectors closely mirrors the motion of corresponding human body keypoints.
This enables us to use a model trained to predict future motion on human data
\emph{zero-shot} on robot data. We train sensorimotor policies to track the
predictions of such a model, conditioned on a history of past robot states,
while optimizing a relatively sparse task reward. This approach entirely
bypasses gradient-based kinematic retargeting and adversarial losses, which
limit existing methods from fully leveraging the scale and diversity of modern
human-scene interaction datasets. Empirically, we find that our approach can
work across robots and tasks, outperforming existing baselines by a large
margin. In addition, we find that tracking a human motion model can substitute
for carefully designed dense rewards and curricula in manipulation tasks. Code,
data and qualitative results available at
https://jirl-upenn.github.io/track_reward/.

AI.tldr: Zero-shot sensorimotor policy learning by imitating a human-motion predictor; bypasses retargeting and dense rewards, yielding strong cross-robot performance across tasks.
AI.motivation: Bridging the embodiment gap between humans and robots by leveraging large-scale human motion datasets to train predictive models; avoiding gradient-based retargeting and adversarial losses to better utilize diverse human-scene data.
AI.method: Train a predictive model on human motion data to forecast future motion. Robot end-effector keypoints mirror human keypoints, enabling zero-shot transfer. Train sensorimotor policies to track the model's predictions, conditioned on a history of past robot states, while optimizing a sparse task reward, bypassing explicit retargeting and adversarial training.
AI.result: The approach outperforms existing baselines by a large margin across multiple robots and tasks. Tracking the human-motion model can substitute for dense rewards and curricula in manipulation tasks. Code and data are provided.
AI.conclusion: This framework enables scalable cross-domain sensorimotor learning by reusing human motion models, reducing reliance on retargeting and dense rewards, and enabling robust generalization across robots and tasks.

title: Automated Landfill Detection Using Deep Learning: A Comparative Study of Lightweight and Custom Architectures with the AerialWaste Dataset
summary:
Illegal landfills are posing as a hazardous threat to people all over the
world. Due to the arduous nature of manually identifying the location of
landfill, many landfills go unnoticed by authorities and later cause dangerous
harm to people and environment. Deep learning can play a significant role in
identifying these landfills while saving valuable time, manpower and resources.
Despite being a burning concern, good quality publicly released datasets for
illegal landfill detection are hard to find due to security concerns. However,
AerialWaste Dataset is a large collection of 10434 images of Lombardy region of
Italy. The images are of varying qualities, collected from three different
sources: AGEA Orthophotos, WorldView-3, and Google Earth. The dataset contains
professionally curated, diverse and high-quality images which makes it
particularly suitable for scalable and impactful research. As we trained
several models to compare results, we found complex and heavy models to be
prone to overfitting and memorizing training data instead of learning patterns.
Therefore, we chose lightweight simpler models which could leverage general
features from the dataset. In this study, Mobilenetv2, Googlenet, Densenet,
MobileVit and other lightweight deep learning models were used to train and
validate the dataset as they achieved significant success with less
overfitting. As we saw substantial improvement in the performance using some of
these models, we combined the best performing models and came up with an
ensemble model. With the help of ensemble and fusion technique, binary
classification could be performed on this dataset with 92.33% accuracy, 92.67%
precision, 92.33% sensitivity, 92.41% F1 score and 92.71% specificity.

AI.tldr: Lightweight ensemble of MobileNetV2, GoogLeNet, DenseNet, MobileViT applied to the AerialWaste dataset for illegal landfill detection, achieving about 92% binary classification accuracy with good precision/recall; heavy models overfit, but lightweight models with fusion offer scalable results using public aerial imagery.
AI.motivation: Illegal landfills threaten health and environment; manual identification is labor-intensive and costly; public, diverse datasets are scarce due to security concerns; a lightweight, scalable approach using publicly available aerial imagery is needed.
AI.method: Evaluate several lightweight CNNs (MobileNetV2, GoogLeNet, DenseNet, MobileViT, among others) on the AerialWaste dataset (10,434 images from Lombardy, Italy; sources: AGEA Orthophotos, WorldView-3, Google Earth). Compare single-model performance and an ensemble/fusion approach for binary classification of landfills vs. non-landfills; observe overfitting in heavy models and emphasize generalization.
AI.result: Binary classification achieved 92.33% accuracy, 92.67% precision, 92.33% recall (sensitivity), 92.41% F1 score, and 92.71% specificity on the dataset.
AI.conclusion: Ensembling lightweight models yields strong, generalizable landfill detection performance with reduced overfitting, demonstrating the viability of public aerial datasets for scalable monitoring of illegal landfills.

title: SALMAN: Stability Analysis of Language Models Through the Maps Between Graph-based Manifolds
summary:
Recent strides in pretrained transformer-based language models have propelled
state-of-the-art performance in numerous NLP tasks. Yet, as these models grow
in size and deployment, their robustness under input perturbations becomes an
increasingly urgent question. Existing robustness methods often diverge between
small-parameter and large-scale models (LLMs), and they typically rely on
labor-intensive, sample-specific adversarial designs. In this paper, we propose
a unified, local (sample-level) robustness framework (SALMAN) that evaluates
model stability without modifying internal parameters or resorting to complex
perturbation heuristics. Central to our approach is a novel Distance Mapping
Distortion (DMD) measure, which ranks each sample's susceptibility by comparing
input-to-output distance mappings in a near-linear complexity manner. By
demonstrating significant gains in attack efficiency and robust training, we
position our framework as a practical, model-agnostic tool for advancing the
reliability of transformer-based NLP systems.

AI.tldr: Proposes SALMAN, a model-agnostic, sample-level robustness framework for transformers using Distance Mapping Distortion to judge and improve input perturbation resilience without changing model parameters.
AI.motivation: As NLP transformers scale, robustness under input perturbations becomes critical. Existing methods differ for small vs large models and often require labor-intensive, adversarial perturbations; a unified, lightweight, sample-level approach is needed.
