AI.method: Introduce SALMAN, a local robustness framework that evaluates stability at the sample level without modifying internal parameters or relying on complex perturbations. It centers on Distance Mapping Distortion (DMD), which ranks each sample’s susceptibility by comparing input-to-output distance mappings with near-linear computational complexity.
AI.result: Demonstrates improved attack efficiency and more effective robust training, showing SALMAN as a practical, model-agnostic tool for enhancing the reliability of transformer-based NLP systems.
AI.conclusion: SALMAN provides a practical, model-agnostic framework for assessing and improving robustness of transformer-based NLP models without altering their parameters.

title: Weisfeiler-Leman Features for Planning: A 1,000,000 Sample Size Hyperparameter Study
summary:
Weisfeiler-Leman Features (WLFs) are a recently introduced classical machine
learning tool for learning to plan and search. They have been shown to be both
theoretically and empirically superior to existing deep learning approaches for
learning value functions for search in symbolic planning. In this paper, we
introduce new WLF hyperparameters and study their various tradeoffs and
effects. We utilise the efficiency of WLFs and run planning experiments on
single core CPUs with a sample size of 1,000,000 to understand the effect of
hyperparameters on training and planning. Our experimental analysis show that
there is a robust and best set of hyperparameters for WLFs across the tested
planning domains. We find that the best WLF hyperparameters for learning
heuristic functions minimise execution time rather than maximise model
expressivity. We further statistically analyse and observe no significant
correlation between training and planning metrics.

AI.tldr: New Weisfeiler-Leman features (WLFs) with extra hyperparameters; large-scale experiments show the best hyperparameters minimize execution time and are robust across domains; no strong correlation between training and planning metrics; WLFs outperform DL baselines for learning planning value functions.
AI.motivation: Understand how WLF hyperparameters affect training efficiency, planning performance, and the trade-off between model expressivity and runtime in symbolic planning.
AI.method: Introduce new WLF hyperparameters and perform planning experiments on single-core CPUs with 1,000,000 samples across several planning domains; analyze effects on training and planning metrics.
AI.result: A robust best hyperparameter set exists across tested domains; optimizing for planning runtime yields better results than maximizing model expressivity; no significant correlation between training and planning metrics.
AI.conclusion: Hyperparameters for WLFs should prioritize reducing execution time; WLFs provide robust, efficient performance for learning heuristic/value functions in symbolic planning, with results empirically supporting the approach.

title: AgriChrono: A Multi-modal Dataset Capturing Crop Growth and Lighting Variability with a Field Robot
summary:
Existing datasets for precision agriculture have primarily been collected in
static or controlled environments such as indoor labs or greenhouses, often
with limited sensor diversity and restricted temporal span. These conditions
fail to reflect the dynamic nature of real farmland, including illumination
changes, crop growth variation, and natural disturbances. As a result, models
trained on such data often lack robustness and generalization when applied to
real-world field scenarios. In this paper, we present AgriChrono, a novel
robotic data collection platform and multi-modal dataset designed to capture
the dynamic conditions of real-world agricultural environments. Our platform
integrates multiple sensors and enables remote, time-synchronized acquisition
of RGB, Depth, LiDAR, and IMU data, supporting efficient and repeatable
long-term data collection across varying illumination and crop growth stages.
We benchmark a range of state-of-the-art 3D reconstruction models on the
AgriChrono dataset, highlighting the difficulty of reconstruction in real-world
field environments and demonstrating its value as a research asset for
advancing model generalization under dynamic conditions. The code and dataset
are publicly available at: https://github.com/StructuresComp/agri-chrono

AI.tldr: AgriChrono introduces a dynamic, multi-modal field dataset and robotic collection platform to study robustness of 3D reconstruction under real-world farming conditions.
AI.motivation: Existing datasets are static or lab-based and fail to reflect real farmland variability in illumination, growth, and disturbances; there is a need for datasets that support robust generalization to dynamic agricultural environments.
AI.method: Design of AgriChrono: a robotic platform that collects synchronized RGB, Depth, LiDAR, and IMU data; enables long-term, time-synchronized data collection across varying illumination and crop growth stages; includes benchmarking of state-of-the-art 3D reconstruction models on the dataset.
AI.result: Reconstruction in real-world field conditions remains challenging; AgriChrono exposes domain gaps and provides a benchmark to drive improvements in model generalization under dynamic agricultural conditions.
AI.conclusion: The dataset and platform offer a publicly accessible resource to advance robust perception in precision agriculture, encouraging development of generalizable models; code and dataset are publicly available.

title: Structures Meet Semantics: Multimodal Fusion via Graph Contrastive Learning
summary:
Multimodal sentiment analysis (MSA) aims to infer emotional states by
effectively integrating textual, acoustic, and visual modalities. Despite
notable progress, existing multimodal fusion methods often neglect
modality-specific structural dependencies and semantic misalignment, limiting
their quality, interpretability, and robustness. To address these challenges,
we propose a novel framework called the Structural-Semantic Unifier (SSU),
which systematically integrates modality-specific structural information and
cross-modal semantic grounding for enhanced multimodal representations.
Specifically, SSU dynamically constructs modality-specific graphs by leveraging
linguistic syntax for text and a lightweight, text-guided attention mechanism
for acoustic and visual modalities, thus capturing detailed intra-modal
relationships and semantic interactions. We further introduce a semantic
anchor, derived from global textual semantics, that serves as a cross-modal
alignment hub, effectively harmonizing heterogeneous semantic spaces across
modalities. Additionally, we develop a multiview contrastive learning objective
that promotes discriminability, semantic consistency, and structural coherence
across intra- and inter-modal views. Extensive evaluations on two widely used
benchmark datasets, CMU-MOSI and CMU-MOSEI, demonstrate that SSU consistently
achieves state-of-the-art performance while significantly reducing
computational overhead compared to prior methods. Comprehensive qualitative
analyses further validate SSU's interpretability and its ability to capture
nuanced emotional patterns through semantically grounded interactions.

AI.tldr: A Structural-Semantic Unifier (SSU) for multimodal sentiment analysis that fuses modality-specific structures with cross-modal semantic grounding, achieving state-of-the-art results with lower computation and better interpretability.
AI.motivation: To overcome modality-specific structural dependencies and semantic misalignment that limit performance, robustness, and interpretability in existing MSA methods.
AI.method: Builds modality-specific graphs (text via linguistic syntax; acoustic/visual via text-guided attention), introduces a semantic anchor as a cross-modal semantic hub, and employs a multiview contrastive objective to enforce discriminability and coherence across intra- and inter-modal views.
AI.result: SSU achieves state-of-the-art performance on CMU-MOSI and CMU-MOSEI and reduces computational overhead; qualitative analyses support interpretability and nuanced emotional pattern capture.
AI.conclusion: Integrating structural cues with semantic grounding yields robust, interpretable multimodal representations for sentiment analysis, with potential efficiency and generalizability benefits.

title: Learning Spatio-Temporal Dynamics via Operator-Valued RKHS and Kernel Koopman Methods
summary:
We introduce a unified framework for learning the spatio-temporal dynamics of
vector valued functions by combining operator valued reproducing kernel Hilbert
spaces (OV-RKHS) with kernel based Koopman operator methods. The approach
enables nonparametric and data driven estimation of complex time evolving
vector fields while preserving both spatial and temporal structure. We
establish representer theorems for time dependent OV-RKHS interpolation, derive
Sobolev type approximation bounds for smooth vector fields, and provide
spectral convergence guarantees for kernel Koopman operator approximations.
This framework supports efficient reduced order modeling and long term
prediction of high dimensional nonlinear systems, offering theoretically
grounded tools for forecasting, control, and uncertainty quantification in
spatio-temporal machine learning.

AI.tldr: A unified, nonparametric framework that blends operator-valued RKHS with kernel Koopman methods to learn spatio-temporal vector-field dynamics, with representer theorems, Sobolev-type bounds, and spectral convergence for reliable long-horizon prediction and reduced-order modeling.
AI.motivation: Modeling time-evolving, high-dimensional vector-valued fields is challenging due to nonlinear dynamics and the need to preserve spatial/temporal structure. Existing parametric or scalar-embedded approaches struggle with structure preservation and guarantees. The work proposes a nonparametric framework combining OV-RKHS and kernel Koopman to enable data-driven, provably consistent learning of spatio-temporal dynamics.
AI.method: Introduce a unified OV-RKHS framework and couple it with kernel-based Koopman operator theory. Establish representer theorems for time-dependent OV-RKHS interpolation, derive Sobolev-type approximation bounds for smooth vector fields, and provide spectral convergence guarantees for kernel Koopman approximations, enabling efficient reduced-order modeling and long-term prediction.
AI.result: The paper provides theoretical guarantees: representer theorems, Sobolev-type approximation bounds, and spectral convergence guarantees for kernel Koopman operator approximations, forming a scalable, nonparametric toolset for forecasting, control, and uncertainty quantification in spatio-temporal ML.
AI.conclusion: By uniting OV-RKHS with kernel Koopman methods, the framework delivers a theoretically grounded, nonparametric approach for forecasting and controlling high-dimensional spatio-temporal systems, with robust convergence guarantees and applicability to uncertainty quantification and ROM in spatio-temporal machine learning.

title: Symmetry-Invariant Novelty Heuristics via Unsupervised Weisfeiler-Leman Features
summary:
Novelty heuristics aid heuristic search by exploring states that exhibit
novel atoms. However, novelty heuristics are not symmetry invariant and hence
may sometimes lead to redundant exploration. In this preliminary report, we
propose to use Weisfeiler-Leman Features for planning (WLFs) in place of atoms
for detecting novelty. WLFs are recently introduced features for learning
domain-dependent heuristics for generalised planning problems. We explore an
unsupervised usage of WLFs for synthesising lifted, domain-independent novelty
heuristics that are invariant to symmetric states. Experiments on the classical
International Planning Competition and Hard To Ground benchmark suites yield
promising results for novelty heuristics synthesised from WLFs.

AI.tldr: Using Weisfeiler-Leman Features (WLFs) as a symmetry-invariant replacement for atoms, to synthesize lifted novelty heuristics for planning; experiments show promising gains on IPC and Hard To Ground benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Standard novelty heuristics are not symmetry-invariant and can cause redundant exploration. By making novelty detection invariant to symmetries, planning efficiency can be improved.
AI.method: Replace atom-based novelty with WLFs for planning features. Unsurprisingly, synthesize lifted, domain-independent novelty heuristics using WLFs in an unsupervised manner. Evaluate the resulting heuristics on classical IPC and Hard To Ground benchmarks.
AI.result: Experiments yield promising results for novelty heuristics synthesized from WLFs.
AI.conclusion: Weaker symmetry-induced redundancy can be mitigated by WLF-based novelty, indicating that WLFs are a promising direction for domain-independent, symmetry-invariant planning heuristics; further work could extend and validate across more domains.

title: Enhancing Video-Based Robot Failure Detection Using Task Knowledge
summary:
Robust robotic task execution hinges on the reliable detection of execution
failures in order to trigger safe operation modes, recovery strategies, or task
replanning. However, many failure detection methods struggle to provide
meaningful performance when applied to a variety of real-world scenarios. In
this paper, we propose a video-based failure detection approach that uses
spatio-temporal knowledge in the form of the actions the robot performs and
task-relevant objects within the field of view. Both pieces of information are
available in most robotic scenarios and can thus be readily obtained. We
demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on three datasets that we amend,
in part, with additional annotations of the aforementioned task-relevant
knowledge. In light of the results, we also propose a data augmentation method
that improves performance by applying variable frame rates to different parts
of the video. We observe an improvement from 77.9 to 80.0 in F1 score on the
ARMBench dataset without additional computational expense and an additional
increase to 81.4 with test-time augmentation. The results emphasize the
importance of spatio-temporal information during failure detection and suggest
further investigation of suitable heuristics in future implementations. Code
and annotations are available.

AI.tldr: Video-based failure detection leverages spatio-temporal cues (robot actions and task-relevant objects) to improve robustness across real-world scenarios; data augmentation via variable frame rates and test-time augmentation yield modest F1 gains on ARMBench; code and annotations released.
AI.motivation: Reliable failure detection is critical for safe and robust robotic task execution, but existing methods struggle with real-world variability. The authors propose to exploit readily available spatio-temporal information (executed actions and in-frame task-relevant objects) to enhance detection performance.
AI.method: Propose a video-based failure detection approach that uses spatio-temporal knowledge in the form of the robot actions and task-relevant objects in view. They amend three datasets with additional annotations of this information. They introduce a data augmentation method that applies variable frame rates to different parts of the video. They report results on ARMBench with and without test-time augmentation.
AI.result: On ARMBench, F1 improved from 77.9 to 80.0 with their augmentation, and to 81.4 with test-time augmentation (no extra computational cost for the first augmentation). They demonstrate the value of spatio-temporal information and provide code and annotations for reproducibility.
AI.conclusion: Spatio-temporal information about actions and objects improves failure detection; variable frame-rate augmentation and test-time augmentation offer performance gains. The work encourages further exploration of heuristics and richer annotations for robust real-world deployment; code and annotations are released.

title: FastAvatar: Instant 3D Gaussian Splatting for Faces from Single Unconstrained Poses
summary:
We present FastAvatar, a pose-invariant, feed-forward framework that can
generate a 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) model from a single face image from an
arbitrary pose in near-instant time (<10ms). FastAvatar uses a novel
encoder-decoder neural network design to achieve both fast fitting and identity
preservation regardless of input pose. First, FastAvatar constructs a 3DGS face
``template'' model from a training dataset of faces with multi-view captures.
Second, FastAvatar encodes the input face image into an identity-specific and
pose-invariant latent embedding, and decodes this embedding to predict
residuals to the structural and appearance parameters of each Gaussian in the
template 3DGS model. By only inferring residuals in a feed-forward fashion,
model inference is fast and robust. FastAvatar significantly outperforms
existing feed-forward face 3DGS methods (e.g., GAGAvatar) in reconstruction
quality, and runs 1000x faster than per-face optimization methods (e.g.,
FlashAvatar, GaussianAvatars and GASP). In addition, FastAvatar's novel latent
space design supports real-time identity interpolation and attribute editing
which is not possible with any existing feed-forward 3DGS face generation
framework. FastAvatar's combination of excellent reconstruction quality and
speed expands the scope of 3DGS for photorealistic avatar applications in
consumer and interactive systems.

AI.tldr: FastAvatar is a fast feed-forward method that converts a single face image into a 3D Gaussian Splatting model across arbitrary poses in under 10 ms, using a template + residuals decoder; achieves higher quality than prior feed-forward 3DGS methods and ~1000x faster than optimization-based methods, enabling real-time identity interpolation and attribute editing.
AI.motivation: The need for real-time, pose-invariant, identity-preserving 3D face reconstruction from a single image; existing methods are either slow optimization-based or lack fidelity and editability in feed-forward approaches.
AI.method: Build a multi-view-trained 3DGS template; train an encoder to produce identity-specific, pose-invariant latent embedding; decode to residuals for the Gaussian parameters; only residuals inferred in feed-forward pass; enabling fast, robust inference; allows identity interpolation and attribute editing.
AI.result: Outperforms existing feed-forward 3DGS methods (e.g., GAGAvatar) in reconstruction quality; ~1000x speedup over per-face optimization methods (FlashAvatar, GaussianAvatars, GASP); enables real-time identity interpolation and attribute editing; expands photorealistic avatar applications.
AI.conclusion: FastAvatar delivers near-instant, pose-invariant, high-quality 3D face reconstruction with editability, broadening use in consumer and interactive systems.

title: CoPE: A Lightweight Complex Positional Encoding
summary:
Recent studies have demonstrated the effectiveness of position encoding in
transformer architectures. By incorporating positional information, this
approach provides essential guidance for modeling dependencies between elements
across different sequence positions. We introduce CoPE (a lightweight Complex
Positional Encoding), a novel architecture that leverages complex-valued
encoding to encode both content and positional information. Our approach
replaces traditional positional encodings with complex embeddings where the
real part captures semantic content and the imaginary part encodes positional
information. We introduce phase-aware attention in the first layer of the
transformer model to capture position-dependent patterns, followed by standard
attention layers for higher-levels. We show that CoPE doesn't exhibit long term
decay and is compatible with linear attention. Experimental evaluation on the
GLUE benchmark suggest that our approach achieves superior performance with
less computational complexity, compared to RoPE, Sinusoidal and Learned
positional encodings.

AI.tldr: CoPE introduces a complex-valued positional encoding for transformers, combining content (real part) and position (imaginary part) with phase-aware attention in the first layer; claims no long-term decay and compatibility with linear attention, achieving superior GLUE performance with lower computational cost than RoPE, sinusoidal, and learned encodings.
AI.motivation: To overcome limitations of standard positional encodings by encoding both semantic content and positional information in a single complex embedding, enabling position-aware modeling with potential efficiency benefits.
AI.method: Replace traditional positional encodings with complex-valued embeddings where the real part encodes content and the imaginary part encodes position; add phase-aware attention in the first Transformer layer to capture position-dependent patterns, followed by standard attention layers; designed to avoid long-term decay and to be compatible with linear attention.
AI.result: On GLUE, CoPE achieves superior performance with lower computational complexity compared to RoPE, sinusoidal, and learned positional encodings, and  exhibits no long-term decay of positional information.
AI.conclusion: CoPE provides a lightweight, decay-free complex-valued positional encoding that integrates content and position, is compatible with linear attention, and improves Transformer performance on GLUE.

title: Generic Guard AI in Stealth Game with Composite Potential Fields
summary:
Guard patrol behavior is central to the immersion and strategic depth of
stealth games, while most existing systems rely on hand-crafted routes or
specialized logic that struggle to balance coverage efficiency and responsive
pursuit with believable naturalness. We propose a generic, fully explainable,
training-free framework that integrates global knowledge and local information
via Composite Potential Fields, combining three interpretable maps-Information,
Confidence, and Connectivity-into a single kernel-filtered decision criterion.
Our parametric, designer-driven approach requires only a handful of decay and
weight parameters-no retraining-to smoothly adapt across both occupancy-grid
and NavMesh-partition abstractions. We evaluate on five representative game
maps, two player-control policies, and five guard modes, confirming that our
method outperforms classical baseline methods in both capture efficiency and
patrol naturalness. Finally, we show how common stealth mechanics-distractions
and environmental elements-integrate naturally into our framework as sub
modules, enabling rapid prototyping of rich, dynamic, and responsive guard
behaviors.

AI.tldr: A training-free, explainable guard-patrol framework using Composite Potential Fields that fuses Information, Confidence, and Connectivity maps into a single kernel-filtered decision criterion; adaptable across occupancy-grid and NavMesh; parameter-tuned by designers; outperforms baselines on efficiency and naturalness; supports modular integration of distractions and environmental elements for rapid prototyping.
AI.motivation: Stealth games require patrol systems that are both efficient (maximize coverage and capture rate) and believable (natural patrols), without brittle hand-crafted routes or heavy bespoke logic. A generic, explainable, training-free approach that blends global and local information across representations is needed.
AI.method: Introduce Composite Potential Fields (CPF) consisting of three interpretable maps — Information, Confidence, and Connectivity — merged into a kernel-filtered decision criterion. The framework is parametric and designer-driven, requiring only decay and weight parameters; no retraining; works across occupancy-grid and NavMesh abstractions; supports modular addition of distractions and environmental elements as submodules.
AI.result: Evaluation across five maps, two player-control policies, and five guard modes shows superior performance to classical baselines in capture efficiency and patrol naturalness.
AI.conclusion: The framework offers a generic, explainable, training-free solution for guard behavior that generalizes across representations and supports rapid prototyping of dynamic, responsive behavior, with natural integration of stealth mechanics; future work could explore parameter tuning strategies, scalability, and potential learning-based extensions that preserve the training-free nature.

title: HyperTASR: Hypernetwork-Driven Task-Aware Scene Representations for Robust Manipulation
summary:
Effective policy learning for robotic manipulation requires scene
representations that selectively capture task-relevant environmental features.
Current approaches typically employ task-agnostic representation extraction,
failing to emulate the dynamic perceptual adaptation observed in human
cognition. We present HyperTASR, a hypernetwork-driven framework that modulates
scene representations based on both task objectives and the execution phase.
Our architecture dynamically generates representation transformation parameters
conditioned on task specifications and progression state, enabling
representations to evolve contextually throughout task execution. This approach
maintains architectural compatibility with existing policy learning frameworks
while fundamentally reconfiguring how visual features are processed. Unlike
methods that simply concatenate or fuse task embeddings with task-agnostic
representations, HyperTASR establishes computational separation between
task-contextual and state-dependent processing paths, enhancing learning
efficiency and representational quality. Comprehensive evaluations in both
simulation and real-world environments demonstrate substantial performance
improvements across different representation paradigms. Through ablation
studies and attention visualization, we confirm that our approach selectively
prioritizes task-relevant scene information, closely mirroring human adaptive
perception during manipulation tasks. The project website is at
\href{https://lisunphil.github.io/HyperTASR_projectpage/}{lisunphil.github.io/HyperTASR\_projectpage}.

AI.tldr: HyperTASR uses a hypernetwork to adapt scene representations during robotic manipulation based on task and execution phase, creating task-contextual processing paths that improve learning efficiency and representation quality, validated across simulation and real-world tasks with ablations and attention visualizations.
AI.motivation: Current task-agnostic representations fall short of human-like selective perception; effective policy learning requires representations that adapt to task objectives and task progression during execution.
AI.method: A hypernetwork generates representation transformation parameters conditioned on task specifications and progression state, enabling dynamic reformulation of features. It maintains compatibility with existing policy learning frameworks while separating task-contextual and state-dependent processing paths rather than simple feature fusion.
AI.result: Across multiple representation paradigms, the approach yields substantial performance improvements. Ablation studies show the necessity of task-contextual processing; attention visualizations indicate the model focuses on task-relevant scene information. Evaluations were conducted in both simulation and real-world environments.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, task-aware representations enable more efficient learning and better manipulation performance; the approach generalizes across representation types and tasks and aligns with human-like adaptive perception during manipulation.

title: Securing Face and Fingerprint Templates in Humanitarian Biometric Systems
summary:
In humanitarian and emergency scenarios, the use of biometrics can
dramatically improve the efficiency of operations, but it poses risks for the
data subjects, which are exacerbated in contexts of vulnerability. To address
this, we present a mobile biometric system implementing a biometric template
protection (BTP) scheme suitable for these scenarios. After rigorously
formulating the functional, operational, and security and privacy requirements
of these contexts, we perform a broad comparative analysis of the BTP
landscape. PolyProtect, a method designed to operate on neural network face
embeddings, is identified as the most suitable method due to its effectiveness,
modularity, and lightweight computational burden. We evaluate PolyProtect in
terms of verification and identification accuracy, irreversibility, and
unlinkability, when this BTP method is applied to face embeddings extracted
using EdgeFace, a novel state-of-the-art efficient feature extractor, on a
real-world face dataset from a humanitarian field project in Ethiopia.
Moreover, as PolyProtect promises to be modality-independent, we extend its
evaluation to fingerprints. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first
time that PolyProtect has been evaluated for the identification scenario and
for fingerprint biometrics. Our experimental results are promising, and we plan
to release our code

AI.tldr: Proposes a privacy-preserving mobile biometric system using PolyProtect on face embeddings, extended to fingerprints, evaluated in humanitarian contexts; promising privacy and performance with plan to release code.
AI.motivation: Balance biometric utility in emergencies with strong privacy protections for vulnerable populations; address BTP in challenging deployment settings.
AI.method: Formulate requirements for BTP in humanitarian contexts; comparative landscape analysis; identify PolyProtect as best option; apply to EdgeFace face embeddings on Ethiopian dataset; extend to fingerprints; assess verification, identification, irreversibility, unlinkability.
AI.result: PolyProtect shows favorable accuracy and privacy properties; modular and lightweight; successful application to face embeddings; feasible extension to fingerprints; first identification and fingerprint evaluation; code to be released.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates viability of BTP-based biometrics in humanitarian scenarios; PolyProtect is a strong candidate; provides a path toward privacy-preserving, deployable biometric systems; further validation and code release anticipated.

title: What Matters in Data for DPO?
summary:
Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) has emerged as a simple and effective
approach for aligning large language models (LLMs) with human preferences,
bypassing the need for a learned reward model. Despite its growing adoption, a
fundamental question remains open: what characteristics of preference data are
most critical for DPO performance? In this work, we provide a systematic study
of how preference data distribution influences DPO, from both theoretical and
empirical perspectives. We show that the quality of chosen responses plays a
dominant role in optimizing the DPO objective, while the quality of rejected
responses may have relatively limited impact. Our theoretical analysis
characterizes the optimal response distribution under DPO and reveals how
contrastiveness between responses helps primarily by improving the chosen
samples. We further study an online DPO setting and show it effectively reduces
to supervised fine-tuning on the chosen responses. Extensive experiments across
diverse tasks confirm our findings: improving the quality of chosen responses
consistently boosts performance regardless of the quality of the rejected
responses. We also investigate the benefit of mixing the on-policy data. Our
results interpret the mechanism behind some widely adopted strategies and offer
practical insights for constructing high-impact preference datasets for LLM
alignment.

AI.tldr: DPO performance is driven mainly by the quality of chosen responses; rejected-response quality has limited impact; contrastiveness helps primarily by improving chosen samples; online DPO effectively reduces to supervised fine-tuning on the chosen responses; mixing on-policy data can be beneficial; provides practical guidance for constructing high-impact preference datasets.
AI.motivation: To understand which characteristics of human preference data are most critical for DPO, addressing a gap between theory and practice in LLM alignment.
AI.method: Theoretical characterization of the optimal response distribution under DPO; analysis of how contrastiveness affects learning; extension to online DPO showing it reduces to supervised fine-tuning on chosen responses; extensive empirical experiments across diverse tasks; examination of mixing on-policy data.
AI.result: Quality of chosen responses dominates performance; the quality of rejected responses has limited effect; contrastiveness improves learning mainly by aiding the chosen samples; online DPO behaves like supervised fine-tuning on chosen responses; mixing on-policy data yields benefits; findings align with and explain practical data-collection strategies.
AI.conclusion: Provides practical guidelines for constructing impactful preference datasets for LLM alignment and clarifies the mechanisms behind common strategies used in DPO and preference-based optimization.

title: A Database-Driven Framework for 3D Level Generation with LLMs
summary:
Procedural Content Generation for 3D game levels faces challenges in
balancing spatial coherence, navigational functionality, and adaptable gameplay
progression across multi-floor environments. This paper introduces a novel
framework for generating such levels, centered on the offline, LLM-assisted
construction of reusable databases for architectural components (facilities and
room templates) and gameplay mechanic elements. Our multi-phase pipeline
assembles levels by: (1) selecting and arranging instances from the Room
Database to form a multi-floor global structure with an inherent topological
order; (2) optimizing the internal layout of facilities for each room based on
predefined constraints from the Facility Database; and (3) integrating
progression-based gameplay mechanics by placing components from a Mechanics
Database according to their topological and spatial rules. A subsequent
two-phase repair system ensures navigability. This approach combines modular,
database-driven design with constraint-based optimization, allowing for
systematic control over level structure and the adaptable pacing of gameplay
elements. Initial experiments validate the framework's ability in generating
diverse, navigable 3D environments and its capability to simulate distinct
gameplay pacing strategies through simple parameterization. This research
advances PCG by presenting a scalable, database-centric foundation for the
automated generation of complex 3D levels with configurable gameplay
progression.

AI.tldr: Database-driven, LLM-assisted PCG framework for multi-floor 3D game levels using Room, Facility, and Mechanics databases; three-phase layout plus two-phase repair; configurable pacing; initial experiments show navigable diversity.
AI.motivation: Address balancing spatial coherence, navigational functionality, and adaptable gameplay progression in multi-floor 3D levels; achieve scalability and configurability through modular databases and constraint-based optimization.
AI.method: Offline construction of reusable databases for rooms, facilities, and mechanics; a three-phase pipeline to (1) form a global multi-floor structure with topological order, (2) optimize internal room layouts using facility constraints, and (3) integrate mechanics with topological/spatial rules; followed by a two-phase repair to ensure navigability; parameterizable to simulate pacing.
AI.result: Initial experiments validate the framework's ability to generate diverse, navigable 3D environments and to simulate distinct gameplay pacing strategies through simple parameterization.
AI.conclusion: Presents a scalable, database-centric foundation for automated generation of complex 3D levels with configurable gameplay progression, advancing PCG in modular, constraint-driven level design.

title: Learning Real-World Acrobatic Flight from Human Preferences
summary:
Preference-based reinforcement learning (PbRL) enables agents to learn
control policies without requiring manually designed reward functions, making
it well-suited for tasks where objectives are difficult to formalize or
inherently subjective. Acrobatic flight poses a particularly challenging
problem due to its complex dynamics, rapid movements, and the importance of
precise execution. In this work, we explore the use of PbRL for agile drone
control, focusing on the execution of dynamic maneuvers such as powerloops.
Building on Preference-based Proximal Policy Optimization (Preference PPO), we
propose Reward Ensemble under Confidence (REC), an extension to the reward
learning objective that improves preference modeling and learning stability.
Our method achieves 88.4% of the shaped reward performance, compared to 55.2%
with standard Preference PPO. We train policies in simulation and successfully
transfer them to real-world drones, demonstrating multiple acrobatic maneuvers
where human preferences emphasize stylistic qualities of motion. Furthermore,
we demonstrate the applicability of our probabilistic reward model in a
representative MuJoCo environment for continuous control. Finally, we highlight
the limitations of manually designed rewards, observing only 60.7% agreement
with human preferences. These results underscore the effectiveness of PbRL in
capturing complex, human-centered objectives across both physical and simulated
domains.

AI.tldr: REC enhances Preference PPO for PbRL in agile drone control, achieving strong sim-to-real transfer and highlighting the limits of manually designed rewards.
AI.motivation: PbRL avoids hand-crafted rewards, which is crucial for subjective, high-speed maneuvers like acrobatics. Drone control presents complex dynamics and the need for stable learning when objectives include stylistic quality and safety.
AI.method: Extend Preference PPO with Reward Ensemble under Confidence (REC) to improve reward learning; incorporate a probabilistic reward model; evaluate in simulation with transfer to real drones, and in MuJoCo for continuous control; assess against human preferences and compare to shaped rewards.
AI.result: REC achieves 88.4% of shaped reward performance versus 55.2% for standard Preference PPO; successful sim-to-real transfer showing multiple acrobatic maneuvers; probabilistic reward model validated in MuJoCo; manual rewards show only 60.7% agreement with human preferences.
AI.conclusion: PbRL with REC effectively captures complex, human-centered objectives across physical and simulated domains. REC improves reward modeling and learning stability; manual reward design is limited in aligning with human preferences.

title: Why Relational Graphs Will Save the Next Generation of Vision Foundation Models?
summary:
Vision foundation models (FMs) have become the predominant architecture in
computer vision, providing highly transferable representations learned from
large-scale, multimodal corpora. Nonetheless, they exhibit persistent
limitations on tasks that require explicit reasoning over entities, roles, and
spatio-temporal relations. Such relational competence is indispensable for
fine-grained human activity recognition, egocentric video understanding, and
multimodal medical image analysis, where spatial, temporal, and semantic
dependencies are decisive for performance. We advance the position that
next-generation FMs should incorporate explicit relational interfaces,
instantiated as dynamic relational graphs (graphs whose topology and edge
semantics are inferred from the input and task context). We illustrate this
position with cross-domain evidence from recent systems in human manipulation
action recognition and brain tumor segmentation, showing that augmenting FMs
with lightweight, context-adaptive graph-reasoning modules improves
fine-grained semantic fidelity, out of distribution robustness,
interpretability, and computational efficiency relative to FM only baselines.
Importantly, by reasoning sparsely over semantic nodes, such hybrids also
achieve favorable memory and hardware efficiency, enabling deployment under
practical resource constraints. We conclude with a targeted research agenda for
FM graph hybrids, prioritizing learned dynamic graph construction, multi-level
relational reasoning (e.g., part object scene in activity understanding, or
region organ in medical imaging), cross-modal fusion, and evaluation protocols
that directly probe relational competence in structured vision tasks.

AI.tldr: Integrating dynamic relational graphs with vision foundation models improves relational understanding and efficiency for structured vision tasks.
AI.motivation: Vision foundation models excel at broad representations but struggle with explicit reasoning about entities, relations, and spatio-temporal structure. This relational competence is vital for fine-grained human activity recognition, egocentric video, and multimodal medical imaging. The paper advocates augmenting FMs with explicit, dynamic graphs that adapt to input and task context.
AI.method: Proposes lightweight, context-adaptive graph-reasoning modules that operate over dynamic graphs whose topology and edge semantics are inferred from the input. Demonstrates cross-domain evidence from human manipulation action recognition and brain tumor segmentation, showing that graph hybrids with FMs improve semantic fidelity, robustness, interpretability, and efficiency compared with FM-only baselines.
AI.result: Relational graph hybrids yield better fine-grained performance, improved OOD robustness, and enhanced interpretability, with reduced memory and computation due to sparse, targeted graph reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Urges a research agenda for FM-graph hybrids: (i) learned dynamic graph construction; (ii) multi-level relational reasoning (e.g., part–object–scene, region–organ); (iii) cross-modal fusion; (iv) evaluation protocols that directly probe relational competence in structured vision tasks.

title: ProtoEHR: Hierarchical Prototype Learning for EHR-based Healthcare Predictions
summary:
Digital healthcare systems have enabled the collection of mass healthcare
data in electronic healthcare records (EHRs), allowing artificial intelligence
solutions for various healthcare prediction tasks. However, existing studies
often focus on isolated components of EHR data, limiting their predictive
performance and interpretability. To address this gap, we propose ProtoEHR, an
interpretable hierarchical prototype learning framework that fully exploits the
rich, multi-level structure of EHR data to enhance healthcare predictions. More
specifically, ProtoEHR models relationships within and across three
hierarchical levels of EHRs: medical codes, hospital visits, and patients. We
first leverage large language models to extract semantic relationships among
medical codes and construct a medical knowledge graph as the knowledge source.
Building on this, we design a hierarchical representation learning framework
that captures contextualized representations across three levels, while
incorporating prototype information within each level to capture intrinsic
similarities and improve generalization. To perform a comprehensive assessment,
we evaluate ProtoEHR in two public datasets on five clinically significant
tasks, including prediction of mortality, prediction of readmission, prediction
of length of stay, drug recommendation, and prediction of phenotype. The
results demonstrate the ability of ProtoEHR to make accurate, robust, and
interpretable predictions compared to baselines in the literature. Furthermore,
ProtoEHR offers interpretable insights on code, visit, and patient levels to
aid in healthcare prediction.

AI.tldr: ProtoEHR is an interpretable hierarchical prototype learning framework for EHR data that captures relationships across codes, visits, and patients via a medical knowledge graph and prototypes, enabling accurate and interpretable predictions across multiple tasks.
AI.motivation: Current EHR-based approaches largely model isolated components, limiting predictive performance and interpretability; there is a need to exploit multi-level EHR structure and semantic code relations.
AI.method: Construct a medical knowledge graph by applying LLMs to derive semantic relationships among codes; build a hierarchical representation learning framework across codes, visits, and patients; incorporate prototypes at each level to capture intrinsic similarities and improve generalization; evaluate on two public datasets for five tasks (mortality, readmission, length of stay, drug recommendation, phenotype).
AI.result: ProtoEHR demonstrates accurate, robust, and interpretable predictions compared to baselines, with interpretability at code, visit, and patient levels providing insights aligned with clinical reasoning.
AI.conclusion: Leveraging multi-level EHR structure and prototype-based representations can enhance predictive performance and interpretability, offering actionable insights for clinicians and healthcare systems.

title: SchemaCoder: Automatic Log Schema Extraction Coder with Residual Q-Tree Boosting
comment: 18 pages, 16 figures, under review for AAAI2026
summary:
Log schema extraction is the process of deriving human-readable templates
from massive volumes of log data, which is essential yet notoriously
labor-intensive. Recent studies have attempted to streamline this task by
leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) for automated schema extraction.
However, existing methods invariably rely on predefined regular expressions,
necessitating human domain expertise and severely limiting productivity gains.
To fundamentally address this limitation, we introduce SchemaCoder, the first
fully automated schema extraction framework applicable to a wide range of log
file formats without requiring human customization within the flow. At its
core, SchemaCoder features a novel Residual Question-Tree (Q-Tree) Boosting
mechanism that iteratively refines schema extraction through targeted, adaptive
queries driven by LLMs. Particularly, our method partitions logs into semantic
chunks via context-bounded segmentation, selects representative patterns using
embedding-based sampling, and generates schema code through hierarchical
Q-Tree-driven LLM queries, iteratively refined by our textual-residual
evolutionary optimizer and residual boosting. Experimental validation
demonstrates SchemaCoder's superiority on the widely-used LogHub-2.0 benchmark,
achieving an average improvement of 21.3% over state-of-the-arts.

AI.tldr: SchemaCoder automates log schema extraction across formats using a residual Q-Tree boosted LLM framework, outperforming prior methods on LogHub-2.0.
AI.motivation: Manual hand-crafted regexes and domain expertise impose high labor costs and limit portability; there is a need for a fully automated, format-agnostic schema extraction approach.
AI.method: Context-bounded segmentation to create semantic log chunks; embedding-based sampling to pick representative patterns; hierarchical Q-Tree driven LLM queries to generate schema code; textual-residual evolutionary optimizer and residual boosting to iteratively refine results.
AI.result: Achieves 21.3% average improvement over state-of-the-art on the LogHub-2.0 benchmark.
AI.conclusion: First fully automated schema extraction framework applicable to diverse log formats without human customization within the workflow; demonstrates significant performance gains and broader applicability.

title: AS2FM: Enabling Statistical Model Checking of ROS 2 Systems for Robust Autonomy
summary:
Designing robotic systems to act autonomously in unforeseen environments is a
challenging task. This work presents a novel approach to use formal
verification, specifically Statistical Model Checking (SMC), to verify system
properties of autonomous robots at design-time. We introduce an extension of
the SCXML format, designed to model system components including both Robot
Operating System 2 (ROS 2) and Behavior Tree (BT) features. Further, we
contribute Autonomous Systems to Formal Models (AS2FM), a tool to translate the
full system model into JANI. The use of JANI, a standard format for
quantitative model checking, enables verification of system properties with
off-the-shelf SMC tools. We demonstrate the practical usability of AS2FM both
in terms of applicability to real-world autonomous robotic control systems, and
in terms of verification runtime scaling. We provide a case study, where we
successfully identify problems in a ROS 2-based robotic manipulation use case
that is verifiable in less than one second using consumer hardware.
Additionally, we compare to the state of the art and demonstrate that our
method is more comprehensive in system feature support, and that the
verification runtime scales linearly with the size of the model, instead of
exponentially.

AI.tldr: AS2FM translates extended SCXML models of ROS 2 and Behavior Trees into the JANI format for Statistical Model Checking, enabling design-time verification of autonomous robots with scalable, linear-time verification that can identify issues quickly on consumer hardware; claims broader feature support than alternatives.
AI.motivation: Autonomous robots operate in unpredictable environments; verifying their control software is hard due to complexity and scalability. A practical, scalable verification workflow at design-time is needed to catch issues early and ensure reliability.
AI.method: Extend SCXML to model ROS 2 and BT features; develop AS2FM to translate the full system model into JANI; use standard SMC tools to verify properties; validate with a ROS 2-based robotic manipulation case study; compare scalability and feature coverage against state-of-the-art approaches.
AI.result: Case study identifies problems in the robotic manipulation scenario and completes verification in under one second on consumer hardware; verification scales linearly with model size rather than exponentially; AS2FM offers more comprehensive system feature support.
AI.conclusion: AS2FM enables practical, scalable, and feature-rich design-time verification of autonomous robotic systems via SMC, with fast runtime and broader modeling coverage than current methods.

title: LPLC: A Dataset for License Plate Legibility Classification
comment:
Accepted for presentation at the Conference on Graphics, Patterns and
  Images (SIBGRAPI) 2025
summary:
Automatic License Plate Recognition (ALPR) faces a major challenge when
dealing with illegible license plates (LPs). While reconstruction methods such
as super-resolution (SR) have emerged, the core issue of recognizing these
low-quality LPs remains unresolved. To optimize model performance and
computational efficiency, image pre-processing should be applied selectively to
cases that require enhanced legibility. To support research in this area, we
introduce a novel dataset comprising 10,210 images of vehicles with 12,687
annotated LPs for legibility classification (the LPLC dataset). The images span
a wide range of vehicle types, lighting conditions, and camera/image quality
levels. We adopt a fine-grained annotation strategy that includes vehicle- and
LP-level occlusions, four legibility categories (perfect, good, poor, and
illegible), and character labels for three categories (excluding illegible
LPs). As a benchmark, we propose a classification task using three image
recognition networks to determine whether an LP image is good enough, requires
super-resolution, or is completely unrecoverable. The overall F1 score, which
remained below 80% for all three baseline models (ViT, ResNet, and YOLO),
together with the analyses of SR and LP recognition methods, highlights the
difficulty of the task and reinforces the need for further research. The
proposed dataset is publicly available at
https://github.com/lmlwojcik/lplc-dataset.

AI.tldr: Introduces the LPLC dataset for legibility classification in automatic license plate recognition and benchmarks three image models, showing F1 scores below 0.8 and highlighting the need for selective pre-processing.
AI.motivation: Illegible license plates hinder ALPR; although super-resolution exists, recognition remains unresolved; to optimize performance and efficiency, pre-processing should be applied only when beneficial, motivating a legibility classification task and a public dataset to study it.
AI.method: Collected 10,210 vehicle images with 12,687 license plates; annotated with occlusions, legibility levels (perfect, good, poor, illegible), and character labels for legible LPs; established a three-way classification (good enough, requires SR, unrecoverable) and evaluated ViT, ResNet, and YOLO as baselines.
AI.result: Baseline F1 scores remained below 0.8 across ViT, ResNet, and YOLO; analysis of SR and LP recognition methods indicates current approaches struggle with legibility; dataset is publicly available at the provided GitHub link.
AI.conclusion: Legibility classification for ALPR remains challenging; more research is needed to develop effective selective preprocessing strategies, and the LPLC dataset provides a valuable resource for future work.

title: Evaluating Federated Learning for At-Risk Student Prediction: A Comparative Analysis of Model Complexity and Data Balancing
comment:
This article has been prepared to be submitted to the Holos Journal
  in Brazil
summary:
High dropout and failure rates in distance education pose a significant
challenge for academic institutions, making the proactive identification of
at-risk students crucial for providing timely support. This study develops and
evaluates a machine learning model based on early academic performance and
digital engagement patterns from the large-scale OULAD dataset to predict
student risk at a UK university. To address the practical challenges of data
privacy and institutional silos that often hinder such initiatives, we
implement the model using a Federated Learning (FL) framework. We compare model
complexity (Logistic Regression vs. a Deep Neural Network) and data balancing.
The final federated model demonstrates strong predictive capability, achieving
an ROC AUC score of approximately 85% in identifying at-risk students. Our
findings show that this federated approach provides a practical and scalable
solution for institutions to build effective early-warning systems, enabling
proactive student support while inherently respecting data privacy.

AI.tldr: Federated learning on OULAD data to predict at-risk students; LR vs DNN; ~85% ROC AUC; data balancing; privacy-preserving early-warning system.
AI.motivation: Address high dropout rates and data privacy concerns in distance education by enabling scalable, privacy-preserving risk prediction through FL across institutions.
AI.method: Train a federated learning model using early academic performance and digital engagement features from OULAD; compare Logistic Regression and Deep Neural Network; experiment with data balancing.
AI.result: Federated model achieves ROC AUC ~0.85 for identifying at-risk students; demonstrates practical, scalable privacy-preserving early-warning capability.
AI.conclusion: Federated learning enables effective, privacy-respecting early-warning systems for institutions, balancing predictive performance with data governance.

title: eSkinHealth: A Multimodal Dataset for Neglected Tropical Skin Diseases
summary:
Skin Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) impose severe health and
socioeconomic burdens in impoverished tropical communities. Yet, advancements
in AI-driven diagnostic support are hindered by data scarcity, particularly for
underrepresented populations and rare manifestations of NTDs. Existing
dermatological datasets often lack the demographic and disease spectrum crucial
for developing reliable recognition models of NTDs. To address this, we
introduce eSkinHealth, a novel dermatological dataset collected on-site in
C\^ote d'Ivoire and Ghana. Specifically, eSkinHealth contains 5,623 images from
1,639 cases and encompasses 47 skin diseases, focusing uniquely on skin NTDs
and rare conditions among West African populations. We further propose an
AI-expert collaboration paradigm to implement foundation language and
segmentation models for efficient generation of multimodal annotations, under
dermatologists' guidance. In addition to patient metadata and diagnosis labels,
eSkinHealth also includes semantic lesion masks, instance-specific visual
captions, and clinical concepts. Overall, our work provides a valuable new
resource and a scalable annotation framework, aiming to catalyze the
development of more equitable, accurate, and interpretable AI tools for global
dermatology.

AI.tldr: New dermatology dataset eSkinHealth with 5,623 images from 1,639 cases across 47 diseases, focusing on skin NTDs in West Africa, plus an AI-expert annotation framework for multimodal data to enable equitable AI in global dermatology.
AI.motivation: AI-driven diagnostic support for neglected tropical diseases is bottlenecked by data scarcity, limited representation of West African populations and rare manifestations; existing dermatology datasets lack demographic and disease spectrum needed to build reliable models for skin NTDs.
AI.method: On-site data collection in Côte d'Ivoire and Ghana; 5,623 images from 1,639 cases; 47 skin diseases; includes patient metadata, diagnosis labels, semantic lesion masks, instance-level captions, and clinical concepts; proposes AI-expert collaboration paradigm to use foundation language and segmentation models to generate multimodal annotations under dermatologists' guidance.
AI.result: A substantial, diverse dataset focusing on skin NTDs and rare conditions in West Africa; provision of semantic masks, captions, and clinical concepts; demonstrates a scalable annotation framework and a valuable resource for developing robust, interpretable AI tools in global dermatology.
AI.conclusion: eSkinHealth and the annotation framework enable more equitable, accurate, and interpretable AI tools for global dermatology, addressing data scarcity and demographic gaps in NTD-focused skin disease recognition.

title: VisionSafeEnhanced VPC: Cautious Predictive Control with Visibility Constraints under Uncertainty for Autonomous Robotic Surgery
summary:
Autonomous control of the laparoscope in robot-assisted Minimally Invasive
Surgery (MIS) has received considerable research interest due to its potential
to improve surgical safety. Despite progress in pixel-level Image-Based Visual
Servoing (IBVS) control, the requirement of continuous visibility and the
existence of complex disturbances, such as parameterization error, measurement
noise, and uncertainties of payloads, could degrade the surgeon's visual
experience and compromise procedural safety. To address these limitations, this
paper proposes VisionSafeEnhanced Visual Predictive Control (VPC), a robust and
uncertainty-adaptive framework for autonomous laparoscope control that
guarantees Field of View (FoV) safety under uncertainty. Firstly, Gaussian
Process Regression (GPR) is utilized to perform hybrid (deterministic +
stochastic) quantification of operational uncertainties including residual
model uncertainties, stochastic uncertainties, and external disturbances. Based
on uncertainty quantification, a novel safety aware trajectory optimization
framework with probabilistic guarantees is proposed, where a
uncertainty-adaptive safety Control Barrier Function (CBF) condition is given
based on uncertainty propagation, and chance constraints are simultaneously
formulated based on probabilistic approximation. This uncertainty aware
formulation enables adaptive control effort allocation, minimizing unnecessary
camera motion while maintaining robustness. The proposed method is validated
through comparative simulations and experiments on a commercial surgical robot
platform (MicroPort MedBot Toumai) performing a sequential multi-target lymph
node dissection. Compared with baseline methods, the framework maintains
near-perfect target visibility (>99.9%), reduces tracking e

AI.tldr: A robust, uncertainty-aware autonomous laparoscope control framework (VPC) that uses Gaussian Process Regression to quantify uncertainties and safety-barrier controls with chance constraints to guarantee field-of-view safety in MIS, validated on a commercial robot with near-perfect visibility.
AI.motivation: Autonomous laparoscope control in MIS faces continuous visibility requirements and disturbances (parameterization error, sensor noise, payload uncertainties) that can degrade safety and surgeon experience. Existing IBVS may fail under uncertainty, necessitating a framework that can adapt to uncertainty while preserving FoV safety.
AI.method: Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) to quantify residual model uncertainties, stochastic disturbances, and external disturbances (hybrid deterministic+stochastic model). Uncertainty-propagation-based safety Control Barrier Function (CBF) with probabilistic (chance) constraints. Probabilistic, safety-aware trajectory optimization enabling uncertainty-adaptive control effort allocation to minimize unnecessary camera motion while maintaining robustness.
AI.result: Simulation and experiments on a commercial surgical robot (MicroPort MedBot Toumai) performing sequential multi-target lymph node dissection. Compared with baseline methods, the framework maintains near-perfect target visibility (>99.9%) and reduces tracking effort/variance (text truncated in abstract).
AI.conclusion: The VisionSafeEnhanced Visual Predictive Control (VPC) framework delivers robust, uncertainty-adaptive, safety-guaranteed autonomous laparoscope control for MIS, achieving exceptional FoV retention on a real robot and highlighting its potential to improve safety and efficiency in robotic surgery.

title: CLARIFY: A Specialist-Generalist Framework for Accurate and Lightweight Dermatological Visual Question Answering
comment:
10 pages, 8 figures, Prepared for submission to IEEE Transactions on
  Human-Machine Systems
summary:
Vision-language models (VLMs) have shown significant potential for medical
tasks; however, their general-purpose nature can limit specialized diagnostic
accuracy, and their large size poses substantial inference costs for real-world
clinical deployment. To address these challenges, we introduce CLARIFY, a
Specialist-Generalist framework for dermatological visual question answering
(VQA). CLARIFY combines two components: (i) a lightweight, domain-trained image
classifier (the Specialist) that provides fast and highly accurate diagnostic
predictions, and (ii) a powerful yet compressed conversational VLM (the
Generalist) that generates natural language explanations to user queries. In
our framework, the Specialist's predictions directly guide the Generalist's
reasoning, focusing it on the correct diagnostic path. This synergy is further
enhanced by a knowledge graph-based retrieval module, which grounds the
Generalist's responses in factual dermatological knowledge, ensuring both
accuracy and reliability. This hierarchical design not only reduces diagnostic
errors but also significantly improves computational efficiency. Experiments on
our curated multimodal dermatology dataset demonstrate that CLARIFY achieves an
18\% improvement in diagnostic accuracy over the strongest baseline, a
fine-tuned, uncompressed single-line VLM, while reducing the average VRAM
requirement and latency by at least 20\% and 5\%, respectively. These results
indicate that a Specialist-Generalist system provides a practical and powerful
paradigm for building lightweight, trustworthy, and clinically viable AI
systems.

AI.tldr: CLARIFY is a two-tier Specialist-Generalist framework for dermatology VQA that pairs a fast, domain-trained Specialist with a compressed Generalist LLM, guided reasoning, and a knowledge-graph retriever to improve accuracy and efficiency, achieving 18% accuracy gain and notable VRAM/latency reductions.
AI.motivation: To overcome general-purpose VLMs' diagnostic limitations and high inference costs in clinical settings by creating a lightweight, trustworthy system.
AI.method: Hybrid architecture: (i) Specialist—a lightweight dermatologist image classifier providing accurate predictions; (ii) Generalist—a compressed conversational VLM that explains answers; (iii) knowledge-graph retrieval grounds responses; the Specialist's predictions steer the Generalist's reasoning; hierarchical design to reduce errors and expedite inference.
AI.result: On curated multimodal dermatology dataset, CLARIFY improves diagnostic accuracy by 18% over the strongest baseline (an uncompressed fine-tuned single-line VLM) and reduces VRAM by ≥20% and latency by ≥5%.
AI.conclusion: A Specialist-Generalist paradigm yields a practical, efficient, trustworthy dermatology AI system suitable for real-world deployment.

title: ZTFed-MAS2S: A Zero-Trust Federated Learning Framework with Verifiable Privacy and Trust-Aware Aggregation for Wind Power Data Imputation
comment:
Accepted by IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, 11 pages, 6
  figures
summary:
Wind power data often suffers from missing values due to sensor faults and
unstable transmission at edge sites. While federated learning enables
privacy-preserving collaboration without sharing raw data, it remains
vulnerable to anomalous updates and privacy leakage during parameter exchange.
These challenges are amplified in open industrial environments, necessitating
zero-trust mechanisms where no participant is inherently trusted. To address
these challenges, this work proposes ZTFed-MAS2S, a zero-trust federated
learning framework that integrates a multi-head attention-based
sequence-to-sequence imputation model. ZTFed integrates verifiable differential
privacy with non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs and a confidentiality and
integrity verification mechanism to ensure verifiable privacy preservation and
secure model parameters transmission. A dynamic trust-aware aggregation
mechanism is employed, where trust is propagated over similarity graphs to
enhance robustness, and communication overhead is reduced via sparsity- and
quantization-based compression. MAS2S captures long-term dependencies in wind
power data for accurate imputation. Extensive experiments on real-world wind
farm datasets validate the superiority of ZTFed-MAS2S in both federated
learning performance and missing data imputation, demonstrating its
effectiveness as a secure and efficient solution for practical applications in
the energy sector.

AI.tldr: Proposes ZTFed-MAS2S, a zero-trust federated learning framework with a MAS2S imputation model, integrating verifiable privacy and secure parameter exchange, robust trust-aware aggregation, and compression, achieving strong missing-data imputation and FL performance on real wind data.
AI.motivation: Wind power data suffer from missing values and sensor/communication faults. Federated learning preserves privacy but is vulnerable to anomalous updates and privacy leakage, especially in open industrial environments, necessitating zero-trust, verifiable privacy protections.
AI.method: Introduce ZTFed-MAS2S: a zero-trust FL framework that uses a multi-head attention-based sequence-to-sequence imputation model (MAS2S); combines verifiable differential privacy with non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs; includes confidentiality and integrity verification for model transmissions; employs a dynamic, trust-aware aggregation on similarity graphs; and uses sparsity- and quantization-based compression to lower communication costs.
AI.result: Empirical results on real-world wind-farm datasets show that ZTFed-MAS2S achieves superior federated learning performance and missing-data imputation quality, demonstrating strong security, privacy, and efficiency advantages for practical energy-sector applications.
AI.conclusion: ZTFed-MAS2S provides a secure, efficient, and accurate zero-trust FL solution for wind data imputation in open industrial settings, combining verifiable privacy with robust aggregation and compression.

title: RLMR: Reinforcement Learning with Mixed Rewards for Creative Writing
summary:
Large language models are extensively utilized in creative writing
applications. Creative writing requires a balance between subjective writing
quality (e.g., literariness and emotional expression) and objective constraint
following (e.g., format requirements and word limits). Existing reinforcement
learning methods struggle to balance these two aspects: single reward
strategies fail to improve both abilities simultaneously, while fixed-weight
mixed-reward methods lack the ability to adapt to different writing scenarios.
To address this problem, we propose Reinforcement Learning with Mixed Rewards
(RLMR), utilizing a dynamically mixed reward system from a writing reward model
evaluating subjective writing quality and a constraint verification model
assessing objective constraint following. The constraint following reward
weight is adjusted dynamically according to the writing quality within sampled
groups, ensuring that samples violating constraints get negative advantage in
GRPO and thus penalized during training, which is the key innovation of this
proposed method. We conduct automated and manual evaluations across diverse
model families from 8B to 72B parameters. Additionally, we construct a
real-world writing benchmark named WriteEval for comprehensive evaluation.
Results illustrate that our method achieves consistent improvements in both
instruction following (IFEval from 83.36\% to 86.65\%) and writing quality
(72.75\% win rate in manual expert pairwise evaluations on WriteEval). To the
best of our knowledge, RLMR is the first work to combine subjective preferences
with objective verification in online RL training, providing an effective
solution for multi-dimensional creative writing optimization.

AI.tldr: RLMR dynamically mixes subjective writing quality rewards with objective constraint rewards in online RL, using a dynamic weight that adapts to writing quality to penalize constraint violations, achieving improvements in both instruction following and writing quality across large models and a new WriteEval benchmark.
AI.motivation: Creative writing must balance subjective quality (literary style, emotion) with objective constraints (format, word limits). Single-reward or fixed-weight RL struggles to optimize both aspects across scenarios; adaptability is needed.
AI.method: Introduce Reinforcement Learning with Mixed Rewards (RLMR). Use two reward models: a subjective writing quality model and an objective constraint verification model. Dynamically adjust the constraint-reward weight based on sampled group writing quality; samples that violate constraints receive negative advantage during policy optimization (GRPO). Train and evaluate across 8B–72B parameter models and on a new real-world benchmark WriteEval, with automated and manual evaluations.
AI.result: RLMR yields consistent gains in both dimensions: instruction following IFEval improves from 83.36% to 86.65%, and writing quality achieves a 72.75% win rate in manual expert pairwise evaluations on WriteEval. Claims first-ever combination of subjective preferences with objective verification in online RL for creative writing.
AI.conclusion: Dynamic, adaptive reward blending in RL can simultaneously advance subjective quality and objective constraint adherence in creative writing, scalable across model sizes, and validated on a real-world benchmark; represents a significant step toward multi-dimensional writing optimization.

title: Enhanced UAV Path Planning Using the Tangent Intersection Guidance (TIG) Algorithm
comment: Accepted for publication in JAMRIS Journal
summary:
Efficient and safe navigation of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) is critical
for various applications, including combat support, package delivery and Search
and Rescue Operations. This paper introduces the Tangent Intersection Guidance
(TIG) algorithm, an advanced approach for UAV path planning in both static and
dynamic environments. The algorithm uses the elliptic tangent intersection
method to generate feasible paths. It generates two sub-paths for each threat,
selects the optimal route based on a heuristic rule, and iteratively refines
the path until the target is reached. Considering the UAV kinematic and dynamic
constraints, a modified smoothing technique based on quadratic B\'ezier curves
is adopted to generate a smooth and efficient route. Experimental results show
that the TIG algorithm can generate the shortest path in less time, starting
from 0.01 seconds, with fewer turning angles compared to A*, PRM, RRT*, Tangent
Graph, and Static APPATT algorithms in static environments. Furthermore, in
completely unknown and partially known environments, TIG demonstrates efficient
real-time path planning capabilities for collision avoidance, outperforming APF
and Dynamic APPATT algorithms.

AI.tldr: Tangent Intersection Guidance (TIG) offers real-time UAV path planning in static and dynamic/unknown environments using elliptic tangent intersection, dual sub-path generation per threat, heuristic path selection, iterative refinement, and quadratic Bézier smoothing to produce short, smooth, collision-free routes.
AI.motivation: UAVs require safe, efficient navigation in static, dynamic, and unknown environments while respecting kinematic and dynamic constraints.
AI.method: Use elliptic tangent intersections to generate two sub-paths per threat, apply a heuristic rule to select the best route, iteratively refine the path until the target is reached; incorporate a smoothing stage based on quadratic Bézier curves to produce a smooth, feasible trajectory that respects UAV dynamics.
AI.result: TIG achieves shorter paths with fewer turning angles than A*, PRM, RRT*, Tangent Graph, and Static APPATT in static environments; demonstrates real-time planning in unknown/partially known environments and improved collision avoidance performance against APF and Dynamic APPATT.
AI.conclusion: TIG provides efficient, safe UAV navigation across diverse environments by combining tangent-intersection path generation with dynamic smoothing, enabling real-time, collision-free planning.

title: VQualA 2025 Challenge on Face Image Quality Assessment: Methods and Results
summary:
Face images play a crucial role in numerous applications; however, real-world
conditions frequently introduce degradations such as noise, blur, and
compression artifacts, affecting overall image quality and hindering subsequent
tasks. To address this challenge, we organized the VQualA 2025 Challenge on
Face Image Quality Assessment (FIQA) as part of the ICCV 2025 Workshops.
Participants created lightweight and efficient models (limited to 0.5 GFLOPs
and 5 million parameters) for the prediction of Mean Opinion Scores (MOS) on
face images with arbitrary resolutions and realistic degradations. Submissions
underwent comprehensive evaluations through correlation metrics on a dataset of
in-the-wild face images. This challenge attracted 127 participants, with 1519
final submissions. This report summarizes the methodologies and findings for
advancing the development of practical FIQA approaches.

AI.tldr: Organized the VQualA 2025 FIQA challenge to predict MOS for face images under degradations with strict efficiency limits (≤0.5 GFLOPs, ≤5M parameters). Attracting 127 participants and 1519 final submissions, evaluated on in-the-wild images. The report aggregates methods and findings to push practical FIQA development.
AI.motivation: Real-world face images suffer from degradations (noise, blur, compression) that degrade image quality and hinder downstream tasks. There is a need for efficient, scalable Face Image Quality Assessment (FIQA) methods that perform well across arbitrary resolutions and degradations, tested under realistic, in-the-wild conditions.
AI.method: Organized as part of ICCV 2025 Workshops, the VQualA 2025 FIQA challenge constrained participants to lightweight models (0.5 GFLOPs and 5 million parameters) for predicting Mean Opinion Scores (MOS) on face images with arbitrary resolutions and degradations. Submissions were evaluated using correlation metrics on an in-the-wild face image dataset; 127 participants submitted a total of 1519 finals.
AI.result: The challenge attracted 127 participants and 1519 final submissions. The report summarizes the diverse methodologies and findings that advance practical FIQA approaches under strong resource constraints, highlighting the collection of strategies useful for real-world deployment.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates progress toward practical, efficient FIQA methods capable of handling real-world degradations across arbitrary resolutions, and provides a consolidated view of effective approaches to guide future FIQA research and deployment.

title: Linear cost mutual information estimation and independence test of similar performance as HSIC
summary:
Evaluation of statistical dependencies between two data samples is a basic
problem of data science/machine learning, and HSIC (Hilbert-Schmidt Information
Criterion)~\cite{HSIC} is considered the state-of-art method. However, for size
$n$ data sample it requires multiplication of $n\times n$ matrices, what
currently needs $\sim O(n^{2.37})$ computational complexity~\cite{mult}, making
it impractical for large data samples. We discuss HCR (Hierarchical Correlation
Reconstruction) as its linear cost practical alternative of even higher
dependence sensitivity in tests, and additionally providing actual joint
distribution model by description of dependencies through features being mixed
moments, starting with correlation and homoscedasticity, also allowing to
approximate mutual information as just sum of squares of such nontrivial mixed
moments between two data samples. Such single dependence describing feature is
calculated in $O(n)$ linear time. Their number to test varies with dimension
$d$ - requiring $O(d^2)$ for pairwise dependencies, $O(d^3)$ if wanting to also
consider more subtle triplewise, and so on.

AI.tldr: HCR is a scalable linear-time alternative to HSIC for dependence testing, offering higher sensitivity and a joint distribution model via mixed moments; complexity scales with n linearly for a single feature and with dimension d for multiple features (O(d^2) pairwise, O(d^3) triplewise).
AI.motivation: To overcome HSIC's quadratic/quasi-quadratic computational cost on large datasets while preserving or improving sensitivity and providing a usable joint distribution description.
AI.method: Hierarchical Correlation Reconstruction: build dependence descriptors from mixed moments (starting with correlation and homoscedasticity), compute single-dependence features in O(n); approximate mutual information as sum of squares of nontrivial mixed moments; test dependencies across dimensions by expanding to pairwise, triplewise, etc., with costs O(d^2), O(d^3), etc.
AI.result: Single dependence describing feature computed in O(n); higher sensitivity tests; joint distribution model via descriptive features; mutual information approximated by sum of squares of mixed moments.
AI.conclusion: HCR offers scalable, linear-cost dependence testing with the ability to represent joint distributions and capture higher-order dependencies; performance depends on dimensionality due to combinatorial growth in testing combinations.

title: Beyond Benchmark: LLMs Evaluation with an Anthropomorphic and Value-oriented Roadmap
summary:
For Large Language Models (LLMs), a disconnect persists between benchmark
