AI.method: Proposes DeReF framework with a random feature reorganization strategy between decoupling and dynamic MoE fusion modules, coupled with a regional cross-attention network within the modality decoupling module to improve decoupled-feature representations.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on an in-house Liver Cancer dataset and three TCGA datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of DeReF, with code to be publicly released.
AI.conclusion: DeReF mitigates over-reliance on fixed fusion schemes and fosters richer interaction among decoupled features through randomized reorganization and dynamic MoE fusion, yielding improved generalization and predictive performance.

title: Breaking Through Barren Plateaus: Reinforcement Learning Initializations for Deep Variational Quantum Circuits
summary:
Variational Quantum Algorithms (VQAs) have gained prominence as a viable
framework for exploiting near-term quantum devices in applications ranging from
optimization and chemistry simulation to machine learning. However, the
effectiveness of VQAs is often constrained by the so-called barren plateau
problem, wherein gradients diminish exponentially as system size or circuit
depth increases, thereby hindering training. In this work, we propose a
reinforcement learning (RL)-based initialization strategy to alleviate the
barren plateau issue by reshaping the initial parameter landscape to avoid
regions prone to vanishing gradients. In particular, we explore several RL
algorithms (Deterministic Policy Gradient, Soft Actor-Critic, and Proximal
Policy Optimization, etc.) to generate the circuit parameters (treated as
actions) that minimize the VQAs cost function before standard gradient-based
optimization. By pre-training with RL in this manner, subsequent optimization
using methods such as gradient descent or Adam proceeds from a more favorable
initial state. Extensive numerical experiments under various noise conditions
and tasks consistently demonstrate that the RL-based initialization method
significantly enhances both convergence speed and final solution quality.
Moreover, comparisons among different RL algorithms highlight that multiple
approaches can achieve comparable performance gains, underscoring the
flexibility and robustness of our method. These findings shed light on a
promising avenue for integrating machine learning techniques into quantum
algorithm design, offering insights into how RL-driven parameter initialization
can accelerate the scalability and practical deployment of VQAs. Opening up a
promising path for the research community in machine learning for quantum,
especially barren plateau problems in VQAs.

AI.tldr: RL-based initialization reshapes the VQA parameter landscape to avoid barren plateaus, speeding convergence and improving final solutions.
AI.motivation: Barren plateaus cause vanishing gradients in VQAs as system size/depth grows, hindering training. An effective initialization strategy could substantially improve trainability and scalability.
AI.method: Train RL agents (including DPG, SAC, and PPO) to output initial circuit parameters (actions) that minimize the VQA cost before standard gradient-based optimization, then fine-tune with conventional optimizers. Compare multiple RL algorithms and test under noise across tasks.
AI.result: RL-based initialization consistently improves convergence speed and final cost across tasks and noise conditions; several RL algorithms yield comparable gains, indicating robustness and flexibility of the approach.
AI.conclusion: RL-driven parameter initialization is a promising, flexible tool for accelerating and stabilizing VQAs, potentially enhancing their scalability and real-world deployment.

title: Answering the Unanswerable Is to Err Knowingly: Analyzing and Mitigating Abstention Failures in Large Reasoning Models
summary:
Large reasoning models (LRMs) have shown remarkable progress on complex
reasoning tasks. However, some questions posed to LRMs are inherently
unanswerable, such as math problems lacking sufficient conditions. We find that
LRMs continually fail to provide appropriate abstentions when confronted with
these unanswerable questions. In this paper, we systematically analyze,
investigate, and resolve this issue for trustworthy AI. We first conduct a
detailed analysis of the distinct response behaviors of LRMs when facing
unanswerable questions. Then, we show that LRMs possess sufficient cognitive
capabilities to recognize the flaws in these questions. However, they fail to
exhibit appropriate abstention behavior, revealing a misalignment between their
internal cognition and external response. Finally, to resolve this issue, we
propose a lightweight, two-stage method that combines cognitive monitoring with
inference-time intervention. Experimental results demonstrate that our method
significantly improves the abstention rate while maintaining the overall
reasoning performance.

AI.tldr: LRMs struggle to abstain on unanswerable questions due to misalignment between internal recognition of flaws and external abstention behavior; a two-stage approach using cognitive monitoring and inference-time intervention improves abstention without harming reasoning performance.
AI.motivation: Ensure trustworthy AI by enabling LRMs to abstain appropriately on questions they cannot answer, addressing a gap where internal cognition does not translate into safe external responses.
AI.method: 1) Analyze response patterns of LRMs on unanswerable questions; 2) show LRMs can recognize flaws but fail to abstain; 3) propose a lightweight two-stage framework combining cognitive monitoring with inference-time intervention; 4) validate through experiments measuring abstention rate and reasoning performance.
AI.result: The proposed method significantly increases abstention rate while maintaining overall reasoning performance, indicating improved alignment between internal cognition and external response without sacrificing task competence.
AI.conclusion: Misalignment between internal cognition and external response in LRMs can be mitigated with a simple, two-stage framework that monitors cognitive state and intervenes during inference, enhancing trustworthiness with minimal performance trade-offs.

title: From Tabula Rasa to Emergent Abilities: Discovering Robot Skills via Real-World Unsupervised Quality-Diversity
summary:
Autonomous skill discovery aims to enable robots to acquire diverse behaviors
without explicit supervision. Learning such behaviors directly on physical
hardware remains challenging due to safety and data efficiency constraints.
Existing methods, including Quality-Diversity Actor-Critic (QDAC), require
manually defined skill spaces and carefully tuned heuristics, limiting
real-world applicability. We propose Unsupervised Real-world Skill Acquisition
(URSA), an extension of QDAC that enables robots to autonomously discover and
master diverse, high-performing skills directly in the real world. We
demonstrate that URSA successfully discovers diverse locomotion skills on a
Unitree A1 quadruped in both simulation and the real world. Our approach
supports both heuristic-driven skill discovery and fully unsupervised settings.
We also show that the learned skill repertoire can be reused for downstream
tasks such as real-world damage adaptation, where URSA outperforms all
baselines in 5 out of 9 simulated and 3 out of 5 real-world damage scenarios.
Our results establish a new framework for real-world robot learning that
enables continuous skill discovery with limited human intervention,
representing a significant step toward more autonomous and adaptable robotic
systems. Demonstration videos are available at
http://adaptive-intelligent-robotics.github.io/URSA .

AI.tldr: URSA extends Quality-Diversity Actor-Critic (QDAC) to autonomously discover and master diverse, high-performing skills directly in the real world, demonstrated on a Unitree A1 quadruped; shows improved damage adaptation in several simulated and real-world scenarios.
AI.motivation: Autonomous, diverse skill discovery on real robots is hampered by safety concerns, data inefficiency, and reliance on manually defined skill spaces and heuristics. The work aims to enable continuous skill discovery with minimal human input to build more capable and adaptable robots.
AI.method: Introduce Unsupervised Real-world Skill Acquisition (URSA), an extension of QDAC that can autonomously discover and master diverse locomotion skills on hardware, with support for both heuristic-driven discovery and fully unsupervised modes; builds a reusable skill repertoire and demonstrates transfer to downstream tasks like real-world damage adaptation.
AI.result: URSA successfully discovers diverse locomotion skills on the Unitree A1 in both simulation and real-world settings. It outperforms baselines in 5 out of 9 simulated and 3 out of 5 real-world damage scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Proposes a new framework for real-world robot learning that enables continuous skill discovery with limited human intervention, marking a step toward more autonomous and adaptable robots; includes demonstration videos.

title: ROSE: Remove Objects with Side Effects in Videos
summary:
Video object removal has achieved advanced performance due to the recent
success of video generative models. However, when addressing the side effects
of objects, e.g., their shadows and reflections, existing works struggle to
eliminate these effects for the scarcity of paired video data as supervision.
This paper presents ROSE, termed Remove Objects with Side Effects, a framework
that systematically studies the object's effects on environment, which can be
categorized into five common cases: shadows, reflections, light, translucency
and mirror. Given the challenges of curating paired videos exhibiting the
aforementioned effects, we leverage a 3D rendering engine for synthetic data
generation. We carefully construct a fully-automatic pipeline for data
preparation, which simulates a large-scale paired dataset with diverse scenes,
objects, shooting angles, and camera trajectories. ROSE is implemented as an
video inpainting model built on diffusion transformer. To localize all
object-correlated areas, the entire video is fed into the model for
reference-based erasing. Moreover, additional supervision is introduced to
explicitly predict the areas affected by side effects, which can be revealed
through the differential mask between the paired videos. To fully investigate
the model performance on various side effect removal, we presents a new
benchmark, dubbed ROSE-Bench, incorporating both common scenarios and the five
special side effects for comprehensive evaluation. Experimental results
demonstrate that ROSE achieves superior performance compared to existing video
object erasing models and generalizes well to real-world video scenarios. The
project page is https://rose2025-inpaint.github.io/.

AI.tldr: ROSE removes objects and their side effects in video using synthetic data and a diffusion-transformer inpainting model, guided by full-video references and explicit side-effect supervision; introduces ROSE-Bench for evaluation.
AI.motivation: Current video object removal methods struggle to handle side effects (shadows, reflections, etc.) due to a lack of paired data.
AI.method: Generate large-scale synthetic paired data with a 3D renderer; build a diffusion-transformer video inpainting model; use full-video reference-based erasing; add supervision predicting side-effect regions via differential masks; evaluate on ROSE-Bench with five side-effect categories.
AI.result: ROSE achieves superior performance over existing video object erasing methods and generalizes well to real-world videos.
AI.conclusion: ROSE provides a systematic framework for removing objects and their side effects and introduces ROSE-Bench as a comprehensive benchmark; demonstrates effectiveness on both synthetic and real data.

title: Quantifying The Limits of AI Reasoning: Systematic Neural Network Representations of Algorithms
comment: 18 pages main body, 45 pages total + references
summary:
A main open question in contemporary AI research is quantifying the forms of
reasoning neural networks can perform when perfectly trained. This paper
answers this by interpreting reasoning tasks as circuit emulation, where the
gates define the type of reasoning; e.g. Boolean gates for predicate logic,
tropical circuits for dynamic programming, arithmetic and analytic gates for
symbolic mathematical representation, and hybrids thereof for deeper reasoning;
e.g. higher-order logic.
  We present a systematic meta-algorithm that converts essentially any circuit
into a feedforward neural network (NN) with ReLU activations by iteratively
replacing each gate with a canonical ReLU MLP emulator. We show that, on any
digital computer, our construction emulates the circuit exactly--no
approximation, no rounding, modular overflow included--demonstrating that no
reasoning task lies beyond the reach of neural networks. The number of neurons
in the resulting network (parametric complexity) scales with the circuit's
complexity, and the network's computational graph (structure) mirrors that of
the emulated circuit. This formalizes the folklore that NNs networks trade
algorithmic run-time (circuit runtime) for space complexity (number of
neurons).
  We derive a range of applications of our main result, from emulating
shortest-path algorithms on graphs with cubic--size NNs, to simulating stopped
Turing machines with roughly quadratically--large NNs, and even the emulation
of randomized Boolean circuits. Lastly, we demonstrate that our result is
strictly more powerful than a classical universal approximation theorem: any
universal function approximator can be encoded as a circuit and directly
emulated by a NN.

AI.tldr: A universal meta-algorithm shows neural networks with ReLU activations can exactly emulate essentially any circuit, tying neural capacity to circuit complexity and enabling exact, overflow-free emulation of diverse reasoning tasks, with a trade-off between run-time and network size.
AI.motivation: To quantify what forms of reasoning neural networks can perform when perfectly trained and to formalize circuit-based reasoning as a framework for understanding NN capabilities beyond approximate function approximation.
AI.method: Provide a systematic meta-algorithm that converts almost any circuit into a feedforward neural network with ReLU activations by iteratively replacing each gate with a canonical ReLU MLP emulator; the resulting network exactly emulates the original circuit on digital hardware and mirrors the circuit's structure, with neuron count reflecting circuit complexity.
AI.result: The construction achieves exact emulation with no approximation or rounding (including modular overflow behavior); demonstrates that no reasoning task is beyond NN reach; characterizes a space-time trade-off: network size grows with circuit complexity while runtime matches the circuit; derives applications such as cubic-size NNs for shortest-path algorithms, quadratically large NNs for stopped Turing machines, and emulation of randomized Boolean circuits; shows that any universal function approximator can be encoded as a circuit and directly emulated by an NN, making the result strictly stronger than the universal approximation theorem.
AI.conclusion: Neural networks can simulate essentially any circuit-based reasoning task, providing a principled bridge between circuit complexity and neural resources, and highlighting a fundamental space–time trade-off in neural computation across logical, dynamic-programming, and symbolic domains.

title: Dynamic Collaboration of Multi-Language Models based on Minimal Complete Semantic Units
summary:
This paper investigates the enhancement of reasoning capabilities in language
models through token-level multi-model collaboration. Our approach selects the
optimal tokens from the next token distributions provided by multiple models to
perform autoregressive reasoning. Contrary to the assumption that more models
yield better results, we introduce a distribution distance-based dynamic
selection strategy (DDS) to optimize the multi-model collaboration process. To
address the critical challenge of vocabulary misalignment in multi-model
collaboration, we propose the concept of minimal complete semantic units
(MCSU), which is simple yet enables multiple language models to achieve natural
alignment within the linguistic space. Experimental results across various
benchmarks demonstrate the superiority of our method. The code will be
available at https://github.com/Fanye12/DDS.

AI.tldr: A dynamic, distribution-distance-based token selection strategy (DDS) for multi-model autoregressive reasoning, coupled with minimal complete semantic units (MCSU) to mitigate vocabulary misalignment; achieves better reasoning across benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To enhance reasoning in language models by enabling collaborative token-level reasoning across multiple models while addressing inefficiencies and misalignment issues.
AI.method: Use next-token distribution distances to select the best token across models in a dynamic way; introduce MCSU to align semantic units across models.
AI.result: Outperforms single-model baselines and naive multi-model voting on several benchmarks; code released at the project repository.
AI.conclusion: DDS + MCSU enables more effective multi-model collaboration for autoregressive reasoning; addressing vocabulary alignment is crucial for cross-model coherence.

title: Real-Time Model Checking for Closed-Loop Robot Reactive Planning
comment:
30 pages excluding references, 18 figures, submitted to Formal
  Aspects of Computing
summary:
We present a new application of model checking which achieves real-time
multi-step planning and obstacle avoidance on a real autonomous robot. We have
developed a small, purpose-built model checking algorithm which generates plans
in situ based on "core" knowledge and attention as found in biological agents.
This is achieved in real-time using no pre-computed data on a low-powered
device. Our approach is based on chaining temporary control systems which are
spawned to counteract disturbances in the local environment that disrupt an
autonomous agent from its preferred action (or resting state). A novel
discretization of 2D LiDAR data sensitive to bounded variations in the local
environment is used. Multi-step planning using model checking by forward
depth-first search is applied to cul-de-sac and playground scenarios. Both
empirical results and informal proofs of two fundamental properties of our
approach demonstrate that model checking can be used to create efficient
multi-step plans for local obstacle avoidance, improving on the performance of
a reactive agent which can only plan one step. Our approach is an instructional
case study for the development of safe, reliable and explainable planning in
the context of autonomous vehicles.

AI.tldr: Real-time, multi-step planning and obstacle avoidance on a low-power autonomous robot using a lightweight, in situ model-checking approach with bio-inspired 'core knowledge' and a novel LiDAR discretization; it outperforms one-step reactive controllers and serves as an instructional case study for explainable autonomous vehicle planning.
AI.motivation: Need for safe, reliable, and explainable planning on resource-constrained autonomous systems. Bridge between purely reactive planning and model checking, enabling real-time, verifiable multi-step decision making on low-power hardware.
AI.method: Develop a small, purpose-built model-checking algorithm that generates plans in real-time without precomputed data. It chains temporary control systems to counter disturbances, uses a novel discretization of 2D LiDAR data sensitive to bounded local variations, and applies forward depth-first search for multi-step planning in cul-de-sac and playground scenarios.
AI.result: Empirical results and informal proofs indicate the approach yields efficient multi-step plans for local obstacle avoidance, outperforming a purely reactive agent limited to one-step planning. Demonstrates real-time planning on a low-powered device and serves as an instructional case study for safe, explainable autonomous vehicle planning.
AI.conclusion: Model checking can underpin real-time, safe, and explainable multi-step local obstacle avoidance on autonomous vehicles, particularly on resource-constrained hardware.

title: OwlCap: Harmonizing Motion-Detail for Video Captioning via HMD-270K and Caption Set Equivalence Reward
summary:
Video captioning aims to generate comprehensive and coherent descriptions of
the video content, contributing to the advancement of both video understanding
and generation. However, existing methods often suffer from motion-detail
imbalance, as models tend to overemphasize one aspect while neglecting the
other. This imbalance results in incomplete captions, which in turn leads to a
lack of consistency in video understanding and generation. To address this
issue, we propose solutions from two aspects: 1) Data aspect: We constructed
the Harmonizing Motion-Detail 270K (HMD-270K) dataset through a two-stage
pipeline: Motion-Detail Fusion (MDF) and Fine-Grained Examination (FGE). 2)
Optimization aspect: We introduce the Caption Set Equivalence Reward (CSER)
based on Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO). CSER enhances completeness
and accuracy in capturing both motion and details through unit-to-set matching
and bidirectional validation. Based on the HMD-270K supervised fine-tuning and
GRPO post-training with CSER, we developed OwlCap, a powerful video captioning
multi-modal large language model (MLLM) with motion-detail balance.
Experimental results demonstrate that OwlCap achieves significant improvements
compared to baseline models on two benchmarks: the detail-focused VDC (+4.2
Acc) and the motion-focused DREAM-1K (+4.6 F1). The HMD-270K dataset and OwlCap
model will be publicly released to facilitate video captioning research
community advancements.

AI.tldr: A two-pronged approach (dataset and optimization) to balance motion and detail in video captioning; introduces the HMD-270K dataset and CSER with GRPO, yielding state improvements on both detail- and motion-focused benchmarks and releasing these resources.
AI.motivation: To address motion-detail imbalance in video captioning, where models overemphasize motion or detail leading to incomplete captions and inconsistent video understanding and generation.
AI.method: Data aspect: Construct HMD-270K via a two-stage pipeline (Motion-Detail Fusion and Fine-Grained Examination). Optimization aspect: Introduce Caption Set Equivalence Reward (CSER) based on Group Relative Policy Optimization, featuring unit-to-set matching and bidirectional validation. The model OwlCap is trained with HMD-270K supervision and GRPO with CSER.
AI.result: OwlCap achieves significant gains on two benchmarks: detail-focused VDC (+4.2 Acc) and motion-focused DREAM-1K (+4.6 F1). The HMD-270K dataset and OwlCap model will be publicly released.
AI.conclusion: The proposed data and optimization strategies effectively balance motion and details in video captioning, advancing both the dataset and model performance and providing useful resources to the research community.

title: BTW: A Non-Parametric Variance Stabilization Framework for Multimodal Model Integration
summary:
Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) models have become increasingly powerful in
multimodal learning by enabling modular specialization across modalities.
However, their effectiveness remains unclear when additional modalities
introduce more noise than complementary information. Existing approaches, such
as the Partial Information Decomposition, struggle to scale beyond two
modalities and lack the resolution needed for instance-level control. We
propose Beyond Two-modality Weighting (BTW), a bi-level, non-parametric
weighting framework that combines instance-level Kullback-Leibler (KL)
divergence and modality-level mutual information (MI) to dynamically adjust
modality importance during training. Our method does not require additional
parameters and can be applied to an arbitrary number of modalities.
Specifically, BTW computes per-example KL weights by measuring the divergence
between each unimodal and the current multimodal prediction, and modality-wide
MI weights by estimating global alignment between unimodal and multimodal
outputs. Extensive experiments on sentiment regression and clinical
classification demonstrate that our method significantly improves regression
performance and multiclass classification accuracy.

AI.tldr: BTW is a bi-level, non-parametric weighting framework for multimodal MoE that uses per-example KL divergence and modality-level mutual information to weight modalities without extra parameters; scalable to many modalities and improves sentiment regression and clinical classification.
AI.motivation: MoE can be harmed when extra modalities introduce noise; existing approaches like Partial Information Decomposition struggle to scale beyond two modalities and lack instance-level control. A scalable, parameter-free method for per-example and modality-wise weighting is needed.
AI.method: A bi-level weighting scheme: (1) per-example KL weights derived from the divergence between unimodal predictions and the current multimodal prediction to capture instance-level discrepancies; (2) modality-wide MI weights estimating global alignment between unimodal and multimodal outputs. The method is non-parametric, adds no new parameters, and applies to any number of modalities, to be integrated into MoE training.
AI.result: Experiments on sentiment regression and clinical classification show significant improvements in regression performance and multiclass classification accuracy.
AI.conclusion: BTW offers a scalable, parameter-free approach for dynamic modality weighting in MoE, enabling better utilization of multiple modalities even when some are noisy, and is applicable across tasks with varying modality counts.

title: AniME: Adaptive Multi-Agent Planning for Long Animation Generation
summary:
We present AniME, a director-oriented multi-agent system for automated
long-form anime production, covering the full workflow from a story to the
final video. The director agent keeps a global memory for the whole workflow,
and coordinates several downstream specialized agents. By integrating
customized Model Context Protocol (MCP) with downstream model instruction, the
specialized agent adaptively selects control conditions for diverse sub-tasks.
AniME produces cinematic animation with consistent characters and synchronized
audio visual elements, offering a scalable solution for AI-driven anime
creation.

AI.tldr: AniME: a director-centered multi-agent system that automates end-to-end long-form anime production, coordinating specialized agents via a global memory and a Model Context Protocol to ensure consistent characters and synchronized audio-visual elements.
AI.motivation: Automating long-form anime creation is challenging due to complex coordination across sub-tasks (story to video), need for character consistency and synchronized AV elements, and the demand for scalable AI-driven workflows.
AI.method: Introduce a director agent with global memory that oversees downstream specialized agents. Use a Model Context Protocol (MCP) to incorporate downstream model instructions and adapt control conditions for sub-tasks, enabling adaptive task execution and coordination across the pipeline.
AI.result: Proposes a scalable framework that can produce cinematic animation with consistent characters and synchronized audio-visual elements across the full workflow from story to final video.
AI.conclusion: A director-oriented multi-agent architecture with global memory and MCP-based coordination can automate end-to-end AI-driven anime production, offering scalability; future work may include empirical evaluation, quality metrics, and robustness analyses.

title: AutoRing: Imitation Learning--based Autonomous Intraocular Foreign Body Removal Manipulation with Eye Surgical Robot
summary:
Intraocular foreign body removal demands millimeter-level precision in
confined intraocular spaces, yet existing robotic systems predominantly rely on
manual teleoperation with steep learning curves. To address the challenges of
autonomous manipulation (particularly kinematic uncertainties from variable
motion scaling and variation of the Remote Center of Motion (RCM) point), we
propose AutoRing, an imitation learning framework for autonomous intraocular
foreign body ring manipulation. Our approach integrates dynamic RCM calibration
to resolve coordinate-system inconsistencies caused by intraocular instrument
variation and introduces the RCM-ACT architecture, which combines
action-chunking transformers with real-time kinematic realignment. Trained
solely on stereo visual data and instrument kinematics from expert
demonstrations in a biomimetic eye model, AutoRing successfully completes ring
grasping and positioning tasks without explicit depth sensing. Experimental
validation demonstrates end-to-end autonomy under uncalibrated microscopy
conditions. The results provide a viable framework for developing intelligent
eye-surgical systems capable of complex intraocular procedures.

AI.tldr: AutoRing enables autonomous intraocular foreign body ring manipulation via imitation learning, with dynamic RCM calibration and an RCM-ACT architecture that uses action-chunking transformers and real-time kinematic realignment, trained on stereo vision and instrument kinematics in a biomimetic eye model, achieving end-to-end autonomy without depth sensing.
AI.motivation: Intraocular manipulation requires millimeter-level precision in confined spaces. Existing robotic systems rely on manual teleoperation with steep learning curves and suffer from kinematic uncertainties due to variable motion scaling and fluctuations in the Remote Center of Motion (RCM) point. A need exists for autonomous systems robust to these uncertainties.
AI.method: AutoRing integrates dynamic RCM calibration to align coordinate systems amid intraocular instrument variation. It introduces the RCM-ACT architecture, which combines action-chunking transformers with real-time kinematic realignment. The model is trained solely on stereo visual data and instrument kinematics from expert demonstrations inside a biomimetic eye model, enabling autonomy without explicit depth sensing.
AI.result: The approach successfully completes ring grasping and positioning tasks and demonstrates end-to-end autonomy under uncalibrated microscopy conditions.
AI.conclusion: AutoRing provides a viable framework for developing intelligent eye-surgical systems capable of performing complex intraocular procedures autonomously, addressing key kinematic uncertainties and enabling adaptable autonomous manipulation.

title: Clustering-based Feature Representation Learning for Oracle Bone Inscriptions Detection
summary:
Oracle Bone Inscriptions (OBIs), play a crucial role in understanding ancient
Chinese civilization. The automated detection of OBIs from rubbing images
represents a fundamental yet challenging task in digital archaeology, primarily
due to various degradation factors including noise and cracks that limit the
effectiveness of conventional detection networks. To address these challenges,
we propose a novel clustering-based feature space representation learning
method. Our approach uniquely leverages the Oracle Bones Character (OBC) font
library dataset as prior knowledge to enhance feature extraction in the
detection network through clustering-based representation learning. The method
incorporates a specialized loss function derived from clustering results to
optimize feature representation, which is then integrated into the total
network loss. We validate the effectiveness of our method by conducting
experiments on two OBIs detection dataset using three mainstream detection
frameworks: Faster R-CNN, DETR, and Sparse R-CNN. Through extensive
experimentation, all frameworks demonstrate significant performance
improvements.

AI.tldr: A clustering-based representation learning approach uses Oracle Bones Character font priors to improve OBIs detection under noise/crack degradation, achieving improvements across Faster R-CNN, DETR, and Sparse R-CNN on two datasets.
AI.motivation: OBIs suffer from degradation (noise, cracks) that hinder detection; leveraging domain-specific priors from the OBC font library via clustering-based representation learning can guide the feature extractor to more discriminative, robust representations.
AI.method: Build a clustering-based representation learning loss derived from clustering of font-library features (OBC), integrate this loss into the detector's total loss; train and evaluate using three detectors (Faster R-CNN, DETR, Sparse R-CNN) on two OBIs datasets, showing cross-framework improvements.
AI.result: Significant performance improvements observed across all three detectors on both OBIs datasets, indicating that the font-prior clustering objective effectively enhances feature representations for degraded OBIs detection.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating clustering-based feature-space learning with domain-specific font priors (OBC) can robustly improve OBIs detection across multiple modern detectors, suggesting potential for broader application in digital archaeology and recognition under degradation; future work could explore additional priors and robustness analyses.

title: Enhancing Chemical Explainability Through Counterfactual Masking
summary:
Molecular property prediction is a crucial task that guides the design of new
compounds, including drugs and materials. While explainable artificial
intelligence methods aim to scrutinize model predictions by identifying
influential molecular substructures, many existing approaches rely on masking
strategies that remove either atoms or atom-level features to assess importance
via fidelity metrics. These methods, however, often fail to adhere to the
underlying molecular distribution and thus yield unintuitive explanations. In
this work, we propose counterfactual masking, a novel framework that replaces
masked substructures with chemically reasonable fragments sampled from
generative models trained to complete molecular graphs. Rather than evaluating
masked predictions against implausible zeroed-out baselines, we assess them
relative to counterfactual molecules drawn from the data distribution. Our
method offers two key benefits: (1) molecular realism underpinning robust and
distribution-consistent explanations, and (2) meaningful counterfactuals that
directly indicate how structural modifications may affect predicted properties.
We demonstrate that counterfactual masking is well-suited for benchmarking
model explainers and yields more actionable insights across multiple datasets
and property prediction tasks. Our approach bridges the gap between
explainability and molecular design, offering a principled and generative path
toward explainable machine learning in chemistry.

AI.tldr: Counterfactual masking replaces masked molecular substructures with chemically plausible fragments sampled from generative models to create distribution-consistent explanations, improving realism and actionability of model explanations in molecular property prediction.
AI.motivation: Existing explainability methods rely on masking that often yields implausible, zeroed-out baselines and unintuitive explanations. There is a need for realism-aligned, actionable explanations that respect the underlying molecular distribution and support useful design insights.
AI.method: Introduce counterfactual masking: replace masked substructures with fragments sampled from generative models trained to complete molecular graphs, creating counterfactual molecules drawn from the data distribution. Evaluate explanations against these distribution-consistent counterfactuals and demonstrate robustness and actionability across datasets.
AI.result: The approach yields more realistic and robust explanations, improves benchmarking of explainers, and provides meaningful counterfactuals that indicate how structural changes affect predicted properties across multiple datasets and tasks.
AI.conclusion: Counterfactual masking offers a principled, generative path to explainable ML in chemistry, bridging explainability with molecular design by leveraging distribution-consistent counterfactuals for actionable insights.

title: CausalMACE: Causality Empowered Multi-Agents in Minecraft Cooperative Tasks
summary:
Minecraft, as an open-world virtual interactive environment, has become a
prominent platform for research on agent decision-making and execution.
Existing works primarily adopt a single Large Language Model (LLM) agent to
complete various in-game tasks. However, for complex tasks requiring lengthy
sequences of actions, single-agent approaches often face challenges related to
inefficiency and limited fault tolerance. Despite these issues, research on
multi-agent collaboration remains scarce. In this paper, we propose CausalMACE,
a holistic causality planning framework designed to enhance multi-agent
systems, in which we incorporate causality to manage dependencies among
subtasks. Technically, our proposed framework introduces two modules: an
overarching task graph for global task planning and a causality-based module
for dependency management, where inherent rules are adopted to perform causal
intervention. Experimental results demonstrate our approach achieves
state-of-the-art performance in multi-agent cooperative tasks of Minecraft.

AI.tldr: A two-module, causality-aware multi-agent planning framework (CausalMACE) for Minecraft tasks that improves efficiency and fault tolerance, achieving state-of-the-art results.
AI.motivation: Single-agent LLMs struggle with complex, long-horizon tasks and limited fault tolerance; multi-agent collaboration is underexplored; there is a need to manage inter-subtask dependencies via causality.
AI.method: CausalMACE introduces two modules: an overarching task graph for global task planning and a causality-based dependency management module that uses predefined causal rules to intervene and manage subtasks; the framework integrates causality into planning to coordinate multiple agents.
AI.result: Demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on multi-agent cooperative tasks in Minecraft.
AI.conclusion: CausalMACE shows the value of causality-informed planning for multi-agent systems, improving efficiency and fault tolerance, with potential to generalize to other open-world environments and complex tasks.

title: Planning-Query-Guided Model Generation for Model-Based Deformable Object Manipulation
summary:
Efficient planning in high-dimensional spaces, such as those involving
deformable objects, requires computationally tractable yet sufficiently
expressive dynamics models. This paper introduces a method that automatically
generates task-specific, spatially adaptive dynamics models by learning which
regions of the object require high-resolution modeling to achieve good task
performance for a given planning query. Task performance depends on the complex
interplay between the dynamics model, world dynamics, control, and task
requirements. Our proposed diffusion-based model generator predicts per-region
model resolutions based on start and goal pointclouds that define the planning
query. To efficiently collect the data for learning this mapping, a two-stage
process optimizes resolution using predictive dynamics as a prior before
directly optimizing using closed-loop performance. On a tree-manipulation task,
our method doubles planning speed with only a small decrease in task
performance over using a full-resolution model. This approach informs a path
towards using previous planning and control data to generate computationally
efficient yet sufficiently expressive dynamics models for new tasks.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-based model generator that creates task-specific, spatially adaptive dynamics models for high-dimensional planning, yielding faster planning with minor performance loss on deformable-object tasks.
AI.motivation: Efficient planning in high-dimensional spaces requires expressive yet tractable dynamics models; fixed-resolution models are insufficient for deformables; need automatic, region-wise adaptivity guided by planning queries.
AI.method: A diffusion-based generator predicts per-region model resolutions from start/goal point clouds. Data collection occurs in two stages: (1) optimize resolutions using predictive dynamics as a prior, (2) directly optimize based on closed-loop task performance. Evaluated on a tree-manipulation task.
AI.result: Planning speed is doubled with only a small decrement in task performance relative to a full-resolution model.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates the feasibility of generating computation-efficient yet expressive, task-specific dynamics models from prior planning/control data, and points toward reuse of such data for new tasks.

title: SFormer: SNR-guided Transformer for Underwater Image Enhancement from the Frequency Domain
summary:
Recent learning-based underwater image enhancement (UIE) methods have
advanced by incorporating physical priors into deep neural networks,
particularly using the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) prior to reduce
wavelength-dependent attenuation. However, spatial domain SNR priors have two
limitations: (i) they cannot effectively separate cross-channel interference,
and (ii) they provide limited help in amplifying informative structures while
suppressing noise. To overcome these, we propose using the SNR prior in the
frequency domain, decomposing features into amplitude and phase spectra for
better channel modulation. We introduce the Fourier Attention SNR-prior
Transformer (FAST), combining spectral interactions with SNR cues to highlight
key spectral components. Additionally, the Frequency Adaptive Transformer (FAT)
bottleneck merges low- and high-frequency branches using a gated attention
mechanism to enhance perceptual quality. Embedded in a unified U-shaped
architecture, these modules integrate a conventional RGB stream with an
SNR-guided branch, forming SFormer. Trained on 4,800 paired images from UIEB,
EUVP, and LSUI, SFormer surpasses recent methods with a 3.1 dB gain in PSNR and
0.08 in SSIM, successfully restoring colors, textures, and contrast in
underwater scenes.

AI.tldr: A frequency-domain SNR-prior framework with FAST and FAT modules (SFormer) enhances underwater images by spectral-aware modulation, outperforming prior methods on standard datasets.
AI.motivation: Spatial-domain SNR priors struggle with cross-channel interference and limited enhancement of informative structures. A frequency-domain approach using amplitude/phase spectra and spectral attention aims to better utilize SNR cues for underwater image enhancement.
AI.method: Proposes FAST (Fourier Attention SNR-prior Transformer) to fuse spectral interactions with SNR cues; FAT (Frequency Adaptive Transformer) bottleneck merges low- and high-frequency branches via gated attention. These modules are embedded in a U-shaped architecture with a conventional RGB stream and an SNR-guided branch to form SFormer. Trained on 4,800 paired images from UIEB, EUVP, and LSUI.
AI.result: Outperforms recent UIE methods, achieving a 3.1 dB PSNR gain and 0.08 SSIM improvement on standard benchmarks, effectively restoring colors, textures, and contrast in underwater scenes.
AI.conclusion: The frequency-domain SNR-prior integration within a Transformer-based U-Net (SFormer) provides significant perceptual and objective gains for underwater image enhancement, validating the effectiveness of spectral SNR priors over traditional spatial-domain approaches.

title: A Note on Graphon-Signal Analysis of Graph Neural Networks
summary:
A recent paper, ``A Graphon-Signal Analysis of Graph Neural Networks'', by
Levie, analyzed message passing graph neural networks (MPNNs) by embedding the
input space of MPNNs, i.e., attributed graphs (graph-signals), to a space of
attributed graphons (graphon-signals). Based on extensions of standard results
in graphon analysis to graphon-signals, the paper proved a generalization bound
and a sampling lemma for MPNNs. However, there are some missing ingredients in
that paper, limiting its applicability in practical settings of graph machine
learning. In the current paper, we introduce several refinements and extensions
to existing results that address these shortcomings. In detail, 1) we extend
the main results in the paper to graphon-signals with multidimensional signals
(rather than 1D signals), 2) we extend the Lipschitz continuity to MPNNs with
readout with respect to cut distance (rather than MPNNs without readout with
respect to cut metric), 3) we improve the generalization bound by utilizing
robustness-type generalization bounds, and 4) we extend the analysis to
non-symmetric graphons and kernels.

AI.tldr: Extends graphon-signal GNN theory to multidimensional signals, readout with cut distance, robustness-based generalization bounds, and non-symmetric graphons/kernels, addressing prior practical gaps.
AI.motivation: The prior work by Levy established key generalization and sampling results but omitted aspects essential for real-world GNNs; this paper aims to make the theory more applicable by covering multidimensional signals, readout impact, robust generalization, and non-symmetric graphons/kernels.
AI.method: Theoretical extensions: (1) generalize core results to multidimensional graphon-signals; (2) generalize Lipschitz continuity to MPNNs with readout w.r.t cut distance; (3) derive robustness-based generalization bounds; (4) extend analysis to non-symmetric graphons and kernels.
AI.result: New bounds and guarantees holding under broader conditions; improved generalization bounds; extended framework enabling practical analysis of GNNs on a wider class of graph signals and structures.
AI.conclusion: The paper fills missing ingredients, broadens the applicability of graphon-signal analysis for GNNs, and provides stronger theoretical guarantees for generalization and sampling in more realistic settings.

title: STARec: An Efficient Agent Framework for Recommender Systems via Autonomous Deliberate Reasoning
summary:
While modern recommender systems are instrumental in navigating information
abundance, they remain fundamentally limited by static user modeling and
reactive decision-making paradigms. Current large language model (LLM)-based
agents inherit these shortcomings through their overreliance on heuristic
pattern matching, yielding recommendations prone to shallow correlation bias,
limited causal inference, and brittleness in sparse-data scenarios. We
introduce STARec, a slow-thinking augmented agent framework that endows
recommender systems with autonomous deliberative reasoning capabilities. Each
user is modeled as an agent with parallel cognitions: fast response for
immediate interactions and slow reasoning that performs chain-of-thought
rationales. To cultivate intrinsic slow thinking, we develop anchored
reinforcement training - a two-stage paradigm combining structured knowledge
distillation from advanced reasoning models with preference-aligned reward
shaping. This hybrid approach scaffolds agents in acquiring foundational
capabilities (preference summarization, rationale generation) while enabling
dynamic policy adaptation through simulated feedback loops. Experiments on
MovieLens 1M and Amazon CDs benchmarks demonstrate that STARec achieves
substantial performance gains compared with state-of-the-art baselines, despite
using only 0.4% of the full training data.

AI.tldr: STARec introduces slow-thinking augmented agents for recommender systems with parallel fast and slow cognition and anchored reinforcement training, achieving strong, data-efficient improvements on MovieLens 1M and Amazon CDs.
AI.motivation: Current recommender systems suffer from static user modeling and reactive decision-making. LLM-based agents over-rely on pattern matching, leading to shallow correlations, limited causal inference, and brittleness in sparse data.
AI.method: Per-user agents with parallel fast responses and slow reasoning that generates chain-of-thought rationales. Anchored reinforcement training: a two-stage paradigm combining structured knowledge distillation from advanced reasoning models with preference-aligned reward shaping, plus simulated feedback loops to cultivate foundational capabilities such as preference summarization and rationale generation.
AI.result: Experiments on MovieLens 1M and Amazon CDs show substantial performance gains over state-of-the-art baselines, with only 0.4% of full training data.
AI.conclusion: The STARec framework demonstrates that slow-thinking, deliberative reasoning can enhance recommender systems, enabling dynamic policy adaptation and improved robustness in data-scarce settings.

title: MemoryVLA: Perceptual-Cognitive Memory in Vision-Language-Action Models for Robotic Manipulation
comment: The project is available at https://shihao1895.github.io/MemoryVLA
summary:
Temporal context is essential for robotic manipulation because such tasks are
inherently non-Markovian, yet mainstream VLA models typically overlook it and
struggle with long-horizon, temporally dependent tasks. Cognitive science
suggests that humans rely on working memory to buffer short-lived
representations for immediate control, while the hippocampal system preserves
verbatim episodic details and semantic gist of past experience for long-term
memory. Inspired by these mechanisms, we propose MemoryVLA, a
Cognition-Memory-Action framework for long-horizon robotic manipulation. A
pretrained VLM encodes the observation into perceptual and cognitive tokens
that form working memory, while a Perceptual-Cognitive Memory Bank stores
low-level details and high-level semantics consolidated from it. Working memory
retrieves decision-relevant entries from the bank, adaptively fuses them with
current tokens, and updates the bank by merging redundancies. Using these
tokens, a memory-conditioned diffusion action expert yields temporally aware
action sequences. We evaluate MemoryVLA on 150+ simulation and real-world tasks
across three robots. On SimplerEnv-Bridge, Fractal, and LIBERO-5 suites, it
achieves 71.9%, 72.7%, and 96.5% success rates, respectively, all outperforming
state-of-the-art baselines CogACT and pi-0, with a notable +14.6 gain on
Bridge. On 12 real-world tasks spanning general skills and long-horizon
temporal dependencies, MemoryVLA achieves 84.0% success rate, with long-horizon
tasks showing a +26 improvement over state-of-the-art baseline. Project Page:
https://shihao1895.github.io/MemoryVLA

AI.tldr: MemoryVLA introduces a cognition-memory-action framework for long-horizon robotic manipulation, integrating working memory and a perceptual-cognitive memory bank with a memory-conditioned diffusion action policy. It uses a pretrained VLM to generate tokens, retrieves and fuses memory entries, and updates the memory bank to produce temporally aware actions.
AI.motivation: Robotic manipulation is inherently non-Markovian and current video-language action (VLA) models struggle with long-horizon, temporally dependent tasks. Humans rely on working memory for immediate control and episodic/semantic long-term memory for past experiences. The paper aims to bridge this cognitive divide to improve long-horizon manipulation.
AI.method: A pretrained vision-language model encodes observations into perceptual and cognitive tokens forming a working memory. A perceptual-cognitive memory bank stores low-level details and high-level semantics derived from these tokens. Working memory retrieves decision-relevant entries from the bank, adaptively fuses them with current tokens, and updates the bank by merging redundancies. A memory-conditioned diffusion action expert uses these tokens to generate temporally aware action sequences.
AI.result: MemoryVLA outperforms state-of-the-art baselines CogACT and pi-0 across 150+ tasks on three robots (SimﬂerEnv-Bridge: 71.9%, Fractal: 72.7%, LIBERO-5: 96.5%) with notable gains (e.g., +14.6 on Bridge). It also achieves 84.0% success on 12 real-world tasks, with long-horizon tasks showing a +26 improvement over baselines.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating cognition-inspired working memory and a long-term memory bank with a memory-conditioned planner enables temporally aware, long-horizon robotic manipulation, yielding robust improvements across simulation and real-world tasks.

title: Hierarchical Spatio-temporal Segmentation Network for Ejection Fraction Estimation in Echocardiography Videos
summary:
Automated segmentation of the left ventricular endocardium in
echocardiography videos is a key research area in cardiology. It aims to
provide accurate assessment of cardiac structure and function through Ejection
Fraction (EF) estimation. Although existing studies have achieved good
segmentation performance, their results do not perform well in EF estimation.
In this paper, we propose a Hierarchical Spatio-temporal Segmentation Network
(\ourmodel) for echocardiography video, aiming to improve EF estimation
accuracy by synergizing local detail modeling with global dynamic perception.
The network employs a hierarchical design, with low-level stages using
convolutional networks to process single-frame images and preserve details,
while high-level stages utilize the Mamba architecture to capture
spatio-temporal relationships. The hierarchical design balances single-frame
and multi-frame processing, avoiding issues such as local error accumulation
when relying solely on single frames or neglecting details when using only
multi-frame data. To overcome local spatio-temporal limitations, we propose the
Spatio-temporal Cross Scan (STCS) module, which integrates long-range context
through skip scanning across frames and positions. This approach helps mitigate
EF calculation biases caused by ultrasound image noise and other factors.

AI.tldr: Proposes a Hierarchical Spatio-temporal Segmentation Network to improve EF estimation from echocardiography by combining detailed single-frame processing with global spatio-temporal context, via a Spatio-temporal Cross Scan (STCS) module.
AI.motivation: Current segmentation methods yield good pixel-level accuracy but do not translate into reliable EF estimation; ultrasound noise and artifacts bias EF calculations. A method that fuses local detail with global dynamics could improve EF accuracy.
AI.method: A hierarchical architecture: low-level CNNs handle single-frame detail; high-level stages use the Mamba architecture to model spatio-temporal relationships. Introduces Spatio-temporal Cross Scan (STCS) to perform skip scanning across frames and spatial positions to inject long-range context and reduce noise-induced biases.
AI.result: The framework is designed to improve EF estimation by balancing local detail and global dynamics and by mitigating EF biases through STCS; aims to demonstrate improved EF accuracy in echocardiography. Quantitative results are not provided in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: The proposed Hierarchical Spatio-temporal Segmentation Network effectively balances single-frame detail and multi-frame dynamics, with the STCS module addressing local spatio-temporal limitations and reducing EF estimation biases in echocardiography.

title: Improving Long-term Autoregressive Spatiotemporal Predictions: A Proof of Concept with Fluid Dynamics
summary:
Data-driven methods are emerging as efficient alternatives to traditional
numerical forecasting, offering fast inference and lower computational cost.
Yet, for complex systems, long-term accuracy often deteriorates due to error
accumulation, and autoregressive training (though effective) demands large GPU
memory and may sacrifice short-term performance. We propose the Stochastic
PushForward (SPF) framework, which retains one-step-ahead training while
enabling multi-step learning. SPF builds a supplementary dataset from model
predictions and combines it with ground truth via a stochastic acquisition
strategy, balancing short- and long-term performance while reducing
overfitting. Multi-step predictions are precomputed between epochs, keeping
memory usage stable without storing full unrolled sequences. Experiments on the
Burgers' equation and the Shallow Water benchmark show that SPF achieves higher
long-term accuracy than autoregressive methods while lowering memory
requirements, making it promising for resource-limited and complex simulations.

AI.tldr: SPF is a data-driven forecasting framework that preserves one-step training but enables multi-step learning via a stochastic PushForward approach, improving long-term accuracy with lower memory usage.
AI.motivation: Autoregressive data-driven forecasts suffer from error accumulation and high memory demands; need memory-efficient methods that maintain short-term accuracy while improving long-term performance in complex systems.
AI.method: SPF constructs a supplementary dataset from model predictions and ground truth, uses a stochastic acquisition strategy to mix them, precomputes multi-step predictions between epochs to keep memory stable, enabling multi-step learning without storing full unrolled sequences.
AI.result: On Burgers' equation and Shallow Water benchmark, SPF outperforms autoregressive methods in long-term accuracy while reducing memory usage.
AI.conclusion: SPF demonstrates promise for resource-limited and complex simulations by balancing short- and long-term performance and mitigating overfitting.

title: Judicial Requirements for Generative AI in Legal Reasoning
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are being integrated into professional domains,
yet their limitations in high-stakes fields like law remain poorly understood.
This paper defines the core capabilities that an AI system must possess to
function as a reliable reasoning tool in judicial decision-making. Using the
IRAC (Issue-Rule-Application-Conclusion) model as an analytical framework, the
study focuses on the most challenging phases of legal adjudication: determining
the applicable Rule (R) and performing the Application (A) of that rule to the
facts of a case. From a judicial perspective, the analysis deconstructs legal
reasoning into a series of core requirements, including the ability to select
the correct legal framework across jurisdictions, generate sound arguments
based on the doctrine of legal sources, distinguish ratio decidendi from obiter
dictum in case law, resolve ambiguity arising from general clauses like
"reasonableness", manage conflicting legal provisions, and correctly apply the
burden of proof. The paper then maps various AI enhancement mechanisms, such as
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), multi-agent systems, and neuro-symbolic
AI, to these requirements, assessing their potential to bridge the gap between
the probabilistic nature of LLMs and the rigorous, choice-driven demands of
legal interpretation. The findings indicate that while these techniques can
address specific challenges, significant challenges remain, particularly in
tasks requiring discretion and transparent, justifiable reasoning. Our paper
concludes that the most effective current role for AI in law is a dual one: as
a high-volume assistant for simple, repetitive cases and as a sophisticated
"sparring partner" for human experts in complex matters.

AI.tldr: Defines core AI capabilities for reliable legal reasoning, maps AI-enhancement techniques to IRAC-driven tasks, and concludes AI should serve as a high-volume assistant for simple cases and a sophisticated sparring partner for experts—not a full substitute due to gaps in discretionary, transparent reasoning.
AI.motivation: Address the gap in understanding how LLMs perform in high-stakes legal settings and how AI can be integrated to support, rather than replace, judicial decision-making.
AI.method: Frame legal reasoning via IRAC (Issue-Rule-Application-Conclusion), identify challenging phases (selecting applicable Rule, applying it to facts), decompose into core requirements (jurisdiction-spanning rule selection, source-based argumentation, distinguishing ratio decidendi from obiter, resolving ambiguities, handling conflicting provisions, burden of proof). Then map AI-enhancement techniques (Retrieval-Augmented Generation, multi-agent systems, neuro-symbolic AI) to these requirements and assess their ability to bridge LLM probabilism with rigorous legal interpretation.
AI.result: Techniques can address specific challenges but cannot fully resolve the need for discretion and transparent, justifiable reasoning. AI can help as a high-volume assistant for repetitive tasks and as a sparring partner for complex matters, but substantial gaps remain in achieving reliable, explainable legal decision-making.
AI.conclusion: The optimal current role for AI in law is dual: assist with routine cases and provide advanced, human-in-the-loop support for complex adjudication, until breakthroughs yield fully transparent, accountable AI legal reasoning.

title: Feature-Space Planes Searcher: A Universal Domain Adaptation Framework for Interpretability and Computational Efficiency
summary:
Domain shift, characterized by degraded model performance during transition
from labeled source domains to unlabeled target domains, poses a persistent
challenge for deploying deep learning systems. Current unsupervised domain
adaptation (UDA) methods predominantly rely on fine-tuning feature extractors -
an approach limited by inefficiency, reduced interpretability, and poor
scalability to modern architectures.
  Our analysis reveals that models pretrained on large-scale data exhibit
domain-invariant geometric patterns in their feature space, characterized by
intra-class clustering and inter-class separation, thereby preserving
transferable discriminative structures. These findings indicate that domain
shifts primarily manifest as boundary misalignment rather than feature
degradation.
  Unlike fine-tuning entire pre-trained models - which risks introducing
unpredictable feature distortions - we propose the Feature-space Planes
Searcher (FPS): a novel domain adaptation framework that optimizes decision
boundaries by leveraging these geometric patterns while keeping the feature
encoder frozen. This streamlined approach enables interpretative analysis of
adaptation while substantially reducing memory and computational costs through
offline feature extraction, permitting full-dataset optimization in a single
computation cycle.
  Evaluations on public benchmarks demonstrate that FPS achieves competitive or
superior performance to state-of-the-art methods. FPS scales efficiently with
multimodal large models and shows versatility across diverse domains including
protein structure prediction, remote sensing classification, and earthquake
detection. We anticipate FPS will provide a simple, effective, and
generalizable paradigm for transfer learning, particularly in domain adaptation
tasks. .

AI.tldr: FPS (Feature-space Planes Searcher) freezes the pretrained feature encoder and optimizes decision boundaries in feature space to address domain shift, treating misalignment at the decision boundary as the core issue rather than feature degradation. It achieves competitive performance with much lower compute/memory by offline feature extraction, enabling full-dataset optimization in one pass and scalable, interpretable domain adaptation across diverse tasks.
AI.motivation: Domain shift degrades performance when transferring models from labeled source domains to unlabeled target domains. Traditional unsupervised domain adaptation relies on fine-tuning feature extractors, which is inefficient, reduces interpretability, and scales poorly with modern architectures. Pretrained models exhibit domain-invariant geometric patterns in feature space (intra-class clustering and inter-class separation), suggesting shifts manifest mainly as boundary misalignment rather than feature degradation. There is a need for a simple, scalable adaptation method that preserves the encoder and leverages discriminative geometry.
AI.method: Propose Feature-space Planes Searcher (FPS): freeze the feature encoder and optimize decision boundaries in the frozen feature space. Leverage the observed domain-invariant geometric patterns (intra-class clustering, inter-class separation) to adjust decision boundaries (planes) without modifying the encoder. Use offline feature extraction to enable full-dataset optimization in a single computation cycle, reducing memory and compute costs. The approach allows interpretability of adaptation results and is applicable to large multimodal models across diverse domains.
AI.result: FPS achieves competitive or superior performance to state-of-the-art unsupervised domain adaptation methods on public benchmarks. It scales efficiently with multimodal large models and demonstrates versatility across domains including protein structure prediction, remote sensing classification, and earthquake detection.
AI.conclusion: FPS offers a simple, effective, and generalizable paradigm for transfer learning in domain adaptation. By freezing the feature encoder and focusing on boundary alignment in feature space, it reduces memory/computational demands, enables interpretability, and maintains strong or superior performance across diverse tasks and architectures.

title: Sparse Autoencoders for Low-$N$ Protein Function Prediction and Design
summary:
Predicting protein function from amino acid sequence remains a central
challenge in data-scarce (low-$N$) regimes, limiting machine learning-guided
protein design when only small amounts of assay-labeled sequence-function data
are available. Protein language models (pLMs) have advanced the field by
providing evolutionary-informed embeddings and sparse autoencoders (SAEs) have
enabled decomposition of these embeddings into interpretable latent variables
that capture structural and functional features. However, the effectiveness of
SAEs for low-$N$ function prediction and protein design has not been
systematically studied. Herein, we evaluate SAEs trained on fine-tuned ESM2
embeddings across diverse fitness extrapolation and protein engineering tasks.
We show that SAEs, with as few as 24 sequences, consistently outperform or
compete with their ESM2 baselines in fitness prediction, indicating that their
sparse latent space encodes compact and biologically meaningful representations
that generalize more effectively from limited data. Moreover, steering
predictive latents exploits biological motifs in pLM representations, yielding
top-fitness variants in 83% of cases compared to designing with ESM2 alone.

AI.tldr: Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) on fine-tuned ESM2 embeddings enable better low-N protein-function prediction and design than ESM2 baselines, with strong performance from as few as 24 sequences; steering predictive latents captures motifs leading to top-fitness variants in 83% of cases.
AI.motivation: Address data scarcity in protein function prediction and design. Leverage protein language model embeddings (pLMs) and interpretable sparse latent representations to generalize from limited labeled sequence-function data.
AI.method: Fine-tune ESM2 embeddings, train sparse autoencoders to decompose embeddings into sparse latent variables; evaluate on diverse fitness extrapolation and protein-engineering tasks; compare against ESM2 baselines; explore steering of latent representations to exploit biological motifs.
AI.result: SAEs trained on 24+ sequences consistently outperform or compete with ESM2 baselines for fitness prediction; the sparse latent space encodes compact, biologically meaningful representations that generalize well under data scarcity; steering predictive latents identifies top-fitness variants in 83% of cases.
AI.conclusion: Sparse latent representations learned from fine-tuned pLM embeddings improve low-N function prediction and design, offering better generalization from limited data and actionable motifs for protein engineering.

title: Interactive Evaluation of Large Language Models for Multi-Requirement Software Engineering Tasks
summary:
Standard single-turn, static benchmarks fall short in evaluating the nuanced
capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) on complex tasks such as software
engineering. In this work, we propose a novel interactive evaluation framework
that assesses LLMs on multi-requirement programming tasks through structured,
feedback-driven dialogue. Each task is modeled as a requirement dependency
graph, and an ``interviewer'' LLM, aware of the ground-truth solution, provides
minimal, targeted hints to an ``interviewee'' model to help correct errors and
fulfill target constraints. This dynamic protocol enables fine-grained
diagnostic insights into model behavior, uncovering strengths and systematic
weaknesses that static benchmarks fail to measure. We build on DevAI, a
benchmark of 55 curated programming tasks, by adding ground-truth solutions and
evaluating the relevance and utility of interviewer hints through expert
annotation. Our results highlight the importance of dynamic evaluation in
advancing the development of collaborative code-generating agents.

AI.tldr: An interactive, feedback-driven evaluation framework for LLMs on multi-requirement programming tasks, using a guided dialogue between an interviewer and interviewee, with tasks as requirement dependency graphs; extends DevAI by adding ground-truth solutions and expert-annotated evaluation of hints, yielding fine-grained diagnostic insights beyond static benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Static single-turn benchmarks fail to capture the nuanced, collaborative capabilities needed for software engineering with LLMs. There is a need for dynamic, diagnostic evaluation that can reveal strengths and systematic weaknesses in how LLMs produce, correct, and collaborate on code.
AI.method: Model a task as a requirement dependency graph. Use an interviewer LLM, aware of the ground-truth solution, to provide minimal, targeted hints to an interviewee model. The interview progresses through structured dialogue with the goal of satisfying constraints and fixing errors. The work builds on DevAI by adding ground-truth solutions and evaluating the relevance/utility of interviewer hints via expert annotation.
AI.result: Dynamic evaluation yields fine-grained diagnostic insights into model behavior, revealing strengths and systematic weaknesses that static benchmarks miss. Expert annotations validate the relevance and utility of interviewer hints, underscoring the value of interactive evaluation for developing collaborative code-generating agents.
AI.conclusion: Interactive, feedback-driven evaluation is a valuable complement to static benchmarks for assessing LLMs in software engineering tasks. Ground-truth solutions and expert-annotated hints enable detailed diagnostics and can guide the development of more effective collaborative code-generation agents.

title: Are All Marine Species Created Equal? Performance Disparities in Underwater Object Detection
summary:
Underwater object detection is critical for monitoring marine ecosystems but
poses unique challenges, including degraded image quality, imbalanced class
distribution, and distinct visual characteristics. Not every species is
detected equally well, yet underlying causes remain unclear. We address two key
research questions: 1) What factors beyond data quantity drive class-specific
performance disparities? 2) How can we systematically improve detection of
under-performing marine species? We manipulate the DUO dataset to separate the
object detection task into localization and classification and investigate the
under-performance of the scallop class. Localization analysis using YOLO11 and
TIDE finds that foreground-background discrimination is the most problematic
stage regardless of data quantity. Classification experiments reveal persistent
precision gaps even with balanced data, indicating intrinsic feature-based
challenges beyond data scarcity and inter-class dependencies. We recommend
imbalanced distributions when prioritizing precision, and balanced
distributions when prioritizing recall. Improving under-performing classes
should focus on algorithmic advances, especially within localization modules.
We publicly release our code and datasets.

AI.tldr: Separating localization and classification in underwater object detection reveals localization as the main bottleneck; simply increasing data quantity does not resolve class-wise gaps, and targeted algorithmic improvements are needed.
AI.motivation: To understand why certain marine species (e.g., scallops) are under-detected beyond data quantity and to guide improvements in detector design and dataset balancing.
AI.method: Modify the DUO dataset to decouple localization from classification; evaluate using YOLO11 and TIDE; analyze scallop under-performance; conduct balanced vs. imbalanced classification experiments; derive strategy implications.
AI.result: Foreground-background discrimination is the most problematic stage independent of data quantity; even with balanced data, precision gaps persist in classification, indicating intrinsic feature-based challenges beyond data scarcity and inter-class dependencies.
AI.conclusion: Use imbalanced distributions when precision is prioritized and balanced distributions when recall is prioritized; improvements should focus on localization modules and algorithmic advances; code and datasets are released to support reproducibility.

title: A Novel Deep Hybrid Framework with Ensemble-Based Feature Optimization for Robust Real-Time Human Activity Recognition
summary:
Human Activity Recognition (HAR) plays a pivotal role in various
applications, including smart surveillance, healthcare, assistive technologies,
sports analytics, etc. However, HAR systems still face critical challenges,
including high computational costs, redundant features, and limited scalability
in real-time scenarios. An optimized hybrid deep learning framework is
introduced that integrates a customized InceptionV3, an LSTM architecture, and
a novel ensemble-based feature selection strategy. The proposed framework first
extracts spatial descriptors using the customized InceptionV3 model, which
captures multilevel contextual patterns, region homogeneity, and fine-grained
localization cues. The temporal dependencies across frames are then modeled
using LSTMs to effectively encode motion dynamics. Finally, an ensemble-based
genetic algorithm with Adaptive Dynamic Fitness Sharing and Attention (ADFSA)
is employed to select a compact and optimized feature set by dynamically
balancing objectives such as accuracy, redundancy, uniqueness, and complexity
reduction. Consequently, the selected feature subsets, which are both diverse
and discriminative, enable various lightweight machine learning classifiers to
achieve accurate and robust HAR in heterogeneous environments. Experimental
results on the robust UCF-YouTube dataset, which presents challenges such as
occlusion, cluttered backgrounds, motion dynamics, and poor illumination,
demonstrate good performance. The proposed approach achieves 99.65% recognition
accuracy, reduces features to as few as 7, and enhances inference time. The
lightweight and scalable nature of the HAR system supports real-time deployment
on edge devices such as Raspberry Pi, enabling practical applications in
intelligent, resource-aware environments, including public safety, assistive
technology, and autonomous monitoring systems.

AI.tldr: A hybrid HAR framework combines customized InceptionV3 for spatial features, LSTM for temporal dynamics, and an ensemble-based GA with Adaptive Dynamic Fitness Sharing and Attention (ADFSA) for feature selection, achieving lightweight, real-time HAR on edge devices.
AI.motivation: HAR systems struggle with high computational cost, redundant features, and limited scalability in real-time settings; there is a need for an efficient, scalable, edge-deployable solution.
AI.method: Extract spatial descriptors using a customized InceptionV3 to capture multilevel patterns; model temporal dependencies with LSTM; apply an ensemble-based genetic algorithm with Adaptive Dynamic Fitness Sharing and Attention (ADFSA) to select a compact, diverse, discriminative feature subset; feed lightweight classifiers for HAR.
AI.result: On the UCF-YouTube dataset (challenging due to occlusion, clutter, motion, illumination), the framework achieves 99.65% accuracy, reduces feature count to as few as 7, and improves inference time, enabling real-time edge deployment (e.g., Raspberry Pi).
AI.conclusion: The proposed pipeline provides a scalable, efficient HAR solution that blends deep feature extraction, temporal modeling, and optimized feature selection to support robust, real-time recognition in heterogeneous environments.

title: DrugReasoner: Interpretable Drug Approval Prediction with a Reasoning-augmented Language Model
summary:
Drug discovery is a complex and resource-intensive process, making early
prediction of approval outcomes critical for optimizing research investments.
While classical machine learning and deep learning methods have shown promise
in drug approval prediction, their limited interpretability constraints their
impact. Here, we present DrugReasoner, a reasoning-based large language model
(LLM) built on the LLaMA architecture and fine-tuned with group relative policy
optimization (GRPO) to predict the likelihood of small-molecule approval.
DrugReasoner integrates molecular descriptors with comparative reasoning
against structurally similar approved and unapproved compounds, generating
predictions alongside step-by-step rationales and confidence scores.
DrugReasoner achieved robust performance with an AUC of 0.732 and an F1 score
of 0.729 on the validation set and 0.725 and 0.718 on the test set,
respectively. These results outperformed conventional baselines, including
logistic regression, support vector machine, and k-nearest neighbors and had
competitive performance relative to XGBoost. On an external independent
dataset, DrugReasoner outperformed both baseline and the recently developed
ChemAP model, achieving an AUC of 0.728 and an F1-score of 0.774, while
maintaining high precision and balanced sensitivity, demonstrating robustness
in real-world scenarios. These findings demonstrate that DrugReasoner not only
delivers competitive predictive accuracy but also enhances transparency through
its reasoning outputs, thereby addressing a key bottleneck in AI-assisted drug
discovery. This study highlights the potential of reasoning-augmented LLMs as
interpretable and effective tools for pharmaceutical decision-making.

AI.tldr: DrugReasoner is a GRPO-finetuned LLaMA-based reasoning LLM that combines molecular descriptors with comparative reasoning over similar compounds to predict small-molecule approval, offering predictions with rationales and achieving competitive AUC/F1 across validation, test, and an external dataset.
AI.motivation: Drug discovery is costly and time-consuming; early prediction of approval outcomes can optimize research investments. Interpretability is a major bottleneck for ML approaches in this domain, limiting adoption.
AI.method: A reasoning-based LLM built on the LLaMA architecture and fine-tuned with group relative policy optimization (GRPO). It integrates molecular descriptors with comparative reasoning against structurally similar approved and unapproved compounds.
