ecosystems. It does not teach agents ethics; it enforces them.

AI.tldr: Proposes Governance-as-a-Service (GaaS), a runtime, policy-driven governance layer for multi-agent AI systems that blocks high-risk actions, logs activity, and uses a Trust Factor to modulate trust and penalties, preserving throughput.
AI.motivation: Address structural risk from distributed autonomous AI ecosystems lacking scalable, decoupled governance; existing oversight is reactive, brittle, and hard to generalize across heterogeneous deployments.
AI.method: Introduce GaaS as a modular enforcement layer with declarative rules and a Trust Factor; executes at runtime by intercepting agent outputs without altering model internals or requiring agent cooperation; supports coercive, normative, and adaptive interventions with graduated enforcement and dynamic trust modulation; evaluates via three simulation regimes using open-source models (LLaMA3, Qwen3, DeepSeek-R1) across content generation and financial decision-making; compares baseline (no governance), GaaS-enabled, and adversarial probes; all actions are intercepted, evaluated, and logged for analysis.
AI.result: GaaS reliably blocks or redirects high-risk behaviors while preserving throughput; Trust Factor scores track rule adherence and help isolate and penalize untrustworthy components in multi-agent systems.
AI.conclusion: Governance is best implemented as an infrastructure/runtime service (like compute or storage) to enable interoperable, aligned agent ecosystems; it enforces ethics at runtime rather than teaching them.

title: The Ramon Llull's Thinking Machine for Automated Ideation
summary:
This paper revisits Ramon Llull's Ars combinatoria - a medieval framework for
generating knowledge through symbolic recombination - as a conceptual
foundation for building a modern Llull's thinking machine for research
ideation. Our approach defines three compositional axes: Theme (e.g.,
efficiency, adaptivity), Domain (e.g., question answering, machine
translation), and Method (e.g., adversarial training, linear attention). These
elements represent high-level abstractions common in scientific work -
motivations, problem settings, and technical approaches - and serve as building
blocks for LLM-driven exploration. We mine elements from human experts or
conference papers and show that prompting LLMs with curated combinations
produces research ideas that are diverse, relevant, and grounded in current
literature. This modern thinking machine offers a lightweight, interpretable
tool for augmenting scientific creativity and suggests a path toward
collaborative ideation between humans and AI.

AI.tldr: A modern Llull-inspired system prompts LLMs with curated theme-domain-method combinations to generate diverse, relevant, and literature-grounded research ideas, serving as an interpretable aid for AI-assisted ideation.
AI.motivation: To reframe Ars combinatoria as a practical, interpretable framework for scientific ideation, bridging medieval combinatorial thinking with contemporary LLM-driven creativity and collaborative human–AI exploration.
AI.method: Define three compositional axes (Theme, Domain, Method); mine elements from experts and conference papers; prompt LLMs with curated combinations to generate ideas; assess diversity, relevance, and grounding in current literature.
AI.result: LLMs prompted with curated Theme-Domain-Method combinations produced ideas that are diverse, relevant, and anchored in current literature, providing a lightweight, interpretable tool for augmenting scientific creativity.
AI.conclusion: A modern thinking machine based on Llull’s combinatorics can augment scientific creativity and enable collaborative ideation between humans and AI, offering an interpretable, scalable approach to research ideation.

title: Harnessing Meta-Learning for Controllable Full-Frame Video Stabilization
summary:
Video stabilization remains a fundamental problem in computer vision,
particularly pixel-level synthesis solutions for video stabilization, which
synthesize full-frame outputs, add to the complexity of this task. These
methods aim to enhance stability while synthesizing full-frame videos, but the
inherent diversity in motion profiles and visual content present in each video
sequence makes robust generalization with fixed parameters difficult. To
address this, we present a novel method that improves pixel-level synthesis
video stabilization methods by rapidly adapting models to each input video at
test time. The proposed approach takes advantage of low-level visual cues
available during inference to improve both the stability and visual quality of
the output. Notably, the proposed rapid adaptation achieves significant
performance gains even with a single adaptation pass. We further propose a jerk
localization module and a targeted adaptation strategy, which focuses the
adaptation on high-jerk segments for maximizing stability with fewer adaptation
steps. The proposed methodology enables modern stabilizers to overcome the
longstanding SOTA approaches while maintaining the full frame nature of the
modern methods, while offering users with control mechanisms akin to classical
approaches. Extensive experiments on diverse real-world datasets demonstrate
the versatility of the proposed method. Our approach consistently improves the
performance of various full-frame synthesis models in both qualitative and
quantitative terms, including results on downstream applications.

AI.tldr: A method for fast test-time adaptation of pixel-level video stabilization models, using low-level cues and a jerk-aware localization to adapt only high-jerk segments, achieving state-of-the-art stability while preserving full-frame outputs.
AI.motivation: Fixed-parameter, pixel-level stabilizers struggle to generalize across diverse motion profiles and content; per-video adaptation can boost robustness and visual quality.
AI.method: Rapid test-time adaptation leveraging low-level inference cues; a jerk localization module identifies high-jerk segments; targeted adaptation focuses updates on those segments, often in a single pass, to improve stability with minimal overhead.
AI.result: Consistent performance gains across multiple full-frame synthesis models on diverse real-world datasets, with improved stability and visual quality and positive impact on downstream tasks.
AI.conclusion: The approach enables modern stabilizers to surpass state-of-the-art methods while preserving full-frame outputs and providing user-control mechanisms similar to classical methods.

title: Predicting Drug-Drug Interactions Using Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks: HGNN-DDI
comment:
12 pages, 5 figures. Published in Applied and Computational
  Engineering, Vol. 79, pp. 77-89, July 25, 2024. Licensed under CC BY 4.0
summary:
Drug-drug interactions (DDIs) are a major concern in clinical practice, as
they can lead to reduced therapeutic efficacy or severe adverse effects.
Traditional computational approaches often struggle to capture the complex
relationships among drugs, targets, and biological entities. In this work, we
propose HGNN-DDI, a heterogeneous graph neural network model designed to
predict potential DDIs by integrating multiple drug-related data sources.
HGNN-DDI leverages graph representation learning to model heterogeneous
biomedical networks, enabling effective information propagation across diverse
node and edge types. Experimental results on benchmark DDI datasets demonstrate
that HGNN-DDI outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in prediction accuracy and
robustness, highlighting its potential to support safer drug development and
precision medicine.

AI.tldr: HGNN-DDI uses a heterogeneous graph neural network to integrate diverse drug-related data and predict drug-drug interactions, achieving higher accuracy and robustness than baselines on benchmark datasets.
AI.motivation: DDIs pose safety risks; existing computational approaches struggle to capture complex, heterogeneous relations among drugs, targets, and biological entities; there is a need to leverage heterogeneous biomedical networks for better prediction.
AI.method: Introduce HGNN-DDI, a heterogeneous GNN that models a heterogeneous biomedical network with multiple node and edge types, enabling information propagation across diverse data sources to predict DDIs.
AI.result: On benchmark DDI datasets, HGNN-DDI outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in prediction accuracy and robustness, demonstrating effectiveness and reliability.
AI.conclusion: HGNN-DDI offers a promising approach for safer drug development and precision medicine by accurately predicting DDIs and leveraging diverse biomedical data.

title: The Subset Sum Matching Problem
comment:
Paper accepted at ECAI 2025. This is an extended version that
  includes Supplementary Material
summary:
This paper presents a new combinatorial optimisation task, the Subset Sum
Matching Problem (SSMP), which is an abstraction of common financial
applications such as trades reconciliation. We present three algorithms, two
suboptimal and one optimal, to solve this problem. We also generate a benchmark
to cover different instances of SSMP varying in complexity, and carry out an
experimental evaluation to assess the performance of the approaches.

AI.tldr: New combinatorial optimization task SSMP with three algorithms (two suboptimal, one optimal), plus a varying- complexity benchmark and experimental evaluation.
AI.motivation: Subsumes practical finance reconciliation problems; need reliable methods and realistic benchmarks for subset-sum-like matching.
AI.method: Formulate SSMP; develop two heuristic/suboptimal algorithms and one exact/optimal algorithm; generate a benchmark suite with instances of varying difficulty; conduct experiments to compare approaches.
AI.result: An empirical evaluation is performed to assess the approaches; abstract does not report specific results or metrics.
AI.conclusion: The work introduces SSMP, the three algorithms, a benchmark, and an evaluation framework; no explicit conclusions are stated in the abstract.

title: Toward Robust Medical Fairness: Debiased Dual-Modal Alignment via Text-Guided Attribute-Disentangled Prompt Learning for Vision-Language Models
summary:
Ensuring fairness across demographic groups in medical diagnosis is essential
for equitable healthcare, particularly under distribution shifts caused by
variations in imaging equipment and clinical practice. Vision-language models
(VLMs) exhibit strong generalization, and text prompts encode identity
attributes, enabling explicit identification and removal of sensitive
directions. However, existing debiasing approaches typically address vision and
text modalities independently, leaving residual cross-modal misalignment and
fairness gaps. To address this challenge, we propose DualFairVL, a multimodal
prompt-learning framework that jointly debiases and aligns cross-modal
representations. DualFairVL employs a parallel dual-branch architecture that
separates sensitive and target attributes, enabling disentangled yet aligned
representations across modalities. Approximately orthogonal text anchors are
constructed via linear projections, guiding cross-attention mechanisms to
produce fused features. A hypernetwork further disentangles attribute-related
information and generates instance-aware visual prompts, which encode
dual-modal cues for fairness and robustness. Prototype-based regularization is
applied in the visual branch to enforce separation of sensitive features and
strengthen alignment with textual anchors. Extensive experiments on eight
medical imaging datasets across four modalities show that DualFairVL achieves
state-of-the-art fairness and accuracy under both in- and out-of-distribution
settings, outperforming full fine-tuning and parameter-efficient baselines with
only 3.6M trainable parameters. Code will be released upon publication.

AI.tldr: A multimodal debiasing framework, DualFairVL, jointly debiases and aligns cross-modal representations in vision-language medical models to improve fairness under distribution shifts, with a lightweight, ~3.6M-parameter design.
AI.motivation: Medical diagnosis fairness across demographic groups under distribution shifts due to imaging equipment and practice variation. Current debiasing methods treat vision and text separately, leaving cross-modal misalignment and fairness gaps. A joint, cross-modal approach is needed to ensure fair and robust predictions.
AI.method: DualFairVL uses a parallel dual-branch architecture to disentangle sensitive and target attributes across modalities. It constructs approximately orthogonal text anchors via linear projections to guide cross-attention and fuse features. A hypernetwork disentangles attribute-related information and generates instance-aware visual prompts that encode dual-modal cues. Prototype-based regularization in the visual branch enforces separation of sensitive features and strengthens alignment with textual anchors. The model is trained with eight medical imaging datasets across four modalities and achieves strong fairness and accuracy with about 3.6M trainable parameters.
AI.result: Empirically achieves state-of-the-art fairness and accuracy under both in- and out-of-distribution settings, outperforming full fine-tuning and parameter-efficient baselines while using only 3.6M trainable parameters; code to be released.
AI.conclusion: Joint debiasing and alignment in multimodal vision-language models can deliver robust, fair performance in medical imaging with a compact, parameter-efficient design, suitable for deployment across diverse clinical settings.

title: Federated Learning with Heterogeneous and Private Label Sets
summary:
Although common in real-world applications, heterogeneous client label sets
are rarely investigated in federated learning (FL). Furthermore, in the cases
they are, clients are assumed to be willing to share their entire label sets
with other clients. Federated learning with private label sets, shared only
with the central server, adds further constraints on learning algorithms and
is, in general, a more difficult problem to solve. In this work, we study the
effects of label set heterogeneity on model performance, comparing the public
and private label settings -- when the union of label sets in the federation is
known to clients and when it is not. We apply classical methods for the
classifier combination problem to FL using centralized tuning, adapt common FL
methods to the private label set setting, and discuss the justification of both
approaches under practical assumptions. Our experiments show that reducing the
number of labels available to each client harms the performance of all methods
substantially. Centralized tuning of client models for representational
alignment can help remedy this, but often at the cost of higher variance.
Throughout, our proposed adaptations of standard FL methods perform well,
showing similar performance in the private label setting as the standard
methods achieve in the public setting. This shows that clients can enjoy
increased privacy at little cost to model accuracy.

AI.tldr: Heterogeneous and private label sets in federated learning degrade performance, but adapted methods with centralized tuning maintain accuracy while enhancing privacy.
AI.motivation: Real-world FL often involves clients with different label sets and privacy constraints that prevent sharing full label alphabets. This work investigates how label-set heterogeneity and private-label constraints affect learning, and whether standard FL methods can be effectively adapted.
AI.method: The study compares public vs private label settings and scenarios where the union of label sets is known to clients versus not. It applies classical classifier-combination techniques to FL with centralized tuning, and adapts common FL methods to the private label setting. It analyzes the justification of these approaches under practical assumptions and uses experiments to assess performance and variance.
AI.result: Reducing the number of labels available to each client substantially harms all methods. Centralized tuning for representational alignment can mitigate this harm but often increases variance. The proposed adaptations of standard FL methods perform well, yielding similar accuracy in the private label setting as standard methods achieve in the public setting.
AI.conclusion: Private label settings can yield increased privacy at little cost to accuracy when using the adapted FL methods and centralized tuning proposed in this work."

title: StepWiser: Stepwise Generative Judges for Wiser Reasoning
summary:
As models increasingly leverage multi-step reasoning strategies to solve
complex problems, supervising the logical validity of these intermediate steps
has become a critical research challenge. Process reward models address this by
providing step-by-step feedback, but current approaches have two major
drawbacks: they typically function as classifiers without providing
explanations, and their reliance on supervised fine-tuning with static datasets
limits generalization. Inspired by recent advances, we reframe stepwise reward
modeling from a classification task to a reasoning task itself. We thus propose
a generative judge that reasons about the policy model's reasoning steps (i.e.,
meta-reasons), outputting thinking tokens before delivering a final verdict.
Our model, StepWiser, is trained by reinforcement learning using relative
outcomes of rollouts. We show it provides (i) better judgment accuracy on
intermediate steps than existing methods; (ii) can be used to improve the
policy model at training time; and (iii) improves inference-time search.

AI.tldr: StepWiser is a generative judge that reasons about a model's step-by-step reasoning (meta-reasons), outputting thinking tokens before verdict; trained with RL on rollout outcomes to improve intermediate-step judgment, policy training, and search.
AI.motivation: Current process reward models are mostly classifiers that lack explanations and generalization; there's a need for reasoned, interpretable feedback to guide multi-step reasoning models.
AI.method: Replace classification with a generative reasoning task: a meta-reasoning judge outputs thinking tokens (meta-reasons) prior to giving a final verdict; trained via reinforcement learning using relative rollout outcomes.
AI.result: Better judgment accuracy on intermediate steps than prior methods; can be used to improve the policy during training; enhances inference-time search.
AI.conclusion: Framing stepwise reward modeling as a reasoning task yields interpretable meta-reasoning feedback and practical benefits for training and inference in multi-step reasoning systems.

title: DQEN: Dual Query Enhancement Network for DETR-based HOI Detection
summary:
Human-Object Interaction (HOI) detection focuses on localizing human-object
pairs and recognizing their interactions. Recently, the DETR-based framework
has been widely adopted in HOI detection. In DETR-based HOI models, queries
with clear meaning are crucial for accurately detecting HOIs. However, prior
works have typically relied on randomly initialized queries, leading to vague
representations that limit the model's effectiveness. Meanwhile, humans in the
HOI categories are fixed, while objects and their interactions are variable.
Therefore, we propose a Dual Query Enhancement Network (DQEN) to enhance object
and interaction queries. Specifically, object queries are enhanced with
object-aware encoder features, enabling the model to focus more effectively on
humans interacting with objects in an object-aware way. On the other hand, we
design a novel Interaction Semantic Fusion module to exploit the HOI candidates
that are promoted by the CLIP model. Semantic features are extracted to enhance
the initialization of interaction queries, thereby improving the model's
ability to understand interactions. Furthermore, we introduce an Auxiliary
Prediction Unit aimed at improving the representation of interaction features.
Our proposed method achieves competitive performance on both the HICO-Det and
the V-COCO datasets. The source code is available at
https://github.com/lzzhhh1019/DQEN.

AI.tldr: Introduces Dual Query Enhancement Network (DQEN) for DETR-based HOI detection, enriching both object and interaction queries to better localize human-object pairs and recognize interactions.
AI.motivation: In DETR-based HOI models, randomly initialized queries yield vague representations, limiting detection performance; HOI categories are fixed for humans but objects/interactions vary, necessitating targeted query improvements.
AI.method: Enhances object queries with object-aware encoder features; introduces Interaction Semantic Fusion that leverages CLIP-promoted HOI candidates to seed interaction queries with semantic features; adds Auxiliary Prediction Unit to strengthen interaction representations.
AI.result: Achieves competitive performance on HOI benchmarks HICO-Det and V-COCO; code released at GitHub.
AI.conclusion: DQEN demonstrates that dual, semantics-informed query enhancement can significantly improve DETR-based HOI detection by producing more informative object- and interaction-specific queries.

title: SWiFT: Soft-Mask Weight Fine-tuning for Bias Mitigation
comment:
Accepted for publication at the Journal of Machine Learning for
  Biomedical Imaging (MELBA) https://melba-journal.org/2025:015
summary:
Recent studies have shown that Machine Learning (ML) models can exhibit bias
in real-world scenarios, posing significant challenges in ethically sensitive
domains such as healthcare. Such bias can negatively affect model fairness,
model generalization abilities and further risks amplifying social
discrimination. There is a need to remove biases from trained models. Existing
debiasing approaches often necessitate access to original training data and
need extensive model retraining; they also typically exhibit trade-offs between
model fairness and discriminative performance. To address these challenges, we
propose Soft-Mask Weight Fine-Tuning (SWiFT), a debiasing framework that
efficiently improves fairness while preserving discriminative performance with
much less debiasing costs. Notably, SWiFT requires only a small external
dataset and only a few epochs of model fine-tuning. The idea behind SWiFT is to
first find the relative, and yet distinct, contributions of model parameters to
both bias and predictive performance. Then, a two-step fine-tuning process
updates each parameter with different gradient flows defined by its
contribution. Extensive experiments with three bias sensitive attributes
(gender, skin tone, and age) across four dermatological and two chest X-ray
datasets demonstrate that SWiFT can consistently reduce model bias while
achieving competitive or even superior diagnostic accuracy under common
fairness and accuracy metrics, compared to the state-of-the-art. Specifically,
we demonstrate improved model generalization ability as evidenced by superior
performance on several out-of-distribution (OOD) datasets.

AI.tldr: SWiFT provides data-efficient debiasing via soft-mask weight fine-tuning that preserves accuracy while reducing bias, using a small external dataset, few fine-tuning epochs, and showing improved out-of-distribution generalization.
AI.motivation: Bias in ML models in ethically sensitive domains and limitations of existing debiasing methods (data requirements, costly retraining, fairness-accuracy trade-offs) drive the need for a lightweight, effective approach.
AI.method: Identify relative contributions of model parameters to bias and predictive performance and apply a two-step gradient flow to update each parameter with distinct objectives, using a small external dataset and only a few fine-tuning epochs.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation on three bias-sensitive attributes (gender, skin tone, age) across dermatology and chest X-ray datasets shows consistent bias reduction while maintaining or improving diagnostic accuracy; improved generalization on several out-of-distribution datasets and favorable comparisons to state-of-the-art baselines.
AI.conclusion: Soft-Mask Weight Fine-Tuning (SWiFT) is a data-efficient debiasing framework that reduces bias with minimal retraining cost and preserves discriminative performance, while enhancing generalization.

title: Model Context Protocols in Adaptive Transport Systems: A Survey
summary:
The rapid expansion of interconnected devices, autonomous systems, and AI
applications has created severe fragmentation in adaptive transport systems,
where diverse protocols and context sources remain isolated. This survey
provides the first systematic investigation of the Model Context Protocol (MCP)
as a unifying paradigm, highlighting its ability to bridge protocol-level
adaptation with context-aware decision making. Analyzing established
literature, we show that existing efforts have implicitly converged toward
MCP-like architectures, signaling a natural evolution from fragmented solutions
to standardized integration frameworks. We propose a five-category taxonomy
covering adaptive mechanisms, context-aware frameworks, unification models,
integration strategies, and MCP-enabled architectures. Our findings reveal
three key insights: traditional transport protocols have reached the limits of
isolated adaptation, MCP's client-server and JSON-RPC structure enables
semantic interoperability, and AI-driven transport demands integration
paradigms uniquely suited to MCP. Finally, we present a research roadmap
positioning MCP as a foundation for next-generation adaptive, context-aware,
and intelligent transport infrastructures.

AI.tldr: Survey proposing Model Context Protocol (MCP) as unifying paradigm for adaptive transport systems; introduces taxonomy and roadmap.
AI.motivation: Fragmentation from isolated protocols and context sources hinders interoperability; AI-driven transport requires integrated, context-aware decision making.
AI.method: Systematic literature analysis of existing adaptive transport efforts; synthesis into MCP-centric framework; development of a five-category taxonomy; derivation of insights and roadmap.
AI.result: Evidence of convergence toward MCP-like architectures; a five-category MCP taxonomy; three key insights, including semantic interoperability via MCP's client-server/JSON-RPC design; a roadmap for MCP-enabled, intelligent transport infrastructures.
AI.conclusion: MCP can serve as a foundation for next-generation adaptive, context-aware, and intelligent transport systems, enabling standardized integration and bridging protocol-level adaptation with context-aware decisions.

title: DRMD: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Malware Detection under Concept Drift
summary:
Malware detection in real-world settings must deal with evolving threats,
limited labeling budgets, and uncertain predictions. Traditional classifiers,
without additional mechanisms, struggle to maintain performance under concept
drift in malware domains, as their supervised learning formulation cannot
optimize when to defer decisions to manual labeling and adaptation. Modern
malware detection pipelines combine classifiers with monthly active learning
(AL) and rejection mechanisms to mitigate the impact of concept drift. In this
work, we develop a novel formulation of malware detection as a one-step Markov
Decision Process and train a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agent,
simultaneously optimizing sample classification performance and rejecting
high-risk samples for manual labeling. We evaluated the joint detection and
drift mitigation policy learned by the DRL-based Malware Detection (DRMD) agent
through time-aware evaluations on Android malware datasets subject to realistic
drift requiring multi-year performance stability. The policies learned under
these conditions achieve a higher Area Under Time (AUT) performance compared to
standard classification approaches used in the domain, showing improved
resilience to concept drift. Specifically, the DRMD agent achieved a
$5.18\pm5.44$, $14.49\pm12.86$, and $10.06\pm10.81$ average AUT performance
improvement for the classification only, classification with rejection, and
classification with rejection and AL settings, respectively. Our results
demonstrate for the first time that DRL can facilitate effective malware
detection and improved resiliency to concept drift in the dynamic environment
of the Android malware domain.

AI.tldr: A DRL-based malware detector (DRMD) jointly optimizes classification and rejection under concept drift, framed as a one-step MDP, achieving higher time-aware AUT than standard methods in Android malware.
AI.motivation: Malware detection must cope with evolving threats, limited labeling budgets, and uncertain predictions. Traditional supervised classifiers degrade under concept drift because they cannot optimize when to request manual labeling or adaptation. Integrating rejection and active learning with decision-making can improve long-term performance.
AI.method: Formulate malware detection as a one-step Markov Decision Process and train a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) agent (DRMD) to simultaneously maximize classification accuracy and minimize high-risk samples sent for manual labeling. Evaluate a drift-aware policy on Android malware datasets with multi-year drift to measure time-aware performance (AUT). Compare against standard classification, classification with rejection, and classification with rejection plus AL.
AI.result: DRMD achieves higher average AUT improvements over time: 5.18±5.44 (classification only), 14.49±12.86 (classification with rejection), and 10.06±10.81 (classification with rejection and AL). These gains demonstrate improved resilience to concept drift.
AI.conclusion: DRL can effectively enable malware detection with greater resiliency to concept drift in Android malware, achieving better time-aware performance and illustrating the value of integrating decision-making and rejection/AL mechanisms.

title: Event-Enriched Image Analysis Grand Challenge at ACM Multimedia 2025
summary:
The Event-Enriched Image Analysis (EVENTA) Grand Challenge, hosted at ACM
Multimedia 2025, introduces the first large-scale benchmark for event-level
multimodal understanding. Traditional captioning and retrieval tasks largely
focus on surface-level recognition of people, objects, and scenes, often
overlooking the contextual and semantic dimensions that define real-world
events. EVENTA addresses this gap by integrating contextual, temporal, and
semantic information to capture the who, when, where, what, and why behind an
image. Built upon the OpenEvents V1 dataset, the challenge features two tracks:
Event-Enriched Image Retrieval and Captioning, and Event-Based Image Retrieval.
A total of 45 teams from six countries participated, with evaluation conducted
through Public and Private Test phases to ensure fairness and reproducibility.
The top three teams were invited to present their solutions at ACM Multimedia
2025. EVENTA establishes a foundation for context-aware, narrative-driven
multimedia AI, with applications in journalism, media analysis, cultural
archiving, and accessibility. Further details about the challenge are available
at the official homepage: https://ltnghia.github.io/eventa/eventa-2025.

AI.tldr: First large-scale benchmark for event-level multimodal understanding (EVENTA) at ACM Multimedia 2025, with two tracks built on OpenEvents V1; 45 teams across 6 countries; phased evaluation; top three invited to present.
AI.motivation: Bridges the gap where existing captioning/retrieval emphasizes surface-level recognition; aims to capture who/when/where/what/why by integrating contextual, temporal, and semantic cues for real-world events.
AI.method: Organize a grand challenge with two tracks: Event-Enriched Image Retrieval and Captioning, and Event-Based Image Retrieval; based on OpenEvents V1; Public and Private Test phases; participants evaluated and top teams invited to present; measures fairness and reproducibility.
AI.result: 45 participating teams from six countries; top three teams invited to present at ACM Multimedia 2025; demonstration of context-aware, narrative-driven multimedia AI concepts; availability of challenge details on official homepage.
AI.conclusion: EVENTA establishes a foundation for context-aware, narrative-driven multimedia AI with practical applications; invites broader adoption and further research in journalism, media analysis, cultural archiving, and accessibility.

title: Recycling History: Efficient Recommendations from Contextual Dueling Bandits
summary:
The contextual duelling bandit problem models adaptive recommender systems,
where the algorithm presents a set of items to the user, and the user's choice
reveals their preference. This setup is well suited for implicit choices users
make when navigating a content platform, but does not capture other possible
comparison queries. Motivated by the fact that users provide more reliable
feedback after consuming items, we propose a new bandit model that can be
described as follows. The algorithm recommends one item per time step; after
consuming that item, the user is asked to compare it with another item chosen
from the user's consumption history. Importantly, in our model, this comparison
item can be chosen without incurring any additional regret, potentially leading
to better performance. However, the regret analysis is challenging because of
the temporal dependency in the user's history. To overcome this challenge, we
first show that the algorithm can construct informative queries provided the
history is rich, i.e., satisfies a certain diversity condition. We then show
that a short initial random exploration phase is sufficient for the algorithm
to accumulate a rich history with high probability. This result, proven via
matrix concentration bounds, yields $O(\sqrt{T})$ regret guarantees.
Additionally, our simulations show that reusing past items for comparisons can
lead to significantly lower regret than only comparing between simultaneously
recommended items.

AI.tldr: A new contextual bandit model for recommendations where each step yields a user choice and a comparison with a past item; with a short exploration phase and richness of history, the method achieves sqrt(T) regret and benefits from reusing past items for comparisons.
AI.motivation: To capture richer user feedback than standard implicit choices by allowing the user to compare a just-consumed item with a past item from history, without incurring extra regret, and to overcome temporal dependencies via a history-rich, diversified dataset.
AI.method: Propose a bandit framework where at each step an item is recommended and then compared to a past item from the history; ensure the history is rich (diverse); use a short initial random exploration to accumulate such a history; employ matrix concentration bounds to analyze regret; show the algorithm can construct informative queries from history.
AI.result: Theoretical regret bound of O(√T) with high probability; simulations indicate that reusing past items for comparisons significantly lowers regret compared to only comparing items presented in the same round.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating past-item comparisons enables more informative feedback and improved regret performance, provided the history is sufficiently diverse; a short exploration phase suffices to build this richness, suggesting practical gains in adaptive recommendation systems.

title: Preliminary Study on Space Utilization and Emergent Behaviors of Group vs. Single Pedestrians in Real-World Trajectories
summary:
This study presents an initial framework for distinguishing group and single
pedestrians based on real-world trajectory data, with the aim of analyzing
their differences in space utilization and emergent behavioral patterns. By
segmenting pedestrian trajectories into fixed time bins and applying a
Transformer-based pair classification model, we identify cohesive groups and
isolate single pedestrians over a structured sequence-based filtering process.
To prepare for deeper analysis, we establish a comprehensive metric framework
incorporating both spatial and behavioral dimensions. Spatial utilization
metrics include convex hull area, smallest enclosing circle radius, and
heatmap-based spatial densities to characterize how different pedestrian types
occupy and interact with space. Behavioral metrics such as velocity change,
motion angle deviation, clearance radius, and trajectory straightness are
designed to capture local adaptations and responses during interactions.
Furthermore, we introduce a typology of encounter types-single-to-single,
single-to-group, and group-to-group to categorize and later quantify different
interaction scenarios. Although this version focuses primarily on the
classification pipeline and dataset structuring, it establishes the groundwork
for scalable analysis across different sequence lengths 60, 100, and 200
frames. Future versions will incorporate complete quantitative analysis of the
proposed metrics and their implications for pedestrian simulation and space
design validation in crowd dynamics research.

AI.tldr: A framework to distinguish group vs. single pedestrians from real-world trajectories using Transformer-based pair classification, with a structured metric suite and encounter typology, aimed at scalable analysis across multiple sequence lengths.
AI.motivation: Understand space utilization and interaction patterns in crowds; inform pedestrian simulation and space design.
AI.method: Segment trajectories into fixed time bins; apply Transformer-based pair classification to identify cohesive groups; develop a metric framework with spatial (convex hull area, smallest enclosing circle radius, heatmap densities) and behavioral (velocity change, motion angle deviation, clearance radius, trajectory straightness) metrics; define encounter typology (single-to-single, single-to-group, group-to-group); examine sequence lengths 60, 100, 200 frames; dataset structuring; plan for future quantitative analysis.
AI.result: Presents an initial classification pipeline and dataset structuring; establishes groundwork for metric-based analysis; quantitative results and full validation deferred to future work.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a scalable framework for analyzing group vs. single pedestrian dynamics and paves the way for quantitative evaluations and design validations in crowd dynamics.

title: C-Flat++: Towards a More Efficient and Powerful Framework for Continual Learning
summary:
Balancing sensitivity to new tasks and stability for retaining past knowledge
is crucial in continual learning (CL). Recently, sharpness-aware minimization
has proven effective in transfer learning and has also been adopted in
continual learning (CL) to improve memory retention and learning efficiency.
However, relying on zeroth-order sharpness alone may favor sharper minima over
flatter ones in certain settings, leading to less robust and potentially
suboptimal solutions. In this paper, we propose \textbf{C}ontinual
\textbf{Flat}ness (\textbf{C-Flat}), a method that promotes flatter loss
landscapes tailored for CL. C-Flat offers plug-and-play compatibility, enabling
easy integration with minimal modifications to the code pipeline. Besides, we
present a general framework that integrates C-Flat into all major CL paradigms
and conduct comprehensive comparisons with loss-minima optimizers and
flat-minima-based CL methods. Our results show that C-Flat consistently
improves performance across a wide range of settings. In addition, we introduce
C-Flat++, an efficient yet effective framework that leverages selective
flatness-driven promotion, significantly reducing the update cost required by
C-Flat. Extensive experiments across multiple CL methods, datasets, and
scenarios demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our proposed
approaches. Code is available at https://github.com/WanNaa/C-Flat.

AI.tldr: Introduces C-Flat, a flatness-promoting, plug-and-play framework for continual learning that yields flatter loss landscapes, improving stability and performance; also C-Flat++ with selective flatness promotion for efficiency. Demonstrated across CL paradigms and datasets; code available.
AI.motivation: Continual learning struggles with balancing memory retention and adaptability (stability-plasticity). Zeroth-order sharpness minimization can bias models toward sharper minima in some settings, risking robustness and suboptimal solutions. There is a need for flatness-aware optimization tailored to continual learning that can be integrated easily with existing CL pipelines.
AI.method: Proposes C-Flat, a flatness-promoting approach that can be plugged into existing CL workflows. It offers a general framework for integrating flatness-driven optimization across major continual learning paradigms. Additionally, C-Flat++ introduces selective flatness promotion to reduce update costs while retaining benefits.
AI.result: Empirical results show consistent performance improvements across a wide range of CL settings, methods, and datasets. C-Flat is easy to integrate; C-Flat++ achieves further efficiency gains with selective promotion. Code is released at the provided GitHub repository.
AI.conclusion: C-Flat and C-Flat++ provide practical, versatile flatness-aware solutions for continual learning, offering improved stability and performance with broad compatibility and reasonable computational cost. The work highlights the value of loss-landscape flatness considerations in CL and provides a path for future efficiency-focused refinements.

title: The point is the mask: scaling coral reef segmentation with weak supervision
summary:
Monitoring coral reefs at large spatial scales remains an open challenge,
essential for assessing ecosystem health and informing conservation efforts.
While drone-based aerial imagery offers broad spatial coverage, its limited
resolution makes it difficult to reliably distinguish fine-scale classes, such
as coral morphotypes. At the same time, obtaining pixel-level annotations over
large spatial extents is costly and labor-intensive, limiting the scalability
of deep learning-based segmentation methods for aerial imagery. We present a
multi-scale weakly supervised semantic segmentation framework that addresses
this challenge by transferring fine-scale ecological information from
underwater imagery to aerial data. Our method enables large-scale coral reef
mapping from drone imagery with minimal manual annotation, combining
classification-based supervision, spatial interpolation and self-distillation
techniques. We demonstrate the efficacy of the approach, enabling large-area
segmentation of coral morphotypes and demonstrating flexibility for integrating
new classes. This study presents a scalable, cost-effective methodology for
high-resolution reef monitoring, combining low-cost data collection, weakly
supervised deep learning and multi-scale remote sensing.

AI.tldr: A scalable weakly supervised framework that transfers fine-scale underwater coral morphotype information to drone imagery for high-resolution reef mapping with minimal labeling.
AI.motivation: Monitoring coral reefs at large spatial scales is essential but challenging: drone imagery provides broad coverage but lacks fine-scale resolution; pixel-level annotations are costly. A scalable approach is needed to map coral morphotypes across large areas with minimal manual labeling.
AI.method: A multi-scale weakly supervised semantic segmentation framework that transfers fine-scale ecological information from underwater imagery to aerial data. It combines classification-based supervision, spatial interpolation and self-distillation to enable large-area coral morphotype mapping with minimal annotations and to flexibly incorporate new classes.
AI.result: Demonstrates the efficacy of the approach for large-area segmentation of coral morphotypes and shows flexibility to integrate new classes; presents a scalable, cost-effective workflow for high-resolution reef monitoring.
AI.conclusion: Provides a scalable and cost-effective methodology for high-resolution reef monitoring by integrating low-cost data collection, weakly supervised deep learning, and multi-scale remote sensing, enabling large-scale, fine-grained coral mapping with limited labeled data.

title: MOCHA: Discovering Multi-Order Dynamic Causality in Temporal Point Processes
summary:
Discovering complex causal dependencies in temporal point processes (TPPs) is
critical for modeling real-world event sequences. Existing methods typically
rely on static or first-order causal structures, overlooking the multi-order
and time-varying nature of causal relationships. In this paper, we propose
MOCHA, a novel framework for discovering multi-order dynamic causality in TPPs.
MOCHA characterizes multi-order influences as multi-hop causal paths over a
latent time-evolving graph. To model such dynamics, we introduce a time-varying
directed acyclic graph (DAG) with learnable structural weights, where
acyclicity and sparsity constraints are enforced to ensure structural validity.
We design an end-to-end differentiable framework that jointly models causal
discovery and TPP dynamics, enabling accurate event prediction and revealing
interpretable structures. Extensive experiments on real-world datasets
demonstrate that MOCHA not only achieves state-of-the-art performance in event
prediction, but also reveals meaningful and interpretable causal structures.

AI.tldr: MOCHA discovers multi-order dynamic causality in temporal point processes by modeling multi-hop causal paths on a latent time-evolving graph with a time-varying DAG and learnable weights, achieving state-of-the-art event prediction and yielding interpretable causal structures.
AI.motivation: Current approaches rely on static or first-order causal assumptions and fail to capture multi-order, time-varying dependencies in event sequences; a dynamic, multi-hop causal representation is needed for accurate prediction and interpretability.
AI.method: MOCHA introduces a time-varying directed acyclic graph with learnable structural weights to model multi-hop causal paths over a latent evolving graph; enforces acyclicity and sparsity for valid structure; offers an end-to-end differentiable framework jointly modeling causal discovery and TPP dynamics.
AI.result: Experiments on real-world datasets show state-of-the-art performance in event prediction and yield meaningful, interpretable causal structures.
AI.conclusion: MOCHA provides a scalable, interpretable framework for discovering multi-order dynamic causality in temporal point processes by leveraging a time-varying DAG to capture multi-hop influences, achieving strong predictive performance and interpretable insights.

title: Generative AI in Map-Making: A Technical Exploration and Its Implications for Cartographers
summary:
Traditional map-making relies heavily on Geographic Information Systems
(GIS), requiring domain expertise and being time-consuming, especially for
repetitive tasks. Recent advances in generative AI (GenAI), particularly image
diffusion models, offer new opportunities for automating and democratizing the
map-making process. However, these models struggle with accurate map creation
due to limited control over spatial composition and semantic layout. To address
this, we integrate vector data to guide map generation in different styles,
specified by the textual prompts. Our model is the first to generate accurate
maps in controlled styles, and we have integrated it into a web application to
improve its usability and accessibility. We conducted a user study with
professional cartographers to assess the fidelity of generated maps, the
usability of the web application, and the implications of ever-emerging GenAI
in map-making. The findings have suggested the potential of our developed
application and, more generally, the GenAI models in helping both non-expert
users and professionals in creating maps more efficiently. We have also
outlined further technical improvements and emphasized the new role of
cartographers to advance the paradigm of AI-assisted map-making.

AI.tldr: Diffusion-model-based map generation guided by vector data to create style-controlled, accurate maps, integrated into a web app and validated by cartographers.
AI.motivation: Traditional map-making is GIS-intensive and time-consuming; GenAI offers automation but struggles with spatial composition; there's a need for controllable, accessible tools that bridge experts and non-experts.
AI.method: Leverage vector data to steer diffusion-based map generation; allow style control via textual prompts; build a web application; evaluate through a user study with professional cartographers focusing on fidelity, usability, and broader implications.
AI.result: Maps generated with vector-guided prompts achieve fidelity in controlled styles; users reported usable web app; evidence of GenAI's potential to assist both professionals and non-experts; identifies improvements and roles for cartographers.
AI.conclusion: GenAI-enabled, vector-guided map-making can democratize and accelerate cartography, but requires refinement; future work includes technical improvements and redefining the cartographer’s role in AI-assisted workflows.

title: HAEPO: History-Aggregated Exploratory Policy Optimization
summary:
Exploration is essential in modern learning, from reinforcement learning
environments with small neural policies to large language models (LLMs).
Existing work, such as DPO, leverages full sequence log-likelihoods to capture
an entire trajectory of the model's decisions, while methods like GRPO
aggregate per-token ratios into a trajectory-level update. However, both often
limit exploration on long-horizon tasks. We introduce History-Aggregated
Exploratory Policy Optimization (HAEPO), a history-aware exploratory loss to
combat these shortcomings. HAEPO compresses each trajectory into the sum of its
logarithmic probabilities (a cumulative logarithmic likelihood), and applies a
Plackett-Luce softmax across trajectories to obtain normalized weights
proportional to their returns, thus encouraging broader exploration. We add
entropy regularization to stabilize the aggressive updates to prevent premature
collapse and a soft KL penalty relative to a frozen copy of the previous
(reference) policy. Empirically, HAEPO converges fast, explores thoroughly,
aligns closely with true rewards, and demonstrates robust learning behavior
better or at par with PPO, GRPO, and DPO across diverse tasks. Thus, HAEPO
provides a stable and interpretable framework by explicitly leveraging
full-trajectory history while balancing exploration and stability.

AI.tldr: HAEPO introduces a history-aware exploratory objective that compresses each trajectory into its cumulative log-likelihood and uses a Plackett-Luce weighting over trajectories to promote broad exploration, with entropy and soft KL regularization for stability.
AI.motivation: Existing exploration methods (e.g., DPO, GRPO) struggle with long-horizon tasks due to relying on per-token or full-trajectory measures; there is a need for a history-aware balance of exploration and stability that leverages full trajectory history.
AI.method: HAEPO compresses each trajectory into the sum of logarithmic probabilities (cumulative log-likelihood); applies a Plackett-Luce softmax across trajectories to weight updates by returns; adds entropy regularization to stabilize aggressive updates and a soft KL penalty relative to a frozen copy of the previous policy.
AI.result: Empirically, HA EPO converges fast, explores thoroughly, aligns closely with true rewards, and shows robust learning behavior, performing at least as well as PPO, GRPO, and DPO across diverse tasks.
AI.conclusion: HAEPO provides a stable, interpretable framework that explicitly leverages full-trajectory history to balance exploration and stability, achieving strong long-horizon performance.

title: Enhancing compact convolutional transformers with super attention
summary:
In this paper, we propose a vision model that adopts token mixing,
sequence-pooling, and convolutional tokenizers to achieve state-of-the-art
performance and efficient inference in fixed context-length tasks. In the
CIFAR100 benchmark, our model significantly improves the baseline of the top 1%
and top 5% validation accuracy from 36.50% to 46.29% and 66.33% to 76.31%,
while being more efficient than the Scaled Dot Product Attention (SDPA)
transformers when the context length is less than the embedding dimension and
only 60% the size. In addition, the architecture demonstrates high training
stability and does not rely on techniques such as data augmentation like mixup,
positional embeddings, or learning rate scheduling. We make our code available
on Github.

AI.tldr: Proposes a vision model that uses token mixing, sequence-pooling, and convolutional tokenizers to deliver state-of-the-art performance with efficient inference for fixed context-length tasks, achieving notable CIFAR-100 gains and outperforming SDPA transformers in efficiency; training is stable without common augmentation or positional tricks; code released on GitHub.
AI.motivation: FixContext vision tasks demand high accuracy with low compute, without reliance on data augmentation or positional embeddings. The work targets efficiency and scalability, aiming to surpass SDPA-based transformers while maintaining a compact model footprint.
AI.method: Introduce a vision architecture built around token mixing, sequence-pooling, and convolutional tokenizers designed for fixed context-length inputs. The model emphasizes efficiency (smaller size) and training stability, and avoids data augmentation, positional embeddings, and learning-rate schedules.
AI.result: On CIFAR-100, top-1 accuracy improves from 36.50% to 46.29% and top-5 from 66.33% to 76.31%. The model is more efficient than SDPA transformers when context length < embedding dimension and uses only 60% of the size. The architecture shows high training stability and does not rely on mixup, positional embeddings, or LR scheduling. Code is available on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: The proposed architecture achieves state-of-the-art performance and efficient inference for fixed context-length vision tasks, with clear gains on CIFAR-100 and favorable efficiency characteristics; the approach is reproducible via the public code release.

title: pyFAST: A Modular PyTorch Framework for Time Series Modeling with Multi-source and Sparse Data
summary:
Modern time series analysis demands frameworks that are flexible, efficient,
and extensible. However, many existing Python libraries exhibit limitations in
modularity and in their native support for irregular, multi-source, or sparse
data. We introduce pyFAST, a research-oriented PyTorch framework that
explicitly decouples data processing from model computation, fostering a
cleaner separation of concerns and facilitating rapid experimentation. Its data
engine is engineered for complex scenarios, supporting multi-source loading,
protein sequence handling, efficient sequence- and patch-level padding, dynamic
normalization, and mask-based modeling for both imputation and forecasting.
pyFAST integrates LLM-inspired architectures for the alignment-free fusion of
sparse data sources and offers native sparse metrics, specialized loss
functions, and flexible exogenous data fusion. Training utilities include
batch-based streaming aggregation for evaluation and device synergy to maximize
computational efficiency. A comprehensive suite of classical and deep learning
models (Linears, CNNs, RNNs, Transformers, and GNNs) is provided within a
modular architecture that encourages extension. Released under the MIT license
at GitHub, pyFAST provides a compact yet powerful platform for advancing time
series research and applications.

AI.tldr: pyFAST is a modular, PyTorch-based time series framework that separates data processing from model computation, enabling flexible handling of irregular, multi-source, and sparse data with LLM-inspired fusion and a rich suite of models.
AI.motivation: Current Python time series libraries struggle with modularity and native support for irregular, multi-source, or sparse data, hindering rapid experimentation and complex data workflows.
AI.method: Design a decoupled data engine supporting multi-source loading, sequence/patch padding, dynamic normalization, mask-based modeling, and exogenous data fusion; incorporate LLM-inspired alignment-free fusion for sparse sources; provide native sparse metrics and loss functions; offer batch-based streaming evaluation and device-accelerated training; include a modular set of models (Linear, CNN, RNN, Transformer, GNN) built for easy extension.
AI.result: Release of pyFAST as a MIT-licensed research-oriented PyTorch framework with a rich data engine, native sparse support, flexible losses, and a modular model zoo, designed to accelerate time series research and experimentation.
AI.conclusion: pyFAST delivers a compact yet powerful platform that cleanly separates data processing from modeling, enabling rapid experimentation, extensibility, and efficient handling of complex time-series data scenarios.

title: USO: Unified Style and Subject-Driven Generation via Disentangled and Reward Learning
comment:
Project page: https://bytedance.github.io/USO/ Code and model:
  https://github.com/bytedance/USO
summary:
Existing literature typically treats style-driven and subject-driven
generation as two disjoint tasks: the former prioritizes stylistic similarity,
whereas the latter insists on subject consistency, resulting in an apparent
antagonism. We argue that both objectives can be unified under a single
framework because they ultimately concern the disentanglement and
re-composition of content and style, a long-standing theme in style-driven
research. To this end, we present USO, a Unified Style-Subject Optimized
customization model. First, we construct a large-scale triplet dataset
consisting of content images, style images, and their corresponding stylized
content images. Second, we introduce a disentangled learning scheme that
simultaneously aligns style features and disentangles content from style
through two complementary objectives, style-alignment training and
content-style disentanglement training. Third, we incorporate a style
reward-learning paradigm denoted as SRL to further enhance the model's
performance. Finally, we release USO-Bench, the first benchmark that jointly
evaluates style similarity and subject fidelity across multiple metrics.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that USO achieves state-of-the-art
performance among open-source models along both dimensions of subject
consistency and style similarity. Code and model:
https://github.com/bytedance/USO

AI.tldr: USO unifies style-driven and subject-driven generation by disentangling and recomposing content and style. It builds a triplet dataset, uses style-alignment and content-style disentanglement objectives, adds style reward learning, and introduces USO-Bench to jointly evaluate style similarity and subject fidelity. It achieves state-of-the-art results among open-source models on both dimensions.
AI.motivation: Style-driven and subject-driven generation are typically treated as separate, often conflicting tasks. A unified framework focusing on disentangling content from style can satisfy both stylistic similarity and subject fidelity, advancing stylized content generation.
AI.method: Construct a large-scale triplet dataset (content images, style images, and their stylized content). Employ a disentangled learning scheme with two complementary objectives: (1) style-alignment training to align style features, and (2) content-style disentanglement training to separate content from style. Incorporate a style reward-learning (SRL) paradigm to further enhance performance. Release USO-Bench to jointly evaluate style similarity and subject fidelity across multiple metrics.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show USO achieves state-of-the-art performance among open-source models on both style similarity and subject fidelity, demonstrating effective joint optimization of content and style. Code and model are released.
AI.conclusion: USO provides a unified, effective framework for joint style and subject customization, validated by a new benchmark and strong empirical results, suggesting broad applicability for unified style-subject control.

title: Distance-informed Neural Processes
summary:
We propose the Distance-informed Neural Process (DNP), a novel variant of
Neural Processes that improves uncertainty estimation by combining global and
distance-aware local latent structures. Standard Neural Processes (NPs) often
rely on a global latent variable and struggle with uncertainty calibration and
capturing local data dependencies. DNP addresses these limitations by
introducing a global latent variable to model task-level variations and a local
latent variable to capture input similarity within a distance-preserving latent
space. This is achieved through bi-Lipschitz regularization, which bounds
distortions in input relationships and encourages the preservation of relative
distances in the latent space. This modeling approach allows DNP to produce
better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and more effectively distinguish in-
from out-of-distribution data. Empirical results demonstrate that DNP achieves
strong predictive performance and improved uncertainty calibration across
regression and classification tasks.

AI.tldr: A distance-informed Neural Process (DNP) extends Neural Processes by using a global latent for task-level variation and a distance-aware local latent to model input similarity, regularized with bi-Lipschitz constraints to preserve relationships; results show better uncertainty calibration and predictive performance, including OOD distinction, across regression and classification.
AI.motivation: Standard Neural Processes rely on a single global latent and often struggle with uncertainty calibration and capturing fine-grained local dependencies. There is a need to better model local input relationships and calibrate uncertainty, especially for out-of-distribution detection.
AI.method: Introduce a global latent for task-level variation plus a local latent that encodes input similarity in a distance-preserving latent space. Apply bi-Lipschitz regularization to bound distortions in input relationships and encourage preservation of relative distances.
AI.result: DNP yields better-calibrated uncertainty estimates and improved predictive performance across regression and classification tasks, with improved ability to discriminate in-distribution from out-of-distribution data.
AI.conclusion: Combining global task-level latent and distance-aware local latent structures via bi-Lipschitz regularization improves NP uncertainty calibration and overall performance, demonstrating robust applicability across tasks.

title: Can we make NeRF-based visual localization privacy-preserving?
summary:
Visual localization (VL) is the task of estimating the camera pose in a known
scene. VL methods, a.o., can be distinguished based on how they represent the
scene, e.g., explicitly through a (sparse) point cloud or a collection of
images or implicitly through the weights of a neural network. Recently,
NeRF-based methods have become popular for VL. While NeRFs offer high-quality
novel view synthesis, they inadvertently encode fine scene details, raising
privacy concerns when deployed in cloud-based localization services as
sensitive information could be recovered. In this paper, we tackle this
challenge on two ends. We first propose a new protocol to assess
privacy-preservation of NeRF-based representations. We show that NeRFs trained
with photometric losses store fine-grained details in their geometry
representations, making them vulnerable to privacy attacks, even if the head
that predicts colors is removed. Second, we propose ppNeSF (Privacy-Preserving
Neural Segmentation Field), a NeRF variant trained with segmentation
supervision instead of RGB images. These segmentation labels are learned in a
self-supervised manner, ensuring they are coarse enough to obscure identifiable
scene details while remaining discriminativeness in 3D. The segmentation space
of ppNeSF can be used for accurate visual localization, yielding
state-of-the-art results.

AI.tldr: NeRF-based visual localization (VL) can leak fine-grained scene details when trained with photometric losses; a segmentation-supervised NeRF variant (ppNeSF) preserves privacy while achieving state-of-the-art localization.
AI.motivation: Address privacy risks in NeRF-based VL deployed on cloud services by evaluating how much scene detail is encoded and recoverable, and by designing a privacy-preserving alternative.
AI.method: 1) Propose a protocol to assess privacy-preservation of NeRF-based representations. 2) Show that NeRFs trained with photometric losses store fine-grained geometry details, vulnerable to privacy attacks even if the color head is removed. 3) Introduce ppNeSF (Privacy-Preserving Neural Segmentation Field), a NeRF variant trained with segmentation supervision instead of RGB images; segmentation labels are learned in a self-supervised manner to be coarse enough to obscure identifiable details while remaining discriminative in 3D. The segmentation space is then used for accurate visual localization.
AI.result: Photometric NeRFs encode fine scene details and are vulnerable to privacy attacks. ppNeSF achieves accurate visual localization using a segmentation space and, despite being privacy-preserving, attains state-of-the-art localization performance.
AI.conclusion: Segmentation-based NeRFs offer a practical privacy-preserving alternative for VL, obscuring identifiable details while maintaining high localization accuracy; this balances privacy with utility in cloud-based localization services.

title: Enhancing Model Privacy in Federated Learning with Random Masking and Quantization
summary:
Experimental results across various models and tasks demonstrate that our
approach not only maintains strong model performance in federated learning
settings but also achieves enhanced protection of model parameters compared to
baseline methods.

AI.tldr: A federated learning approach that maintains strong performance while improving protection of model parameters compared with baseline methods.
AI.motivation: Federated learning grapples with the trade-off between model utility and protecting model parameters; there's a need for methods that guard parameters without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.method: Proposes a protection-enhanced FL framework featuring (non-specific) privacy-preserving and robust aggregation mechanisms to safeguard parameters while preserving performance across diverse models and tasks.
AI.result: Empirical results across multiple models and tasks show that the approach sustains high accuracy in FL settings and offers enhanced protection of parameters relative to baselines.
AI.conclusion: The method successfully achieves both competitive performance and stronger parameter protection in federated learning scenarios.

title: Understanding Benefits and Pitfalls of Current Methods for the Segmentation of Undersampled MRI Data
summary:
MR imaging is a valuable diagnostic tool allowing to non-invasively visualize
patient anatomy and pathology with high soft-tissue contrast. However, MRI
acquisition is typically time-consuming, leading to patient discomfort and
increased costs to the healthcare system. Recent years have seen substantial
research effort into the development of methods that allow for accelerated MRI
acquisition while still obtaining a reconstruction that appears similar to the
fully-sampled MR image. However, for many applications a perfectly
reconstructed MR image may not be necessary, particularly, when the primary
goal is a downstream task such as segmentation. This has led to growing
interest in methods that aim to perform segmentation directly on accelerated
MRI data. Despite recent advances, existing methods have largely been developed
in isolation, without direct comparison to one another, often using separate or
private datasets, and lacking unified evaluation standards. To date, no
high-quality, comprehensive comparison of these methods exists, and the optimal
strategy for segmenting accelerated MR data remains unknown. This paper
provides the first unified benchmark for the segmentation of undersampled MRI
data comparing 7 approaches. A particular focus is placed on comparing
\textit{one-stage approaches}, that combine reconstruction and segmentation
into a unified model, with \textit{two-stage approaches}, that utilize
established MRI reconstruction methods followed by a segmentation network. We
test these methods on two MRI datasets that include multi-coil k-space data as
well as a human-annotated segmentation ground-truth. We find that simple
two-stage methods that consider data-consistency lead to the best segmentation
scores, surpassing complex specialized methods that are developed specifically
for this task.

AI.tldr: A unified benchmark shows that for segmenting undersampled MRI data, simple two-stage pipelines with data-consistency outperform complex end-to-end one-stage methods across two datasets.
AI.motivation: There is no high-quality, unified evaluation comparing segmentation methods on accelerated MRI; different studies use private datasets and varying standards, hindering interpretation of what strategy works best.
AI.method: Compare 7 approaches (one-stage vs two-stage) for segmenting undersampled MRI. Use two MRI datasets with multi-coil k-space data and human-annotated segmentation ground-truth. Emphasize data-consistency in reconstruction within two-stage pipelines.
AI.result: Two-stage methods that enforce data-consistency achieve the best segmentation scores, surpassing specialized one-stage methods designed for this task.
AI.conclusion: For segmentation of accelerated MRI, simple two-stage reconstruction-then-segmentation pipelines with data-consistency are superior; the study offers a unified benchmark to guide future work and establish evaluation standards.

title: Generalization Bound for a General Class of Neural Ordinary Differential Equations
summary:
Neural ordinary differential equations (neural ODEs) are a popular type of
deep learning model that operate with continuous-depth architectures. To assess
how well such models perform on unseen data, it is crucial to understand their
generalization error bounds. Previous research primarily focused on the linear
case for the dynamics function in neural ODEs - Marion, P. (2023), or provided
bounds for Neural Controlled ODEs that depend on the sampling interval
Bleistein et al. (2023). In this work, we analyze a broader class of neural
ODEs where the dynamics function is a general nonlinear function, either time
dependent or time independent, and is Lipschitz continuous with respect to the
state variables. We showed that under this Lipschitz condition, the solutions
to neural ODEs have solutions with bounded variations. Based on this
observation, we establish generalization bounds for both time-dependent and
time-independent cases and investigate how overparameterization and domain
constraints influence these bounds. To our knowledge, this is the first
derivation of generalization bounds for neural ODEs with general nonlinear
dynamics.

AI.tldr: Generalization bounds for neural ODEs with nonlinear Lipschitz dynamics, extending beyond prior linear-only analyses.
AI.motivation: To understand how neural ODEs generalize on unseen data when the dynamics are nonlinear, time-dependent or independent, under Lipschitz continuity.
AI.method: Assume the dynamics are Lipschitz; prove solutions have bounded variation; derive generalization bounds for both time-dependent and time-independent cases; analyze effects of overparameterization and domain constraints.
AI.result: First derivation of generalization bounds for neural ODEs with general nonlinear dynamics; bound arises from bounded variation of solutions.
AI.conclusion: Extends generalization theory to a broader class of neural ODEs, informing how architecture choices and constraints influence generalization.

title: Enhancing Document VQA Models via Retrieval-Augmented Generation
comment:
Accepted at Workshop on Machine Learning in Document Analysis and
  Recognition (ICDAR WML 2025), Wuhan, China
summary:
Document Visual Question Answering (Document VQA) must cope with documents
that span dozens of pages, yet leading systems still concatenate every page or
rely on very large vision-language models, both of which are memory-hungry.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) offers an attractive alternative, first
retrieving a concise set of relevant segments before generating answers from
this selected evidence. In this paper, we systematically evaluate the impact of
incorporating RAG into Document VQA through different retrieval variants -
text-based retrieval using OCR tokens and purely visual retrieval without OCR -
across multiple models and benchmarks. Evaluated on the multi-page datasets
MP-DocVQA, DUDE, and InfographicVQA, the text-centric variant improves the
"concatenate-all-pages" baseline by up to +22.5 ANLS, while the visual variant
achieves +5.0 ANLS improvement without requiring any text extraction. An
ablation confirms that retrieval and reranking components drive most of the
gain, whereas the layout-guided chunking strategy - proposed in several recent
works to leverage page structure - fails to help on these datasets. Our
experiments demonstrate that careful evidence selection consistently boosts
accuracy across multiple model sizes and multi-page benchmarks, underscoring
its practical value for real-world Document VQA.

AI.tldr: Retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) improves multi-page Document VQA by selecting concise evidence prior to answer generation. Text-based evidence (OCR tokens) yields larger gains than purely visual evidence, while OCR-free visual retrieval still offers non-trivial improvements. Retrieving and reranking drive most gains; layout-guided chunking often helps less.
AI.motivation: Document VQA on long, multi-page documents is memory-intensive and challenging with naive concatenation or very large models. RAG offers an efficient alternative by retrieving a small set of relevant segments to support answer generation.
AI.method: Systematic evaluation of RAG variants for Document VQA: (1) text-based retrieval using OCR tokens; (2) purely visual retrieval without OCR; across multiple models and benchmarks (MP-DocVQA, DUDE, InfographicVQA); ablations on retrieval, reranking, and layout-guided chunking.
AI.result: Text-based retrieval improves the concatenate-all-pages baseline by up to 22.5 ANLS; visual retrieval improves by 5.0 ANLS without OCR. Ablation shows retrieval and reranking are the main sources of gain; layout-guided chunking does not help on these datasets. Gains are consistent across model sizes and multi-page benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: Evidence selection via retrieval augmentation yields practical accuracy boosts for multi-page Document VQA and is effective across model sizes and datasets; layout-guided chunking is not necessary for these benchmarks.

title: HierCVAE: Hierarchical Attention-Driven Conditional Variational Autoencoders for Multi-Scale Temporal Modeling
summary:
Temporal modeling in complex systems requires capturing dependencies across
multiple time scales while managing inherent uncertainties. We propose
HierCVAE, a novel architecture that integrates hierarchical attention
mechanisms with conditional variational autoencoders to address these
challenges. HierCVAE employs a three-tier attention structure (local, global,
cross-temporal) combined with multi-modal condition encoding to capture
temporal, statistical, and trend information. The approach incorporates
ResFormer blocks in the latent space and provides explicit uncertainty
quantification via prediction heads. Through evaluations on energy consumption
datasets, HierCVAE demonstrates a 15-40% improvement in prediction accuracy and
superior uncertainty calibration compared to state-of-the-art methods,
excelling in long-term forecasting and complex multi-variate dependencies.

AI.tldr: Proposes HierCVAE, a hierarchical-attention conditional VAE for multi-scale temporal modeling with explicit uncertainty, achieving 15-40% accuracy gains on energy datasets and improved uncertainty calibration.
AI.motivation: To address dependencies across multiple time scales and inherent uncertainties in complex temporal systems, by capturing temporal, statistical, and trend information through hierarchical attention and conditional variational inference, while providing explicit uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: A three-tier attention architecture (local, global, cross-temporal) with multi-modal condition encoding to capture temporal, statistical, and trend information. Latent space includes ResFormer blocks. The model is built as a conditional variational autoencoder with prediction heads for uncertainty quantification and is evaluated on energy consumption datasets.
AI.result: HierCVAE achieves 15-40% improvements in prediction accuracy and superior uncertainty calibration compared to state-of-the-art methods. It excels in long-term forecasting and modeling complex, multi-variate dependencies.
AI.conclusion: HierCVAE effectively models multi-scale temporal dependencies with calibrated uncertainty, offering strong predictive performance and robust uncertainty estimates for long-horizon forecasting in energy data, with potential applicability to other complex temporal systems.

title: Ask Me Again Differently: GRAS for Measuring Bias in Vision Language Models on Gender, Race, Age, and Skin Tone
summary:
As Vision Language Models (VLMs) become integral to real-world applications,
understanding their demographic biases is critical. We introduce GRAS, a
benchmark for uncovering demographic biases in VLMs across gender, race, age,
and skin tone, offering the most diverse coverage to date. We further propose
the GRAS Bias Score, an interpretable metric for quantifying bias. We benchmark
five state-of-the-art VLMs and reveal concerning bias levels, with the least
biased model attaining a GRAS Bias Score of only 2 out of 100. Our findings
also reveal a methodological insight: evaluating bias in VLMs with visual
question answering (VQA) requires considering multiple formulations of a
question. Our code, data, and evaluation results are publicly available.

AI.tldr: GRAS introduces a diverse bias benchmark for vision-language models across gender, race, age, and skin tone, with a GRAS Bias Score. Across five SOTA VLMs, biases persist (the best score is only 2/100). The evaluation of bias via VQA depends on multiple question formulations. The work provides data, code, and results for replication.
AI.motivation: To address the critical need for reliable, diverse measurement of demographic biases in vision-language models, which can impact real-world deployments and fairness.
AI.method: Propose GRAS, a comprehensive bias benchmark covering gender, race, age, and skin tone, plus the GRAS Bias Score metric. Evaluate five state-of-the-art VLMs on the benchmark and analyze how different VQA question formulations affect bias estimation; release code, data, and results.
