AI.result: GRAS reveals concerning bias levels across tested models, with the best model scoring only 2/100 on the GRAS Bias Score. It also demonstrates that bias evaluation in VLMs via VQA is sensitive to question formulations, underscoring the need for diverse prompts.
AI.conclusion: Bias in vision-language models remains a significant challenge. A robust evaluation requires diverse VQA formulations; GRAS provides a diverse, interpretable framework and artifacts for replication and future work.

title: Energy-Based Flow Matching for Generating 3D Molecular Structure
comment: Accepted to the International Conference on Machine Learning (2025)
summary:
Molecular structure generation is a fundamental problem that involves
determining the 3D positions of molecules' constituents. It has crucial
biological applications, such as molecular docking, protein folding, and
molecular design. Recent advances in generative modeling, such as diffusion
models and flow matching, have made great progress on these tasks by modeling
molecular conformations as a distribution. In this work, we focus on flow
matching and adopt an energy-based perspective to improve training and
inference of structure generation models. Our view results in a mapping
function, represented by a deep network, that is directly learned to
\textit{iteratively} map random configurations, i.e. samples from the source
distribution, to target structures, i.e. points in the data manifold. This
yields a conceptually simple and empirically effective flow matching setup that
is theoretically justified and has interesting connections to fundamental
properties such as idempotency and stability, as well as the empirically useful
techniques such as structure refinement in AlphaFold. Experiments on protein
docking as well as protein backbone generation consistently demonstrate the
method's effectiveness, where it outperforms recent baselines of
task-associated flow matching and diffusion models, using a similar
computational budget.

AI.tldr: An energy-based flow-matching approach for molecular structure generation learns a deep mapping that iteratively transforms random configurations into valid molecular structures, achieving state-of-the-art results on protein docking and backbone generation within similar compute budgets.
AI.motivation: Molecular structure generation is essential for tasks like docking, folding, and design. While diffusion and flow-matching models have advanced the field by modeling conformations as distributions, there is a need for improved training/inference through an energy-based perspective that highlights stability, idempotency, and refinement, inspired by techniques used in AlphaFold.
AI.method: Adopt an energy-based view to design a flow-matching framework where a deep network learns a mapping that iteratively transforms samples from a source distribution into the data manifold (target structures). The approach emphasizes energy-based training, theoretical properties (idempotency, stability), and connections to refinement strategies.
AI.result: On protein docking and backbone generation, the proposed method consistently outperforms recent baselines in task-specific flow matching and diffusion models while using a similar computational budget.
AI.conclusion: The simple yet principled flow-matching framework, grounded in energy-based theory, offers empirical gains and theoretical insight for molecular structure generation and aligns with refinement ideas from AlphaFold.

title: RoofSeg: An edge-aware transformer-based network for end-to-end roof plane segmentation
summary:
Roof plane segmentation is one of the key procedures for reconstructing
three-dimensional (3D) building models at levels of detail (LoD) 2 and 3 from
airborne light detection and ranging (LiDAR) point clouds. The majority of
current approaches for roof plane segmentation rely on the manually designed or
learned features followed by some specifically designed geometric clustering
strategies. Because the learned features are more powerful than the manually
designed features, the deep learning-based approaches usually perform better
than the traditional approaches. However, the current deep learning-based
approaches have three unsolved problems. The first is that most of them are not
truly end-to-end, the plane segmentation results may be not optimal. The second
is that the point feature discriminability near the edges is relatively low,
leading to inaccurate planar edges. The third is that the planar geometric
characteristics are not sufficiently considered to constrain the network
training. To solve these issues, a novel edge-aware transformer-based network,
named RoofSeg, is developed for segmenting roof planes from LiDAR point clouds
in a truly end-to-end manner. In the RoofSeg, we leverage a transformer
encoder-decoder-based framework to hierarchically predict the plane instance
masks with the use of a set of learnable plane queries. To further improve the
segmentation accuracy of edge regions, we also design an Edge-Aware Mask Module
(EAMM) that sufficiently incorporates planar geometric prior of edges to
enhance its discriminability for plane instance mask refinement. In addition,
we propose an adaptive weighting strategy in the mask loss to reduce the
influence of misclassified points, and also propose a new plane geometric loss
to constrain the network training.

AI.tldr: End-to-end RoofSeg: an edge-aware transformer for LiDAR roof plane segmentation, with EAMM, adaptive loss, and a plane geometric loss to improve edge accuracy and plane masks.
AI.motivation: Current DL-based roof segmentation is not fully end-to-end, points near edges have low discriminability, and geometry priors are underutilized; a method is needed to jointly learn masks with better edge handling and geometric constraints.
AI.method: Transformer encoder-decoder with learnable plane queries; Edge-Aware Mask Module (EAMM) leveraging planar edge geometry to refine masks; adaptive masking loss to downweight misclassified points; plane geometric loss to constrain training.
AI.result: Proposes RoofSeg architecture; demonstrates improved edge-aware segmentation accuracy via novel components; no quantitative results reported in the abstract.
AI.conclusion: An end-to-end RoofSeg framework effectively leverages edge-aware priors and geometric losses to enhance roof plane segmentation from LiDAR; addresses key limitations of prior approaches.

title: Estimating Conditional Covariance between labels for Multilabel Data
summary:
Multilabel data should be analysed for label dependence before applying
multilabel models. Independence between multilabel data labels cannot be
measured directly from the label values due to their dependence on the set of
covariates $\vec{x}$, but can be measured by examining the conditional label
covariance using a multivariate Probit model. Unfortunately, the multivariate
Probit model provides an estimate of its copula covariance, and so might not be
reliable in estimating constant covariance and dependent covariance. In this
article, we compare three models (Multivariate Probit, Multivariate Bernoulli
and Staged Logit) for estimating the constant and dependent multilabel
conditional label covariance. We provide an experiment that allows us to
observe each model's measurement of conditional covariance. We found that all
models measure constant and dependent covariance equally well, depending on the
strength of the covariance, but the models all falsely detect that dependent
covariance is present for data where constant covariance is present. Of the
three models, the Multivariate Probit model had the lowest error rate.

AI.tldr: Three models (Multivariate Probit, Multivariate Bernoulli, and Staged Logit) are compared for estimating constant and dependent multilabel conditional covariance. All models may falsely detect dependency when only constant covariance is present, but Multivariate Probit has the lowest error rate.
AI.motivation: To determine how well different models estimate constant versus dependent conditional covariance in multilabel data, given that unconditional independence cannot be verified directly and that the multivariate Probit model’s copula covariance may be unreliable.
AI.method: An experimental comparison where each model is used to estimate constant and dependent multilabel conditional covariance across varying levels of true covariance strength and dependence.
AI.result: All models detect dependent covariance depending on strength, but all tend to falsely detect dependence when constant covariance is present. Among the three, Multivariate Probit achieves the lowest error rate.
AI.conclusion: Multivariate Probit is the most reliable among the three models for estimating constant and dependent multilabel conditional covariance, though all models struggle with false positives when constant covariance is present.

title: MicroDetect-Net (MDN): Leveraging Deep Learning to Detect Microplastics in Clam Blood, a Step Towards Human Blood Analysis
comment:
10 pages, 5 figures. Accepted to ICICC 2025 (Innovative Computation
  in Biomedical Imaging)
summary:
With the prevalence of plastics exceeding 368 million tons yearly,
microplastic pollution has grown to an extent where air, water, soil, and
living organisms have all tested positive for microplastic presence. These
particles, which are smaller than 5 millimeters in size, are no less harmful to
humans than to the environment. Toxicity research on microplastics has shown
that exposure may cause liver infection, intestinal injuries, and gut flora
imbalance, leading to numerous potential health hazards. This paper presents a
new model, MicroDetect-Net (MDN), which applies fluorescence microscopy with
Nile Red dye staining and deep learning to scan blood samples for
microplastics. Although clam blood has certain limitations in replicating real
human blood, this study opens avenues for applying the approach to human
samples, which are more consistent for preliminary data collection. The MDN
model integrates dataset preparation, fluorescence imaging, and segmentation
using a convolutional neural network to localize and count microplastic
fragments. The combination of convolutional networks and Nile Red dye for
segmentation produced strong image detection and accuracy. MDN was evaluated on
a dataset of 276 Nile Red-stained fluorescent blood images and achieved an
accuracy of ninety two percent. Robust performance was observed with an
Intersection over Union of 87.4 percent, F1 score of 92.1 percent, Precision of
90.6 percent, and Recall of 93.7 percent. These metrics demonstrate the
effectiveness of MDN in the detection of microplastics.

AI.tldr: IntroducesMicroDetect-Net(MDN),aCNN-basedpipelineusingNileRedfluorescencetostdetectmicroplasticsinstainedbloodimages;achieved92%accuracyandIoU87.4%on276samples;promisingbutlimitedbyuseofclambloodashumanproxyandneedvalidationonhumanblood.
AI.motivation: Risingmicroplasticpollutionacrossenvironmentsandpotentialhumanhealthrisksnecessitatess automated,high-throughputdetectioninbiologicalmatrices;currentmethodsaremanualandlimited,soadeep-learningimagingapproachcouldacceleratescreening.
AI.method: PrepareNileRed-stainedfluorescenceimagesfrombloodsamples(clambloodasproxy).UseCNN-basedsegmentationforlocalizationandcountingofmicroplasticfragments;integratedatasetpreparation,fluorescenceimaging,ands segmentation;Evaluateon276images;metricsincludeaccuracy,IoU,F1,precision,recall.

title: On the Generalisation of Koopman Representations for Chaotic System Control
summary:
This paper investigates the generalisability of Koopman-based representations
for chaotic dynamical systems, focusing on their transferability across
prediction and control tasks. Using the Lorenz system as a testbed, we propose
a three-stage methodology: learning Koopman embeddings through autoencoding,
pre-training a transformer on next-state prediction, and fine-tuning for
safety-critical control. Our results show that Koopman embeddings outperform
both standard and physics-informed PCA baselines, achieving accurate and
data-efficient performance. Notably, fixing the pre-trained transformer weights
during fine-tuning leads to no performance degradation, indicating that the
learned representations capture reusable dynamical structure rather than
task-specific patterns. These findings support the use of Koopman embeddings as
a foundation for multi-task learning in physics-informed machine learning. A
project page is available at https://kikisprdx.github.io/.

AI.tldr: A three-stage pipeline learns Koopman embeddings for a chaotic Lorenz system to achieve transferable representations across prediction and control tasks; embeddings outperform PCA baselines and are robust to freezing the transformer during fine-tuning, suggesting reusable dynamical structure for multi-task physics-informed ML.
AI.motivation: Evaluate whether Koopman-based representations generalize across tasks in chaotic dynamics and can serve as a reusable foundation for multi-task, physics-informed machine learning.
AI.method: 1) learn Koopman embeddings via autoencoding; 2) pre-train a transformer on next-state prediction; 3) fine-tune for safety-critical control; compare against standard and physics-informed PCA baselines; test with Lorenz system; assess effect of freezing pre-trained transformer during fine-tuning.
AI.result: Koopman embeddings outperform both standard and physics-informed PCA baselines with accurate, data-efficient performance; fixing transformer weights during fine-tuning yields no degradation, indicating learned representations capture reusable dynamical structure rather than task-specific patterns.
AI.conclusion: Koopman embeddings are a solid foundation for multi-task learning in physics-informed ML; demonstrated via Lorenz system with transferability across prediction and control; project page available.

title: ProPy: Building Interactive Prompt Pyramids upon CLIP for Partially Relevant Video Retrieval
summary:
Partially Relevant Video Retrieval (PRVR) is a practical yet challenging task
that involves retrieving videos based on queries relevant to only specific
segments. While existing works follow the paradigm of developing models to
process unimodal features, powerful pretrained vision-language models like CLIP
remain underexplored in this field. To bridge this gap, we propose ProPy, a
model with systematic architectural adaption of CLIP specifically designed for
PRVR. Drawing insights from the semantic relevance of multi-granularity events,
ProPy introduces two key innovations: (1) A Prompt Pyramid structure that
organizes event prompts to capture semantics at multiple granularity levels,
and (2) An Ancestor-Descendant Interaction Mechanism built on the pyramid that
enables dynamic semantic interaction among events. With these designs, ProPy
achieves SOTA performance on three public datasets, outperforming previous
models by significant margins. Code is available at
https://github.com/BUAAPY/ProPy.

AI.tldr: ProPy adapts CLIP for partially relevant video retrieval using a Prompt Pyramid and Ancestor-Descendant Interaction, achieving state-of-the-art on three datasets.
AI.motivation: PRVR tasks require retrieving videos based on queries relevant to specific segments, and existing approaches underutilize powerful vision-language models like CLIP; there is a need for multi-granularity semantic prompts and dynamic hierarchical interactions to capture partial relevance.
AI.method: Systematic architectural adaptation of CLIP for PRVR. Introduce a Prompt Pyramid to organize event prompts across multiple granularity levels and an Ancestor-Descendant Interaction Mechanism that enables dynamic semantic interaction among events within the pyramid.
AI.result: State-of-the-art performance on three public PRVR datasets, with significant gains over baselines.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates effective integration of vision-language models for PRVR via hierarchical, multi-granularity prompts and interactions; validates the proposed design and provides code for reproducibility.

title: PAX-TS: Model-agnostic multi-granular explanations for time series forecasting via localized perturbations
summary:
Time series forecasting has seen considerable improvement during the last
years, with transformer models and large language models driving advancements
of the state of the art. Modern forecasting models are generally opaque and do
not provide explanations for their forecasts, while well-known post-hoc
explainability methods like LIME are not suitable for the forecasting context.
We propose PAX-TS, a model-agnostic post-hoc algorithm to explain time series
forecasting models and their forecasts. Our method is based on localized input
perturbations and results in multi-granular explanations. Further, it is able
to characterize cross-channel correlations for multivariate time series
forecasts. We clearly outline the algorithmic procedure behind PAX-TS,
demonstrate it on a benchmark with 7 algorithms and 10 diverse datasets,
compare it with two other state-of-the-art explanation algorithms, and present
the different explanation types of the method. We found that the explanations
of high-performing and low-performing algorithms differ on the same datasets,
highlighting that the explanations of PAX-TS effectively capture a model's
behavior. Based on time step correlation matrices resulting from the benchmark,
we identify 6 classes of patterns that repeatedly occur across different
datasets and algorithms. We found that the patterns are indicators of
performance, with noticeable differences in forecasting error between the
classes. Lastly, we outline a multivariate example where PAX-TS demonstrates
how the forecasting model takes cross-channel correlations into account. With
PAX-TS, time series forecasting models' mechanisms can be illustrated in
different levels of detail, and its explanations can be used to answer
practical questions on forecasts.

AI.tldr: PAX-TS is a model-agnostic, post-hoc explanation method for time series forecasting that uses localized perturbations to provide multi-granular, cross-channel explanations, revealing patterns in time-step correlations that relate to model performance across multiple datasets and algorithms.
AI.motivation: Modern time series forecasting models are often opaque. Traditional post-hoc explainers (e.g., LIME) are not well-suited for forecasting due to temporal structure and cross-channel dependencies; there is a need for explanations tailored to forecast models that reveal how inputs influence predictions over time and across channels.
AI.method: PAX-TS applies localized input perturbations to time series inputs to generate explanations in a model-agnostic, post-hoc manner. It produces multi-granular explanations, characterizes cross-channel correlations for multivariate forecasts, outlines a concrete algorithm, and is evaluated on a benchmark of 7 forecasting algorithms across 10 diverse datasets, comparing with two state-of-the-art explanation methods, and detailing different explanation types and patterns.
AI.result: Explanations differ between high-performing and low-performing models on the same datasets, indicating PAX-TS captures model behavior. Time-step correlation matrices reveal six recurrent pattern classes across datasets and algorithms, which correlate with forecasting error. A multivariate example demonstrates how cross-channel correlations influence forecasts.
AI.conclusion: PAX-TS enables illustrating forecasting models’ mechanisms at multiple levels of detail and supports answering practical questions about forecasts; it also provides insight into cross-channel interactions and pattern-based indicators of performance.

title: GReAT: leveraging geometric artery data to improve wall shear stress assessment
comment: (MICCAI 2025) Workshop on Shape in Medical Imaging (ShapeMI)
summary:
Leveraging big data for patient care is promising in many medical fields such
as cardiovascular health. For example, hemodynamic biomarkers like wall shear
stress could be assessed from patient-specific medical images via machine
learning algorithms, bypassing the need for time-intensive computational fluid
simulation. However, it is extremely challenging to amass large-enough datasets
to effectively train such models. We could address this data scarcity by means
of self-supervised pre-training and foundations models given large datasets of
geometric artery models. In the context of coronary arteries, leveraging
learned representations to improve hemodynamic biomarker assessment has not yet
been well studied. In this work, we address this gap by investigating whether a
large dataset (8449 shapes) consisting of geometric models of 3D blood vessels
can benefit wall shear stress assessment in coronary artery models from a
small-scale clinical trial (49 patients). We create a self-supervised target
for the 3D blood vessels by computing the heat kernel signature, a quantity
obtained via Laplacian eigenvectors, which captures the very essence of the
shapes. We show how geometric representations learned from this datasets can
boost segmentation of coronary arteries into regions of low, mid and high
(time-averaged) wall shear stress even when trained on limited data.

AI.tldr: Large geometric artery datasets with self-supervised heat-kernel targets improve coronary wall shear stress segmentation in data-scarce settings.
AI.motivation: Data scarcity limits training for ML-based hemodynamic biomarkers like wall shear stress; leveraging big geometric shape datasets with self-supervised learning could bridge the gap.
AI.method: Train on a large collection (8449) of 3D vessel shapes using the heat kernel signature as a self-supervised target (derived from Laplacian eigenvectors); transfer learned representations to segment coronary arteries into regions of time-averaged low/mid/high wall shear stress, evaluated on a small clinical trial (49 patients).
AI.result: Geometric representations learned from the large dataset improve segmentation of coronary arteries into low/mid/high WSS regions even when trained on limited clinical data.
AI.conclusion: Self-supervised learning on large geometric artery models (via heat-kernel targets) can enhance hemodynamic biomarker assessment and demonstrates the value of big geometric datasets for medical image analysis.

title: FedProtoKD: Dual Knowledge Distillation with Adaptive Class-wise Prototype Margin for Heterogeneous Federated Learning
summary:
Heterogeneous Federated Learning (HFL) has gained attention for its ability
to accommodate diverse models and heterogeneous data across clients.
Prototype-based HFL methods emerge as a promising solution to address
statistical heterogeneity and privacy challenges, paving the way for new
advancements in HFL research. This method focuses on sharing only
class-representative prototypes among heterogeneous clients. However, these
prototypes are often aggregated on the server using weighted averaging, leading
to sub-optimal global knowledge; these cause the shrinking of aggregated
prototypes, which negatively affects the model performance in scenarios when
models are heterogeneous and data distributions are extremely non-IID. We
propose FedProtoKD in a Heterogeneous Federated Learning setting, using an
enhanced dual-knowledge distillation mechanism to improve the system
performance with clients' logits and prototype feature representation. We aim
to resolve the prototype margin-shrinking problem using a contrastive
learning-based trainable server prototype by leveraging a class-wise adaptive
prototype margin. Furthermore, we assess the importance of public samples using
the closeness of the sample's prototype to its class representative prototypes,
which enhances learning performance. FedProtoKD achieved average improvements
of 1.13% up to 34.13% accuracy across various settings and significantly
outperforms existing state-of-the-art HFL methods.

AI.tldr: FedProtoKD tackles prototype margin shrinking in heterogeneous federated learning by applying an enhanced dual-knowledge distillation framework that leverages client logits and prototype features, with a trainable server prototype using contrastive learning and a class-wise adaptive margin, and by evaluating public samples via prototype proximity. It achieves notable accuracy gains over state-of-the-art HFL methods.
AI.motivation: Heterogeneous Federated Learning (HFL) enables diverse models and non-IID data across clients, but prototype-based HFL suffers from prototype margin shrinkage due to server aggregation, which degrades global knowledge transfer and model performance while preserving privacy.
AI.method: Introduce FedProtoKD with an enhanced dual-knowledge distillation mechanism that uses client logits and prototype feature representations. Mitigate prototype margin shrinking with a contrastive-learning-based trainable server prototype and a class-wise adaptive prototype margin. Assess the importance of public samples by measuring how close a sample’s prototype is to its class prototypes to weight learning.
AI.result: Federated models show average accuracy improvements from 1.13% up to 34.13% across various settings, significantly outperforming existing state-of-the-art HFL methods.
AI.conclusion: FedProtoKD effectively alleviates prototype margin shrinking in heterogeneous FL and improves overall performance by leveraging dual distillation, adaptive prototype margins, and public-sample-aware learning, indicating strong potential for privacy-preserving HFL in highly non-IID, model-heterogeneous scenarios.

title: No Label Left Behind: A Unified Surface Defect Detection Model for all Supervision Regimes
comment: Accepted by The Journal of Intelligent Manufacturing
summary:
Surface defect detection is a critical task across numerous industries, aimed
at efficiently identifying and localising imperfections or irregularities on
manufactured components. While numerous methods have been proposed, many fail
to meet industrial demands for high performance, efficiency, and adaptability.
Existing approaches are often constrained to specific supervision scenarios and
struggle to adapt to the diverse data annotations encountered in real-world
manufacturing processes, such as unsupervised, weakly supervised, mixed
supervision, and fully supervised settings. To address these challenges, we
propose SuperSimpleNet, a highly efficient and adaptable discriminative model
built on the foundation of SimpleNet. SuperSimpleNet incorporates a novel
synthetic anomaly generation process, an enhanced classification head, and an
improved learning procedure, enabling efficient training in all four
supervision scenarios, making it the first model capable of fully leveraging
all available data annotations. SuperSimpleNet sets a new standard for
performance across all scenarios, as demonstrated by its results on four
challenging benchmark datasets. Beyond accuracy, it is very fast, achieving an
inference time below 10 ms. With its ability to unify diverse supervision
paradigms while maintaining outstanding speed and reliability, SuperSimpleNet
represents a promising step forward in addressing real-world manufacturing
challenges and bridging the gap between academic research and industrial
applications. Code: https://github.com/blaz-r/SuperSimpleNet

AI.tldr: A discriminative, efficient surface-defect detector named SuperSimpleNet unifying four supervision paradigms (unsupervised, weakly supervised, mixed, and fully supervised) via synthetic anomaly generation, an enhanced classifier head, and improved learning, achieving state-of-the-art results across four benchmarks with inference under 10 ms.
AI.motivation: Industrial surface defect detection requires high performance, speed, and adaptability to diverse annotation scenarios. Many methods are limited to specific supervision setups and struggle to generalize to real-world data. There is a need for a single model that can leverage all available annotations and operate efficiently in production settings.
AI.method: Build on SimpleNet to create SuperSimpleNet, introducing (1) a synthetic anomaly generation process, (2) an enhanced classification head, and (3) an improved learning procedure. The model is designed to train effectively under unsupervised, weakly supervised, mixed supervision, and fully supervised settings, enabling it to utilize all available data annotations.
AI.result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance across four challenging defect-detection benchmarks and maintains very fast inference (below 10 ms). It is positioned as the first model capable of leveraging all annotation regimes.
AI.conclusion: SuperSimpleNet offers a unified, fast, and accurate framework for industrial surface defect detection, bridging the gap between academic research and practical manufacturing applications. The accompanying code is available at the provided GitHub URL.

title: STDiff: A State Transition Diffusion Framework for Time Series Imputation in Industrial Systems
summary:
Most deep learning methods for imputing missing values treat the task as
completing patterns within a fixed time window. This assumption often fails in
industrial systems, where dynamics are driven by control actions, are highly
non-stationary, and can experience long, uninterrupted gaps. We propose STDiff,
which reframes imputation as learning how the system evolves from one state to
the next. STDiff uses a conditional denoising diffusion model with a causal
bias aligned to control theory, generating missing values step-by-step based on
the most recent known state and relevant control or environmental inputs. On a
public wastewater treatment dataset with simulated missing blocks, STDiff
consistently achieves the lowest errors, with its advantage increasing for
longer gaps. On a raw industrial dataset with substantial real gaps, it
produces trajectories that remain dynamically plausible, in contrast to
window-based models that tend to flatten or over-smooth. These results support
dynamics-aware, explicitly conditioned imputation as a robust approach for
industrial time series, and we discuss computational trade-offs and extensions
to broader domains.

AI.tldr: STDiff uses a dynamics-aware conditional diffusion model to impute missing values by predicting state-to-state evolution, outperforming window-based methods, especially for long gaps.
AI.motivation: Imputation often relies on fixed time-window patterns, which fails in industrial systems where dynamics are driven by control actions, are non-stationary, and can have long, uninterrupted gaps. A dynamics-aware approach that conditions on the most recent state and inputs is needed to preserve plausible trajectories.
AI.method: A conditional denoising diffusion model with a causal bias aligned to control theory. It generates missing values step-by-step based on the most recent known state and relevant control/environmental inputs, reframing imputation as learning the system's evolution from one state to the next.
AI.result: On a public wastewater dataset with simulated missing blocks, STDiff achieves the lowest error, with advantage increasing for longer gaps. On a real industrial dataset with substantial gaps, it yields dynamically plausible trajectories, whereas window-based models tend to flatten or over-smooth.
AI.conclusion: Dynamics-aware, explicitly conditioned imputation is a robust approach for industrial time series; the work discusses computational trade-offs and extensions to broader domains.

title: Learning Binary Sampling Patterns for Single-Pixel Imaging using Bilevel Optimisation
summary:
Single-Pixel Imaging enables reconstructing objects using a single detector
through sequential illuminations with structured light patterns. We propose a
bilevel optimisation method for learning task-specific, binary illumination
patterns, optimised for applications like single-pixel fluorescence microscopy.
We address the non-differentiable nature of binary pattern optimisation using
the Straight-Through Estimator and leveraging a Total Deep Variation
regulariser in the bilevel formulation. We demonstrate our method on the
CytoImageNet microscopy dataset and show that learned patterns achieve superior
reconstruction performance compared to baseline methods, especially in highly
undersampled regimes.

AI.tldr: A bilevel optimization framework learns task-specific binary illumination patterns for single-pixel imaging, using Straight-Through Estimator and a Total Deep Variation regularizer; demonstrates improved reconstruction in undersampled fluorescence microscopy on CytoImageNet.
AI.motivation: To overcome non-differentiable binary pattern optimization in single-pixel imaging and tailor illumination to specific tasks (e.g., fluorescence microscopy), improving reconstruction under limited measurements.
AI.method: Formulate as bilevel optimization; handle binary patterns with Straight-Through Estimator; apply Total Deep Variation regulariser; train on CytoImageNet microscopy dataset to learn patterns optimized for reconstruction.
AI.result: Learned patterns yield superior reconstruction compared to baselines, especially in highly undersampled regimes.
AI.conclusion: Task-specific binary illumination patterns learned via bilevel optimization enhance single-pixel imaging performance and are particularly advantageous when measurements are scarce; relevant for fluorescence microscopy.

title: Learning with springs and sticks
summary:
Learning is a physical process. Here, we aim to study a simple dynamical
system composed of springs and sticks capable of arbitrarily approximating any
continuous function. The main idea of our work is to use the sticks to mimic a
piecewise-linear approximation of the given function, use the potential energy
of springs to encode a desired mean squared error loss function, and converge
to a minimum-energy configuration via dissipation. We apply the proposed
simulation system to regression tasks and show that its performance is
comparable to that of multi-layer perceptrons. In addition, we study the
thermodynamic properties of the system and find a relation between the free
energy change of the system and its ability to learn an underlying data
distribution. We empirically find a \emph{thermodynamic learning barrier} for
the system caused by the fluctuations of the environment, whereby the system
cannot learn if its change in free energy hits such a barrier. We believe this
simple model can help us better understand learning systems from a physical
point of view.

AI.tldr: A spring-and-stick mechanical system can approximate any continuous function via a piecewise-linear representation, learning through energy minimization where spring potential encodes the loss; regression performance is on par with MLPs, and the model reveals thermodynamic aspects of learning, including a barrier due to environmental fluctuations.
AI.motivation: To understand learning as a physical process by building a minimal dynamical system (springs and sticks) that can learn from data through dissipation and energy minimization, and to connect learning performance with thermodynamic quantities like free energy.
AI.method: Construct a mechanical network of springs and sticks to realize piecewise-linear function approximation. Use the potential energy of springs to encode a mean-squared-error loss; drive the system to a minimum-energy configuration via dissipative dynamics. Test on regression tasks and compare to multi-layer perceptrons; study thermodynamic properties and fluctuations to relate free-energy change to learning behavior.
AI.result: The system achieves regression performance comparable to MLPs. It reveals a relation between free-energy changes and the ability to learn a data distribution. Empirically, a thermodynamic learning barrier emerges due to environmental fluctuations, limiting learning when energy changes cross this barrier.
AI.conclusion: A simple, physically grounded model can shed light on learning dynamics by linking optimization to energy dissipation and thermodynamics. The existence of a learning barrier underscores fundamental limits set by the environment and motivates further exploration of physical implementations of learning systems.

title: Working My Way Back to You: Resource-Centric Next-Activity Prediction
summary:
Predictive Process Monitoring (PPM) aims to train models that forecast
upcoming events in process executions. These predictions support early
bottleneck detection, improved scheduling, proactive interventions, and timely
communication with stakeholders. While existing research adopts a control-flow
perspective, we investigate next-activity prediction from a resource-centric
viewpoint, which offers additional benefits such as improved work organization,
workload balancing, and capacity forecasting. Although resource information has
been shown to enhance tasks such as process performance analysis, its role in
next-activity prediction remains unexplored. In this study, we evaluate four
prediction models and three encoding strategies across four real-life datasets.
Compared to the baseline, our results show that LightGBM and Transformer models
perform best with an encoding based on 2-gram activity transitions, while
Random Forest benefits most from an encoding that combines 2-gram transitions
and activity repetition features. This combined encoding also achieves the
highest average accuracy. This resource-centric approach could enable smarter
resource allocation, strategic workforce planning, and personalized employee
support by analyzing individual behavior rather than case-level progression.
The findings underscore the potential of resource-centric next-activity
prediction, opening up new venues for research on PPM.

AI.tldr: A resource-centric view for predictive process monitoring (PPM) is effective for next-activity prediction. Across four real-life datasets, LightGBM and Transformer excel with 2-gram activity-transition encoding, while Random Forest benefits most from a 2-gram plus activity repetition encoding. The combined encoding yields the highest average accuracy, suggesting resource information enables smarter resource allocation and workforce planning. This opens new avenues for PPM research.
AI.motivation: Traditionally, PPM emphasizes control-flow; this work argues for a resource-centric perspective, which can improve work organization, workload balancing, and capacity forecasting. Resource information's role in next-activity prediction is underexplored, and this study investigates its impact.
AI.method: Evaluate four prediction models and three encoding strategies across four real-life datasets for next-activity prediction from a resource-centric viewpoint. Compare model performance and identify encoding schemes that maximize accuracy, with a focus on 2-gram transitions and repetition features.
AI.result: LightGBM and Transformer achieve the best performance with 2-gram activity-transition encoding, while Random Forest benefits most from a combined 2-gram and repetition feature encoding. The combined encoding attains the highest average accuracy across datasets. The results support the viability of resource-centric next-activity prediction and its potential benefits in practice.
AI.conclusion: Resource-centric next-activity prediction is a promising direction for PPM, enabling smarter resource allocation, strategic workforce planning, and personalized employee support by analyzing individual behavior. This work highlights a new research avenue and the potential impact of incorporating resource information into PPM.

title: RDDM: Practicing RAW Domain Diffusion Model for Real-world Image Restoration
summary:
We present the RAW domain diffusion model (RDDM), an end-to-end diffusion
model that restores photo-realistic images directly from the sensor RAW data.
While recent sRGB-domain diffusion methods achieve impressive results, they are
caught in a dilemma between high fidelity and realistic generation. As these
models process lossy sRGB inputs and neglect the accessibility of the sensor
RAW images in many scenarios, e.g., in image and video capturing in edge
devices, resulting in sub-optimal performance. RDDM bypasses this limitation by
directly restoring images in the RAW domain, replacing the conventional
two-stage image signal processing (ISP) + IR pipeline. However, a simple
adaptation of pre-trained diffusion models to the RAW domain confronts the
out-of-distribution (OOD) issues. To this end, we propose: (1) a RAW-domain VAE
(RVAE) learning optimal latent representations, (2) a differentiable Post Tone
Processing (PTP) module enabling joint RAW and sRGB space optimization. To
compensate for the deficiency in the dataset, we develop a scalable degradation
pipeline synthesizing RAW LQ-HQ pairs from existing sRGB datasets for
large-scale training. Furthermore, we devise a configurable multi-bayer (CMB)
LoRA module handling diverse RAW patterns such as RGGB, BGGR, etc. Extensive
experiments demonstrate RDDM's superiority over state-of-the-art sRGB diffusion
methods, yielding higher fidelity results with fewer artifacts.

AI.tldr: RDDM is an end-to-end diffusion model that restores images directly from RAW sensor data, using RVAE, differentiable Post Tone Processing, scalable RAW data synthesis, and a multi-bayer LoRA to handle various RAW patterns, outperforming sRGB-domain diffusion methods.
AI.motivation: Motivated by the limitations of sRGB-domain diffusion that operate on lossy sRGB inputs and ignore RAW data availability, leading to suboptimal fidelity and practical issues on edge devices. The authors aim to bypass the conventional ISP+IR two-stage pipeline by restoring directly in the RAW domain and addressing OOD issues when adapting pre-trained models to RAW.
AI.method: Develop RAW-domain VAE (RVAE) to learn optimal latent RAW representations; introduce a differentiable Post Tone Processing (PTP) module for joint RAW and sRGB optimization; build a scalable degradation pipeline to synthesize RAW LQ-HQ pairs from existing sRGB datasets for large-scale training; implement a configurable multi-bayer (CMB) LoRA module to handle diverse RAW patterns (e.g., RGGB, BGGR, etc); integrate these components into an end-to-end RAW-domain diffusion framework.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show that RDDM outperforms state-of-the-art sRGB diffusion methods, achieving higher image fidelity with fewer artifacts.
AI.conclusion: RDDM demonstrates the feasibility and advantages of RAW-domain diffusion, offering higher-quality restoration directly from RAW data and reducing dependence on ISP-based processing, with robustness to diverse RAW patterns and scalable data synthesis.

title: Metric Matters: A Formal Evaluation of Similarity Measures in Active Learning for Cyber Threat Intelligence
summary:
Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) pose a severe challenge to cyber defense
due to their stealthy behavior and the extreme class imbalance inherent in
detection datasets. To address these issues, we propose a novel active
learning-based anomaly detection framework that leverages similarity search to
iteratively refine the decision space. Built upon an Attention-Based
Autoencoder, our approach uses feature-space similarity to identify normal-like
and anomaly-like instances, thereby enhancing model robustness with minimal
oracle supervision. Crucially, we perform a formal evaluation of various
similarity measures to understand their influence on sample selection and
anomaly ranking effectiveness. Through experiments on diverse datasets,
including DARPA Transparent Computing APT traces, we demonstrate that the
choice of similarity metric significantly impacts model convergence, anomaly
detection accuracy, and label efficiency. Our results offer actionable insights
for selecting similarity functions in active learning pipelines tailored for
threat intelligence and cyber defense.

AI.tldr: Active learning for anomaly detection against APTs using an Attention-Based Autoencoder and feature-space similarity search; the choice of similarity metric strongly affects convergence, detection accuracy, and label efficiency.
AI.motivation: APT threats combine stealthy behavior with severe class imbalance in detection datasets, making robust detection with limited labels challenging; the work seeks to improve robustness and labeling efficiency through similarity-guided active learning.
AI.method: An active learning-based anomaly detection framework using an Attention-Based Autoencoder. It identifies normal-like and anomaly-like instances via feature-space similarity, iteratively refining the decision space with minimal oracle supervision. The study formally evaluates multiple similarity measures and tests on diverse datasets, including DARPA Transparent Computing APT traces.
AI.result: The similarity metric choice significantly impacts model convergence, anomaly ranking accuracy, and labeling efficiency. The paper provides actionable insights on selecting similarity functions for active learning pipelines in threat intelligence and cyber defense.
AI.conclusion: Similarity function selection is a critical design decision in active learning for threat detection; appropriate choice improves convergence and detection performance and should be tailored to cyber defense contexts and datasets.

title: Few-Shot Connectivity-Aware Text Line Segmentation in Historical Documents
summary:
A foundational task for the digital analysis of documents is text line
segmentation. However, automating this process with deep learning models is
challenging because it requires large, annotated datasets that are often
unavailable for historical documents. Additionally, the annotation process is a
labor- and cost-intensive task that requires expert knowledge, which makes
few-shot learning a promising direction for reducing data requirements. In this
work, we demonstrate that small and simple architectures, coupled with a
topology-aware loss function, are more accurate and data-efficient than more
complex alternatives. We pair a lightweight UNet++ with a connectivity-aware
loss, initially developed for neuron morphology, which explicitly penalizes
structural errors like line fragmentation and unintended line merges. To
increase our limited data, we train on small patches extracted from a mere
three annotated pages per manuscript. Our methodology significantly improves
upon the current state-of-the-art on the U-DIADS-TL dataset, with a 200%
increase in Recognition Accuracy and a 75% increase in Line Intersection over
Union. Our method also achieves an F-Measure score on par with or even
exceeding that of the competition winner of the DIVA-HisDB baseline detection
task, all while requiring only three annotated pages, exemplifying the efficacy
of our approach. Our implementation is publicly available at:
https://github.com/RafaelSterzinger/acpr_few_shot_hist.

AI.tldr: A lightweight, topology-aware few-shot approach for historical text line segmentation that outperforms larger models using only three annotated pages per manuscript.
AI.motivation: Text line segmentation in historical documents suffers from data scarcity and costly expert annotations; few-shot learning could reduce data requirements.
AI.method: Use a lightweight UNet++ architecture with a connectivity-aware loss designed to penalize line fragmentation and unintended merges; train on small patches extracted from only three annotated pages per manuscript.
AI.result: Significant gains on U-DIADS-TL: 200% higher Recognition Accuracy and 75% higher Line IoU; competitive or superior F-Measure compared to DIVA-HisDB winner; public implementation.
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates that small, simple models with topology-aware loss can achieve state-of-the-art results in data-scarce historical document analysis.

title: GRADSTOP: Early Stopping of Gradient Descent via Posterior Sampling
summary:
Machine learning models are often learned by minimising a loss function on
the training data using a gradient descent algorithm. These models often suffer
from overfitting, leading to a decline in predictive performance on unseen
data. A standard solution is early stopping using a hold-out validation set,
which halts the minimisation when the validation loss stops decreasing.
However, this hold-out set reduces the data available for training. This paper
presents {\sc gradstop}, a novel stochastic early stopping method that only
uses information in the gradients, which are produced by the gradient descent
algorithm ``for free.'' Our main contributions are that we estimate the
Bayesian posterior by the gradient information, define the early stopping
problem as drawing sample from this posterior, and use the approximated
posterior to obtain a stopping criterion. Our empirical evaluation shows that
{\sc gradstop} achieves a small loss on test data and compares favourably to a
validation-set-based stopping criterion. By leveraging the entire dataset for
training, our method is particularly advantageous in data-limited settings,
such as transfer learning. It can be incorporated as an optional feature in
gradient descent libraries with only a small computational overhead. The source
code is available at https://github.com/edahelsinki/gradstop.

AI.tldr: GradStop is a gradient-based stochastic early stopping method that uses gradient information to approximate a Bayesian posterior and decide when to stop training without relying on a hold-out validation set.
AI.motivation: Standard hold-out validation reduces training data and can hurt performance, especially in data-limited settings. There's a need for data-efficient, automatic stopping criteria.
AI.method: Treat early stopping as drawing samples from a Bayesian posterior estimated from gradient information produced during gradient descent. Use the approximate posterior to define a stopping rule; integrate as an optional, low-overhead feature in GD libraries.
AI.result: Empirically, GradStop achieves low test loss and compares favorably to validation-set stopping; particularly advantageous when training data is scarce (e.g., transfer learning). Code available.
AI.conclusion: GradStop offers a data-efficient alternative to hold-out-based stopping by leveraging gradient information to perform Bayesian-inspired stopping; suitable for integration into existing workflows.

title: Dual Enhancement on 3D Vision-Language Perception for Monocular 3D Visual Grounding
summary:
Monocular 3D visual grounding is a novel task that aims to locate 3D objects
in RGB images using text descriptions with explicit geometry information.
Despite the inclusion of geometry details in the text, we observe that the text
embeddings are sensitive to the magnitude of numerical values but largely
ignore the associated measurement units. For example, simply equidistant
mapping the length with unit "meter" to "decimeters" or "centimeters" leads to
severe performance degradation, even though the physical length remains
equivalent. This observation signifies the weak 3D comprehension of pre-trained
language model, which generates misguiding text features to hinder 3D
perception. Therefore, we propose to enhance the 3D perception of model on text
embeddings and geometry features with two simple and effective methods.
Firstly, we introduce a pre-processing method named 3D-text Enhancement (3DTE),
which enhances the comprehension of mapping relationships between different
units by augmenting the diversity of distance descriptors in text queries.
Next, we propose a Text-Guided Geometry Enhancement (TGE) module to further
enhance the 3D-text information by projecting the basic text features into
geometrically consistent space. These 3D-enhanced text features are then
leveraged to precisely guide the attention of geometry features. We evaluate
the proposed method through extensive comparisons and ablation studies on the
Mono3DRefer dataset. Experimental results demonstrate substantial improvements
over previous methods, achieving new state-of-the-art results with a notable
accuracy gain of 11.94\% in the "Far" scenario. Our code will be made publicly
available.

AI.tldr: Addresses the misalignment between numeric magnitudes and units in text-driven monocular 3D grounding by enhancing 3D-text representations with two modules, achieving SOTA on Mono3DRefer, especially in Far scenarios.
AI.motivation: Text-based 3D grounding suffers from weak 3D understanding of pretrained language models, where numerics are sensitive to magnitude but units are largely ignored, causing misguidance in geometry reasoning.
AI.method: Propose two modules: (i) 3D-text Enhancement (3DTE) to diversify distance descriptors and improve unit handling; (ii) Text-Guided Geometry Enhancement (TGE) to project basic text features into a geometrically consistent space and guide geometry feature attention.
AI.result: On Mono3DRefer, the approach yields substantial improvements over prior methods, including a notable 11.94 percentage point gain in the Far scenario, indicating strong 3D-text–geometry alignment.
AI.conclusion: Combining enhanced 3D-text representations with geometry-guided embedding attention effectively improves monocular 3D visual grounding; results support the approach's efficacy and generalization, with code to be released.

title: When recalling in-context, Transformers are not SSMs
summary:
Despite the advantageous subquadratic complexity of modern recurrent deep
learning models -- such as state-space models (SSMs) -- recent studies have
highlighted their potential shortcomings compared to transformers on reasoning
and memorization tasks. In this paper, we dive deeper into one of such
benchmarks: associative recall (AR), which has been shown to correlate well
with language modeling performance, and inspect in detail the effects of
scaling and optimization issues in recently proposed token mixing strategies.
We first demonstrate that, unlike standard transformers, the choice of learning
rate plays a critical role in the performance of modern recurrent models: an
issue that can severely affect reported performance in previous works and
suggests further research is needed to stabilize training. Next, we show that
recurrent and attention-based models exhibit contrasting benefits when scaling
in width as opposed to depth, with attention being notably unable to solve AR
when limited to a single layer. We then further inspect 1-layer transformers,
revealing that despite their poor performance, their training dynamics
surprisingly resemble the formation of induction heads, a phenomenon previously
observed only in their 2-layer counterparts. Finally, through architectural
ablations, we study how components affects Transformer and Mamba's performance
and optimization stability.

AI.tldr: This work investigates why recurrent deep models lag transformers on associative recall, showing that learning-rate control is crucial, scaling behavior differs between architectures, and 1-layer transformers exhibit induction-head–like dynamics; ablations highlight stability considerations for Transformer and Mamba.
AI.motivation: To explain the gap in associative recall performance between modern recurrent models (e.g., state-space models) and Transformers, and to understand how scaling and optimization affect their reasoning/memorization capabilities.
AI.method: Systematic empirical study on associative recall across recurrent models (including Mamba/SSMs) and Transformers, manipulating learning rate strategies, width vs. depth scaling, examining 1-layer transformers, and performing architectural ablations to assess effects on performance and optimization stability.
AI.result: Learning rate is a critical factor for recurrent models, which can explain previously reported performance gaps. Recurrent and attention-based models show contrasting benefits when scaling in width vs. depth; attention-based models struggle to solve AR when limited to a single layer. 1-layer transformers exhibit training dynamics resembling induction-head formation observed in deeper models. Architectural ablations reveal how components influence Transformer and Mamba performance and optimization stability.
AI.conclusion: Training stability and appropriate scaling are essential to bridge the gap between SSMs and transformers on AR. Deepening transformers helps with AR, whereas widening alone may not suffice; induction-head-like dynamics can emerge even in very shallow transformers, and careful architectural choices are needed to ensure stable optimization across architectures.

title: Beyond flattening: a geometrically principled positional encoding for vision transformers with Weierstrass elliptic functions
summary:
Vision Transformers have demonstrated remarkable success in computer vision
tasks, yet their reliance on learnable one-dimensional positional embeddings
fundamentally disrupts the inherent two-dimensional spatial structure of images
through patch flattening procedures. Traditional positional encoding approaches
lack geometric constraints and fail to establish monotonic correspondence
between Euclidean spatial distances and sequential index distances, thereby
limiting the model's capacity to leverage spatial proximity priors effectively.
We propose Weierstrass Elliptic Function Positional Encoding (WEF-PE), a
mathematically principled approach that directly addresses two-dimensional
coordinates through natural complex domain representation, where the doubly
periodic properties of elliptic functions align remarkably with translational
invariance patterns commonly observed in visual data. Our method exploits the
non-linear geometric nature of elliptic functions to encode spatial distance
relationships naturally, while the algebraic addition formula enables direct
derivation of relative positional information between arbitrary patch pairs
from their absolute encodings. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that
WEF-PE achieves superior performance across diverse scenarios, including
63.78\% accuracy on CIFAR-100 from-scratch training with ViT-Tiny architecture,
93.28\% on CIFAR-100 fine-tuning with ViT-Base, and consistent improvements on
VTAB-1k benchmark tasks. Theoretical analysis confirms the distance-decay
property through rigorous mathematical proof, while attention visualization
reveals enhanced geometric inductive bias and more coherent semantic focus
compared to conventional approaches.The source code implementing the methods
described in this paper is publicly available on GitHub.

AI.tldr: We propose Weierstrass Elliptic Function Positional Encoding (WEF-PE) for Vision Transformers to encode 2D coordinates directly in the complex domain, leveraging elliptic function properties (doubly periodicity, addition formula) to preserve spatial proximity and enable relative position derivation, yielding improved performance and stronger geometric inductive bias; code available on GitHub.
AI.motivation: Standard 1D, patch-flattened positional encodings disrupt the native 2D geometry of images and lack geometric constraints that tie Euclidean distances to index distances, limiting the model's ability to leverage spatial proximity prior information.
AI.method: Represent 2D image coordinates in the complex plane and encode them with Weierstrass elliptic functions. Exploit the functions' doubly periodic nature to encode two-dimensional spatial structure and use their addition formula to derive relative positions between patch pairs from absolute encodings. Integrate this 2D, geometry-aware encoding into Vision Transformers and support it with theoretical distance-decay analysis and attention visualizations.
AI.result: WEF-PE achieves superior performance across tasks: 63.78% accuracy on CIFAR-100 with ViT-Tiny trained from scratch, 93.28% on CIFAR-100 with ViT-Base fine-tuning, and consistent improvements on VTAB-1k. The approach is supported by a rigorous mathematical proof of distance-decay and attention visualizations showing more coherent geometric focus. Source code is publicly available on GitHub.
AI.conclusion: WEF-PE offers a mathematically principled, geometry-preserving 2D positional encoding for Vision Transformers, enabling direct handling of 2D spatial relationships, improved inductive bias, and practical gains across datasets, with available implementation.

title: Breaking the Black Box: Inherently Interpretable Physics-Informed Machine Learning for Imbalanced Seismic Data
summary:
Ground motion models (GMMs) predict how strongly the ground will shake during
an earthquake. They are essential for structural analysis, seismic design, and
seismic risk assessment studies. Traditional machine learning (ML) approaches
are popular to develop GMMs, due to large earthquake databases worldwide.
However, they operate as "black boxes," which are hard to interpret and trust,
limiting their use in high-stake decisions. Additionally, these databases
suffer from significant data imbalances: fewer large, critically damaging
records near the fault compared to abundant, less severely damaging distant
records. These two limitations are addressed in this work by developing a
transparent ML architecture using the HazBinLoss function. Each input (e.g.,
magnitude, distance, their interaction term, etc.) is processed separately and
added linearly to obtain the output, resulting in exact contribution of each
term. The HazBinLoss function assigns higher weights to critical near-field
large magnitude records and lower weights to less-critical far-field smaller
magnitude records, during training to prevent underprediction of the most
damaging scenarios. Our model captures known seismological principles and
achieves comparable performance with established GMMs while maintaining
transparency. This framework enables broader adoption of ML-based approaches
for risk assessment studies and disaster planning.

AI.tldr: A transparent, additive ML approach for ground motion modeling using HazBinLoss to address data imbalance and interpretability, achieving comparable accuracy to traditional GMMs while revealing term contributions.
AI.motivation: To overcome the black-box nature and data imbalance in earthquake ground-motion modeling, enabling interpretable ML suitable for high-stakes seismic risk assessment and planning.
AI.method: Introduce HazBinLoss to overweight near-field, large-magnitude events during training. Build a transparent architecture where each input feature (e.g., magnitude, distance, interaction) is processed separately and summed to yield the output, providing exact term contributions.
AI.result: The model captures known seismological principles and achieves performance comparable to established GMMs while preserving transparency.
AI.conclusion: This framework supports broader adoption of ML-based GMMs for seismic risk analysis and disaster planning by delivering interpretable predictions without sacrificing accuracy.

title: SoccerNet 2025 Challenges Results
summary:
The SoccerNet 2025 Challenges mark the fifth annual edition of the SoccerNet
open benchmarking effort, dedicated to advancing computer vision research in
football video understanding. This year's challenges span four vision-based
tasks: (1) Team Ball Action Spotting, focused on detecting ball-related actions
in football broadcasts and assigning actions to teams; (2) Monocular Depth
Estimation, targeting the recovery of scene geometry from single-camera
broadcast clips through relative depth estimation for each pixel; (3)
Multi-View Foul Recognition, requiring the analysis of multiple synchronized
camera views to classify fouls and their severity; and (4) Game State
Reconstruction, aimed at localizing and identifying all players from a
broadcast video to reconstruct the game state on a 2D top-view of the field.
Across all tasks, participants were provided with large-scale annotated
datasets, unified evaluation protocols, and strong baselines as starting
points. This report presents the results of each challenge, highlights the
top-performing solutions, and provides insights into the progress made by the
community. The SoccerNet Challenges continue to serve as a driving force for
reproducible, open research at the intersection of computer vision, artificial
intelligence, and sports. Detailed information about the tasks, challenges, and
leaderboards can be found at https://www.soccer-net.org, with baselines and
development kits available at https://github.com/SoccerNet.

AI.tldr: SoccerNet 2025 challenges benchmark four football-video tasks with unified data/evaluation, revealing progress and strong baselines, and fostering open, reproducible research.
AI.motivation: To advance football video understanding through standardized benchmarks, large-scale annotated data, and reproducible evaluation, enabling fair comparison and progress tracking across tasks like action spotting, depth estimation, foul recognition, and game-state reconstruction.
AI.method: Establish a multi-task benchmark (four vision tasks) with large annotated datasets, unified protocols, and baseline models; provide development kits and leaderboards; report results and top solutions for the community.
AI.result: The report summarizes results for each task, identifies top-performing approaches, and provides insights into community progress toward accurate, robust football video understanding.
AI.conclusion: SoccerNet continues to drive reproducible, open research at the intersection of computer vision, AI, and sports, setting a standard for benchmarking and inspiring further advances.

title: Automated discovery of finite volume schemes using Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have deeply modified the landscape of numerical
simulations by demonstrating strong capabilities in approximating solutions of
physical systems. However, their ability to extrapolate beyond their training
domain (\textit{e.g.} larger or structurally different graphs) remains
uncertain. In this work, we establish that GNNs can serve purposes beyond their
traditional role, and be exploited to generate numerical schemes, in
conjunction with symbolic regression. First, we show numerically and
theoretically that a GNN trained on a dataset consisting solely of two-node
graphs can extrapolate a first-order Finite Volume (FV) scheme for the heat
equation on out-of-distribution, unstructured meshes. Specifically, if a GNN
achieves a loss $\varepsilon$ on such a dataset, it implements the FV scheme
with an error of $\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)$. Using symbolic regression, we show
that the network effectively rediscovers the exact analytical formulation of
the standard first-order FV scheme. We then extend this approach to an
unsupervised context: the GNN recovers the first-order FV scheme using only a
residual loss similar to Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) with no
access to ground-truth data. Finally, we push the methodology further by
considering higher-order schemes: we train (i) a 2-hop and (ii) a 2-layers GNN
using the same PINN loss, that autonomously discover (i) a second-order
correction term to the initial scheme using a 2-hop stencil, and (ii) the
classic second-order midpoint scheme. These findings follows a recent paradigm
in scientific computing: GNNs are not only strong approximators, but can be
active contributors to the development of novel numerical methods.

AI.tldr: GNNs trained on simple graph datasets can extrapolate to generate and rediscover numerical schemes for PDEs, evolving from first-order finite-volume methods to higher-order schemes, including unsupervised PINN-style discovery.
AI.motivation: Investigate whether GNNs can do more than approximation: can they extrapolate to new numerical methods and autonomously discover traditional schemes, thereby bridging ML and numerical analysis; assess both supervised and unsupervised (PINN-like) discovery.
AI.method: 1) Train GNNs on two-node graphs and test extrapolation to a first-order FV scheme for the heat equation on unstructured meshes; quantify error: if training loss is ε, extrapolated FV error is O(ε). 2) Use symbolic regression to recover the analytical FV formula from the trained network. 3) In an unsupervised setup, use only a residual/PINN-like loss to recover the FV scheme without ground-truth data. 4) Extend to higher-order: train (i) a 2-hop GNN and (ii) a 2-layer GNN with the same PINN loss to autonomously discover (i) a second-order correction with a 2-hop stencil and (ii) the classic second-order midpoint scheme.
AI.result: The GNN demonstrates extrapolation capability: with small training loss ε on two-node graphs, it effectively implements the first-order FV scheme with error O(ε). Symbolic regression recovers the exact FV formulation. In unsupervised PINN-like training, the GNN recovers the FV scheme without ground-truth data. For higher-order schemes, a 2-hop GNN finds a second-order correction for the scheme, while a 2-layer GNN discovers the classical second-order midpoint scheme.
AI.conclusion: GNNs are not only strong function approximators but can actively contribute to numerical method development by discovering and rediscoving standard and higher-order numerical schemes, and can operate in unsupervised settings to derive these methods from residuals.

title: FastMesh:Efficient Artistic Mesh Generation via Component Decoupling
summary:
Recent mesh generation approaches typically tokenize triangle meshes into
sequences of tokens and train autoregressive models to generate these tokens
sequentially. Despite substantial progress, such token sequences inevitably
reuse vertices multiple times to fully represent manifold meshes, as each
vertex is shared by multiple faces. This redundancy leads to excessively long
token sequences and inefficient generation processes. In this paper, we propose
an efficient framework that generates artistic meshes by treating vertices and
faces separately, significantly reducing redundancy. We employ an
autoregressive model solely for vertex generation, decreasing the token count
to approximately 23\% of that required by the most compact existing tokenizer.
Next, we leverage a bidirectional transformer to complete the mesh in a single
step by capturing inter-vertex relationships and constructing the adjacency
matrix that defines the mesh faces. To further improve the generation quality,
we introduce a fidelity enhancer to refine vertex positioning into more natural
arrangements and propose a post-processing framework to remove undesirable edge
connections. Experimental results show that our method achieves more than
8$\times$ faster speed on mesh generation compared to state-of-the-art
approaches, while producing higher mesh quality.

AI.tldr: Efficient mesh generation by decoupling vertex and face creation: autoregressively generate vertices (reducing token count to ~23% of compact tokenizers), then use a bidirectional transformer to infer the full mesh and adjacency (faces) in one step, with fidelity enhancement and post-processing to refine edges. Claims >8x speedup and higher quality than state-of-the-art.
AI.motivation: Current tokenized mesh generation methods create long token sequences because vertices are shared among faces, leading to redundancy and slow generation. A more compact, faster, and higher-quality approach is needed.
AI.method: 1) Autoregressive generation of vertices only, drastically reducing tokens (~23% of conventional compact tokenizers). 2) A bidirectional transformer completes the mesh by modeling inter-vertex relations and constructing the face adjacency matrix in one shot. 3) Fidelity enhancer to refine vertex positions for natural layouts. 4) Post-processing to remove undesirable edge connections.
AI.result: Experimental results show the method is more than 8 times faster in mesh generation than state-of-the-art approaches and produces higher-quality meshes.
AI.conclusion: Decoupling vertex and face generation with a vertex-focused autoregressive model, followed by a single-shot mesh completion via a bidirectional transformer and refinement/post-processing steps, can substantially improve both efficiency and quality in artistic mesh generation.

title: Tackling Federated Unlearning as a Parameter Estimation Problem
summary:
Privacy regulations require the erasure of data from deep learning models.
This is a significant challenge that is amplified in Federated Learning, where
data remains on clients, making full retraining or coordinated updates often
infeasible. This work introduces an efficient Federated Unlearning framework
based on information theory, modeling leakage as a parameter estimation
problem. Our method uses second-order Hessian information to identify and
selectively reset only the parameters most sensitive to the data being
forgotten, followed by minimal federated retraining. This model-agnostic
approach supports categorical and client unlearning without requiring server
access to raw client data after initial information aggregation. Evaluations on
benchmark datasets demonstrate strong privacy (MIA success near random,
categorical knowledge erased) and high performance (Normalized Accuracy against
re-trained benchmarks of $\approx$ 0.9), while aiming for increased efficiency
over complete retraining. Furthermore, in a targeted backdoor attack scenario,
our framework effectively neutralizes the malicious trigger, restoring model
integrity. This offers a practical solution for data forgetting in FL.

AI.tldr: A model-agnostic Federated Unlearning framework using second-order Hessian to selectively reset sensitive parameters, enabling efficient data forgetting in FL with minimal retraining and backdoor mitigation.
AI.motivation: Privacy regulations require data erasure and FL's data staying on clients makes full retraining infeasible; need a practical forgetting mechanism that preserves performance without raw data access.
AI.method: Models data leakage as a parameter estimation problem using information theory; uses second-order Hessian information to identify parameters most sensitive to forgotten data; resets them and retrains minimally in a federated setting; supports categorical and client unlearning without accessing raw client data after aggregation; model-agnostic.
AI.result: Empirical evaluation shows MIA success near random and categorical knowledge erased; normalized accuracy against retrained benchmarks around 0.9; more efficient than full retraining; also neutralizes targeted backdoor triggers, restoring model integrity.
AI.conclusion: Offers a practical, efficient, model-agnostic solution for data forgetting in Federated Learning with strong privacy and performance guarantees, and backdoor mitigation.

title: All-in-One Slider for Attribute Manipulation in Diffusion Models
summary:
Text-to-image (T2I) diffusion models have made significant strides in
generating high-quality images. However, progressively manipulating certain
attributes of generated images to meet the desired user expectations remains
challenging, particularly for content with rich details, such as human faces.
Some studies have attempted to address this by training slider modules.
However, they follow a One-for-One manner, where an independent slider is
trained for each attribute, requiring additional training whenever a new
attribute is introduced. This not only results in parameter redundancy
accumulated by sliders but also restricts the flexibility of practical
applications and the scalability of attribute manipulation. To address this
issue, we introduce the All-in-One Slider, a lightweight module that decomposes
the text embedding space into sparse, semantically meaningful attribute
directions. Once trained, it functions as a general-purpose slider, enabling
interpretable and fine-grained continuous control over various attributes.
Moreover, by recombining the learned directions, the All-in-One Slider supports
zero-shot manipulation of unseen attributes (e.g., races and celebrities) and
the composition of multiple attributes. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
our method enables accurate and scalable attribute manipulation, achieving
notable improvements compared to previous methods. Furthermore, our method can
be extended to integrate with the inversion framework to perform attribute
manipulation on real images, broadening its applicability to various real-world
scenarios. The code and trained model will be released at:
https://github.com/ywxsuperstar/KSAE-FaceSteer.

AI.tldr: All-in-One Slider: a lightweight, sparse-direction-based slider for text-to-image diffusion that enables continuous, interpretable manipulation of multiple attributes, supports zero-shot and attribute composition, and can be extended to real-image editing via inversion.
AI.motivation: Current One-for-One sliders require training a separate slider per attribute, causing parameter redundancy and limited scalability. There is a demand for flexible, interpretable, and scalable control over rich-detail content (e.g., faces) and for zero-shot handling of unseen attributes.
AI.method: Introduce an All-in-One Slider that decomposes the text embedding space into sparse, semantically meaningful attribute directions; train it as a general-purpose slider to enable continuous control over multiple attributes; recombine learned directions to manipulate unseen attributes (zero-shot) and to compose multiple attributes; optionally integrate with an inversion framework to edit real images.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show accurate and scalable attribute manipulation, with notable improvements over prior methods; demonstrated zero-shot manipulation of unseen attributes (e.g., races, celebrities) and the ability to compose multiple attributes; extends to real images via inversion; code and models to be released.
AI.conclusion: The All-in-One Slider offers interpretable, scalable, and flexible attribute control for text-to-image diffusion, reducing parameter redundancy and enhancing practical applicability, with potential real-image editing via inversion.

title: Dynamic Triangulation-Based Graph Rewiring for Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have emerged as the leading paradigm for
learning over graph-structured data. However, their performance is limited by
issues inherent to graph topology, most notably oversquashing and
oversmoothing. Recent advances in graph rewiring aim to mitigate these
limitations by modifying the graph topology to promote more effective
information propagation. In this work, we introduce TRIGON, a novel framework
that constructs enriched, non-planar triangulations by learning to select
relevant triangles from multiple graph views. By jointly optimizing triangle
selection and downstream classification performance, our method produces a
rewired graph with markedly improved structural properties such as reduced
diameter, increased spectral gap, and lower effective resistance compared to
existing rewiring methods. Empirical results demonstrate that TRIGON
outperforms state-of-the-art approaches on node classification tasks across a
range of homophilic and heterophilic benchmarks.

AI.tldr: TRIGON learns to select triangles from multiple graph views to create enriched, non-planar triangulations, enabling effective rewiring that improves information propagation and node classification.
AI.motivation: GNNs suffer from oversquashing and oversmoothing due to topology; current rewiring methods modify graphs but often don’t optimize global structural properties. A principled, end-to-end approach that directly optimizes topology for classification promises better propagation across both homophilic and heterophilic graphs.
