AI.method: TRIGON constructs enriched, non-planar triangulations by learning to select relevant triangles from multiple graph views and jointly optimizes triangle selection with the downstream classification objective, yielding a rewired graph with improved structural properties.
AI.result: Empirical results show TRIGON outperforms state-of-the-art rewiring methods on node classification across both homophilic and heterophilic benchmarks and achieves graphs with lower diameter, larger spectral gap, and lower effective resistance.
AI.conclusion: TRIGON provides a principled, end-to-end framework for topology-aware graph rewiring via learned triangulations, enhancing information propagation and classification performance across diverse graph regimes.

title: LSD-3D: Large-Scale 3D Driving Scene Generation with Geometry Grounding
summary:
Large-scale scene data is essential for training and testing in robot
learning. Neural reconstruction methods have promised the capability of
reconstructing large physically-grounded outdoor scenes from captured sensor
data. However, these methods have baked-in static environments and only allow
for limited scene control -- they are functionally constrained in scene and
trajectory diversity by the captures from which they are reconstructed. In
contrast, generating driving data with recent image or video diffusion models
offers control, however, at the cost of geometry grounding and causality. In
this work, we aim to bridge this gap and present a method that directly
generates large-scale 3D driving scenes with accurate geometry, allowing for
causal novel view synthesis with object permanence and explicit 3D geometry
estimation. The proposed method combines the generation of a proxy geometry and
environment representation with score distillation from learned 2D image
priors. We find that this approach allows for high controllability, enabling
the prompt-guided geometry and high-fidelity texture and structure that can be
conditioned on map layouts -- producing realistic and geometrically consistent
3D generations of complex driving scenes.

AI.tldr: A diffusion-assisted 3D driving-scene generation framework that yields controllable, geometry-grounded, large-scale scenes by jointly modeling proxy geometry and environment, guided by 2D priors and map layouts, enabling causal novel-view synthesis and object permanence.
AI.motivation: Current image/video diffusion models offer controllable generation but lack reliable geometry grounding and causality; traditional neural reconstructions create static scenes with limited diversity. There is a need for scalable, geometry-consistent 3D driving data that can be steered by prompts and maps.
AI.method: Proposes a pipeline that generates proxy geometry and an environment representation, then performs score distillation from learned 2D image priors to align 3D geometry and texture with 2D cues. The system supports prompt-driven geometry and map-conditioned realizations, producing high-fidelity, geometrically consistent 3D driving scenes with object permanence.
AI.result: The approach achieves high controllability and realistic geometry-texture fidelity, enabling causal novel-view synthesis and explicit 3D geometry estimation within large-scale driving scenes conditioned on map layouts.
AI.conclusion: Bridges diffusion-based controllable image generation with explicit 3D geometry grounding, enabling scalable, realistic, and manipulable 3D driving scene generation suitable for training/testing large-scale robotics data pipelines.

title: APT-LLM: Exploiting Arbitrary-Precision Tensor Core Computing for LLM Acceleration
comment:
To appear in the IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of
  Integrated Circuits and Systems (TCAD)
summary:
Large language models (LLMs) have revolutionized AI applications, yet their
enormous computational demands severely limit deployment and real-time
performance. Quantization methods can help reduce computational costs, however,
attaining the extreme efficiency associated with ultra-low-bit quantized LLMs
at arbitrary precision presents challenges on GPUs. This is primarily due to
the limited support for GPU Tensor Cores, inefficient memory management, and
inflexible kernel optimizations. To tackle these challenges, we propose a
comprehensive acceleration scheme for arbitrary precision LLMs, namely APT-LLM.
Firstly, we introduce a novel data format, bipolar-INT, which allows for
efficient and lossless conversion with signed INT, while also being more
conducive to parallel computation. We also develop a matrix multiplication
(MatMul) method allowing for arbitrary precision by dismantling and
reassembling matrices at the bit level. This method provides flexible precision
and optimizes the utilization of GPU Tensor Cores. In addition, we propose a
memory management system focused on data recovery, which strategically employs
fast shared memory to substantially increase kernel execution speed and reduce
memory access latency. Finally, we develop a kernel mapping method that
dynamically selects the optimal configurable hyperparameters of kernels for
varying matrix sizes, enabling optimal performance across different LLM
architectures and precision settings. In LLM inference, APT-LLM achieves up to
a 3.99$\times$ speedup compared to FP16 baselines and a 2.16$\times$ speedup
over NVIDIA CUTLASS INT4 acceleration on RTX 3090. On RTX 4090 and H800,
APT-LLM achieves up to 2.44$\times$ speedup over FP16 and 1.65$\times$ speedup
over CUTLASS integer baselines.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive acceleration framework (APT-LLM) for arbitrary-precision LLM inference on GPUs, combining bipolar-INT data format, bit-level MatMul, memory management leveraging shared memory, and dynamic kernel mapping to achieve significant speedups over FP16 and INT4 baselines.
AI.motivation: Ultra-low-bit quantization for LLMs at arbitrary precision is hampered by limited GPU Tensor Core support, memory bottlenecks, and inflexible kernels, hindering practical deployment and real-time performance.
AI.method: Introduce bipolar-INT data format; develop a bit-level MatMul that dismantles/reassembles matrices for arbitrary precision; design memory management with fast shared memory for data recovery; implement a kernel mapping strategy to automatically select optimal kernel hyperparameters for different matrix sizes and architectures.
AI.result: Demonstrates up to 3.99x speedup over FP16 baselines and 2.16x over CUTLASS INT4 on RTX 3090; on RTX 4090 and H800, up to 2.44x speedup over FP16 and 1.65x over CUTLASS integer baselines.
AI.conclusion: APT-LLM provides a holistic acceleration scheme enabling efficient arbitrary-precision LLM inference across diverse GPUs, by integrating a novel data format, bit-level matrix operations, memory optimization, and adaptive kernel mapping to unlock practical ultra-efficient quantized LLM deployment.

title: OmniHuman-1.5: Instilling an Active Mind in Avatars via Cognitive Simulation
summary:
Existing video avatar models can produce fluid human animations, yet they
struggle to move beyond mere physical likeness to capture a character's
authentic essence. Their motions typically synchronize with low-level cues like
audio rhythm, lacking a deeper semantic understanding of emotion, intent, or
context. To bridge this gap, \textbf{we propose a framework designed to
generate character animations that are not only physically plausible but also
semantically coherent and expressive.} Our model, \textbf{OmniHuman-1.5}, is
built upon two key technical contributions. First, we leverage Multimodal Large
Language Models to synthesize a structured textual representation of conditions
that provides high-level semantic guidance. This guidance steers our motion
generator beyond simplistic rhythmic synchronization, enabling the production
of actions that are contextually and emotionally resonant. Second, to ensure
the effective fusion of these multimodal inputs and mitigate inter-modality
conflicts, we introduce a specialized Multimodal DiT architecture with a novel
Pseudo Last Frame design. The synergy of these components allows our model to
accurately interpret the joint semantics of audio, images, and text, thereby
generating motions that are deeply coherent with the character, scene, and
linguistic content. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our model achieves
leading performance across a comprehensive set of metrics, including lip-sync
accuracy, video quality, motion naturalness and semantic consistency with
textual prompts. Furthermore, our approach shows remarkable extensibility to
complex scenarios, such as those involving multi-person and non-human subjects.
Homepage: \href{https://omnihuman-lab.github.io/v1_5/}

AI.tldr: OmniHuman-1.5 presents a framework that combines multimodal LLM-driven semantic guidance with a Multimodal DiT (Pseudo Last Frame) to generate character animations that are physically plausible and semantically coherent, achieving strong lip-sync, video quality, motion naturalness, and semantic consistency, and generalizing to multi-person and non-human subjects.
AI.motivation: Existing video avatar models produce realistic motion but lack deep semantic understanding of emotion, intent, and context, often syncing with rhythm rather than semantic content. There is a need for integrating audio, imagery, and text to produce expressive, context-aware animations.
AI.method: 1) Use Multimodal Large Language Models to synthesize a structured textual representation of conditions, providing high-level semantic guidance for the motion generator. 2) Introduce a Multimodal DiT architecture with a novel Pseudo Last Frame design to effectively fuse multimodal inputs and mitigate inter-modality conflicts. 3) The model interprets joint semantics of audio, images, and text to generate motions coherent with character, scene, and linguistic content.
AI.result: Extensive experiments show leading performance across metrics: lip-sync accuracy, video quality, motion naturalness, and semantic consistency with textual prompts. The approach also scales to complex scenarios including multiple people and non-human subjects.
AI.conclusion: The framework delivers physically plausible and semantically coherent, expressive character animations by integrating multimodal semantic guidance with a robust fusion architecture, with strong generalization to complex scenes.

title: Composition and Alignment of Diffusion Models using Constrained Learning
summary:
Diffusion models have become prevalent in generative modeling due to their
ability to sample from complex distributions. To improve the quality of
generated samples and their compliance with user requirements, two commonly
used methods are: (i) Alignment, which involves fine-tuning a diffusion model
to align it with a reward; and (ii) Composition, which combines several
pre-trained diffusion models, each emphasizing a desirable attribute in the
generated outputs. However, trade-offs often arise when optimizing for multiple
rewards or combining multiple models, as they can often represent competing
properties. Existing methods cannot guarantee that the resulting model
faithfully generates samples with all the desired properties. To address this
gap, we propose a constrained optimization framework that unifies alignment and
composition of diffusion models by enforcing that the aligned model satisfies
reward constraints and/or remains close to (potentially multiple) pre-trained
models. We provide a theoretical characterization of the solutions to the
constrained alignment and composition problems and develop a Lagrangian-based
primal-dual training algorithm to approximate these solutions. Empirically, we
demonstrate the effectiveness and merits of our proposed approach in image
generation, applying it to alignment and composition, and show that our aligned
or composed model satisfies constraints effectively, and improves on the
equally-weighted approach. Our implementation can be found at
https://github.com/shervinkhalafi/constrained_comp_align.

AI.tldr: A unified constrained optimization framework for diffusion-model alignment and model composition, enforcing reward constraints and closeness to pre-trained models via a Lagrangian primal-dual algorithm, with theoretical guarantees and empirical validation in image generation.
AI.motivation: In multi-objective diffusion generation, aligning to rewards and composing multiple models can conflict, and existing methods cannot guarantee satisfaction of all desired properties. A principled framework is needed to ensure constraints are met while leveraging pre-trained priors.
AI.method: Formulate alignment and composition as constrained optimization problems over diffusion models. Introduce a Lagrangian-based primal-dual training algorithm to approximate solutions, along with theoretical characterizations of the solution set. Applies the framework to both alignment and composition and analyzes trade-offs under constraints.
AI.result: Theoretical characterization of constrained-alignment/composition solutions; a practical primal-dual algorithm that approximates these solutions; empirical results on image generation showing constraint satisfaction and improvements over equally-weighted baselines; open-source implementation.
AI.conclusion: The framework unifies alignment and composition under a principled constrained-optimization approach, enabling multiple rewards and priors to be enforced simultaneously with performance gains and guarantees, advancing multi-property diffusion model generation.

title: Automated Feature Tracking for Real-Time Kinematic Analysis and Shape Estimation of Carbon Nanotube Growth
comment:
Accepted at IEEE/CVF ICCV 2025, CV4MS Workshop (Computer Vision for
  Materials Science), Code available at: https://github.com/kavehsfv/VFTrack
summary:
Carbon nanotubes (CNTs) are critical building blocks in nanotechnology, yet
the characterization of their dynamic growth is limited by the experimental
challenges in nanoscale motion measurement using scanning electron microscopy
(SEM) imaging. Existing ex situ methods offer only static analysis, while in
situ techniques often require manual initialization and lack continuous
per-particle trajectory decomposition. We present Visual Feature Tracking
(VFTrack) an in-situ real-time particle tracking framework that automatically
detects and tracks individual CNT particles in SEM image sequences. VFTrack
integrates handcrafted or deep feature detectors and matchers within a particle
tracking framework to enable kinematic analysis of CNT micropillar growth. A
systematic using 13,540 manually annotated trajectories identifies the ALIKED
detector with LightGlue matcher as an optimal combination (F1-score of 0.78,
$\alpha$-score of 0.89). VFTrack motion vectors decomposed into axial growth,
lateral drift, and oscillations, facilitate the calculation of heterogeneous
regional growth rates and the reconstruction of evolving CNT pillar
morphologies. This work enables advancement in automated nano-material
characterization, bridging the gap between physics-based models and
experimental observation to enable real-time optimization of CNT synthesis.

AI.tldr: An in-situ CNT tracking framework (VFTrack) for SEM sequences that automatically detects and tracks individual CNT particles, enabling real-time kinematic analysis and pillar morphology reconstruction using ALIKED detector + LightGlue matcher (F1=0.78, α=0.89) on 13,540 annotated trajectories.
AI.motivation: Current in-situ SEM tracking struggles with manual initialization, discontinuous per-particle trajectories, and lack of real-time analysis. There is a need for automated, continuous tracking to quantify CNT growth dynamics and optimize synthesis.
AI.method: Integrates either handcrafted or deep feature detectors with a matcher within a particle-tracking framework. Systematically evaluated 13,540 manually annotated trajectories to identify the optimal combination (ALIKED detector + LightGlue matcher). Motion vectors are decomposed into axial growth, lateral drift, and oscillations to compute regional growth rates and reconstruct evolving CNT pillar morphologies in real time.
AI.result: Optimal detector/matcher combination (ALIKED + LightGlue) achieved F1-score 0.78 and α-score 0.89 on the annotated dataset. VFTrack enables decomposition of particle motion and reconstruction of CNT pillar dynamics, supporting automated, real-time nano-material characterization.
AI.conclusion: VFTrack closes the gap between physics-based CNT growth models and experimental observation, enabling real-time optimization of CNT synthesis through automated, in-situ tracking and kinematic analysis.

title: Active Query Selection for Crowd-Based Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Preference-based reinforcement learning has gained prominence as a strategy
for training agents in environments where the reward signal is difficult to
specify or misaligned with human intent. However, its effectiveness is often
limited by the high cost and low availability of reliable human input,
especially in domains where expert feedback is scarce or errors are costly. To
address this, we propose a novel framework that combines two complementary
strategies: probabilistic crowd modelling to handle noisy, multi-annotator
feedback, and active learning to prioritize feedback on the most informative
agent actions. We extend the Advise algorithm to support multiple trainers,
estimate their reliability online, and incorporate entropy-based query
selection to guide feedback requests. We evaluate our approach in a set of
environments that span both synthetic and real-world-inspired settings,
including 2D games (Taxi, Pacman, Frozen Lake) and a blood glucose control task
for Type 1 Diabetes using the clinically approved UVA/Padova simulator. Our
preliminary results demonstrate that agents trained with feedback on uncertain
trajectories exhibit faster learning in most tasks, and we outperform the
baselines for the blood glucose control task.

AI.tldr: A probabilistic crowd modelling + active learning framework for preference-based RL that handles noisy multi-annotator feedback and informative-action querying; extends Advise to multiple trainers and uses entropy-based queries; demonstrated on Taxi, Pacman, Frozen Lake, and a Type 1 Diabetes blood glucose control task with UVA/Padova simulator; shows faster learning and improved glucose control.
AI.motivation: Human feedback in preference-based RL is costly and error-prone; leveraging multiple annotators and focusing on informative actions can improve data efficiency and robustness.
AI.method: Extend Advise to multi-trainer setting; online estimation of trainer reliability; entropy-based query selection; probabilistic crowd model to aggregate feedback; evaluation on 2D games and a clinical glucose control task using UVA/Padova simulator.
AI.result: Agents trained on uncertain trajectories exhibit faster learning in most tasks; the approach outperforms baselines on the blood glucose control task.
AI.conclusion: The combination of probabilistic crowd modelling and active learning improves data efficiency and resilience to annotator noise in preference-based RL; promising for domains with scarce expert feedback.

title: Autoregressive Universal Video Segmentation Model
summary:
Recent video foundation models such as SAM2 excel at prompted video
segmentation by treating masks as a general-purpose primitive. However, many
real-world settings require unprompted segmentation that aims to detect and
track all objects in a video without external cues, leaving today's landscape
fragmented across task-specific models and pipelines. We recast streaming video
segmentation as sequential mask prediction, analogous to language modeling, and
introduce the Autoregressive Universal Segmentation Model (AUSM), a single
architecture that unifies both prompted and unprompted video segmentation.
Built on recent state-space models, AUSM maintains a fixed-size spatial state
and scales to video streams of arbitrary length. Furthermore, all components of
AUSM are designed for parallel training across frames, yielding substantial
speedups over iterative training. On standard benchmarks (DAVIS17, YouTube-VOS
2018 & 2019, MOSE, YouTube-VIS 2019 & 2021, and OVIS) AUSM outperforms prior
universal streaming video segmentation methods and achieves up to 2.5x faster
training on 16-frame sequences.

AI.tldr: Autoregressive Universal Segmentation Model (AUSM) unifies prompted and unprompted video segmentation by sequentially predicting masks with a fixed spatial state, enabling streaming and parallel training with strong benchmarks.
AI.motivation: To unify prompted and unprompted video segmentation and support long, streaming video inputs with efficient training/inference using a fixed-size spatial state.
AI.method: Develop AUSM on state-space model foundations; maintain fixed spatial state, predict masks autoregressively over time; enable parallel training across frames; evaluate on standard video segmentation benchmarks.
AI.result: Outperforms prior universal streaming methods; achieves up to 2.5x faster training on 16-frame sequences; competitive or superior performance on multiple benchmarks.
AI.conclusion: AUSM provides a unified, scalable approach that bridges both segmentation settings and enables efficient long-sequence video segmentation.

title: Saddle Hierarchy in Dense Associative Memory
summary:
Dense associative memory (DAM) models have been attracting renewed attention
since they were shown to be robust to adversarial examples and closely related
to state-of-the-art machine learning paradigms, such as the attention
mechanisms in transformers and generative diffusion models. We study a DAM
built upon a three-layer Boltzmann machine with Potts hidden units, which
represent data clusters and classes. Through a statistical mechanics analysis,
we derive saddle-point equations that characterize both the stationary points
of DAMs trained on real data and the fixed points of DAMs trained on synthetic
data within a teacher-student framework. Based on these results, we propose a
novel regularization scheme that makes training significantly more stable.
Moreover, we show empirically that our DAM learns interpretable solutions to
both supervised and unsupervised classification problems. Pushing our
theoretical analysis further, we find that the weights learned by relatively
small DAMs correspond to unstable saddle points in larger DAMs. We implement a
network-growing algorithm that leverages this saddle-point hierarchy to
drastically reduce the computational cost of training dense associative memory.

AI.tldr: A Boltzmann dense associative memory (DAM) with Potts hidden units is analyzed via statistical mechanics to map its energy landscape and training dynamics. The authors derive saddle-point equations for DAMs trained on real and synthetic data, introduce a novel regularization that stabilizes training, and demonstrate interpretable solutions for supervised/unsupervised tasks. They reveal a saddle-point hierarchy whereby small DAMs’ weights correspond to unstable saddles in larger DAMs, and propose a network-growing algorithm to dramatically reduce training cost.
AI.motivation: To understand the theoretical underpinnings of DAMs in modern contexts, improve training stability and interpretability, and achieve scalable training by exploiting the relationship between small and large DAMs. The work also aims to connect DAMs with contemporary ML paradigms and robustness considerations.
AI.method: Perform a statistical-mechanics analysis of a three-layer Boltzmann DAM with Potts hidden units; derive saddle-point equations for both real-data-trained and teacher-student (synthetic-data-trained) settings. Propose a regularization scheme based on these insights. Validate empirically on supervised and unsupervised tasks and study weight configurations across network sizes. Develop a network-growing algorithm to leverage the saddle-point hierarchy for efficiency.
AI.result: Regularization leads to more stable training. The DAM learns interpretable solutions for both supervised and unsupervised problems. Weights of small DAMs align with unstable saddle points in larger DAMs, enabling a growth strategy that drastically reduces training cost without sacrificing performance.
AI.conclusion: The study provides a principled link between the energy landscape of DAMs and their trainability, interpretable representations, and scalability. Exposing a saddle-point hierarchy enables efficient training through network growth, and highlights connections between DAMs and broader ML mechanisms like attention and diffusion models.

title: Style4D-Bench: A Benchmark Suite for 4D Stylization
summary:
We introduce Style4D-Bench, the first benchmark suite specifically designed
for 4D stylization, with the goal of standardizing evaluation and facilitating
progress in this emerging area. Style4D-Bench comprises: 1) a comprehensive
evaluation protocol measuring spatial fidelity, temporal coherence, and
multi-view consistency through both perceptual and quantitative metrics, 2) a
strong baseline that make an initial attempt for 4D stylization, and 3) a
curated collection of high-resolution dynamic 4D scenes with diverse motions
and complex backgrounds. To establish a strong baseline, we present Style4D, a
novel framework built upon 4D Gaussian Splatting. It consists of three key
components: a basic 4DGS scene representation to capture reliable geometry, a
Style Gaussian Representation that leverages lightweight per-Gaussian MLPs for
temporally and spatially aware appearance control, and a Holistic
Geometry-Preserved Style Transfer module designed to enhance spatio-temporal
consistency via contrastive coherence learning and structural content
preservation. Extensive experiments on Style4D-Bench demonstrate that Style4D
achieves state-of-the-art performance in 4D stylization, producing fine-grained
stylistic details with stable temporal dynamics and consistent multi-view
rendering. We expect Style4D-Bench to become a valuable resource for
benchmarking and advancing research in stylized rendering of dynamic 3D scenes.
Project page: https://becky-catherine.github.io/Style4D . Code:
https://github.com/Becky-catherine/Style4D-Bench .

AI.tldr: Introduces Style4D-Bench, a benchmark suite for 4D stylization, plus Style4D baseline on 4D Gaussian Splatting, featuring an evaluation protocol, baseline model, and a diverse high‑resolution 4D scene collection to standardize evaluation and accelerate progress.
AI.motivation: There is no standardized benchmark for 4D stylization. A unified evaluation protocol across spatial fidelity, temporal coherence, and multi-view consistency is needed to fairly compare methods and drive progress in this emerging area.
AI.method: Style4D-Bench provides an evaluation protocol with perceptual and quantitative metrics for spatial, temporal, and multi-view aspects. It also supplies a baseline model, Style4D, built on 4D Gaussian Splatting (4DGS). Style4D comprises: (1) a basic 4DGS scene representation to capture geometry; (2) a Style Gaussian Representation with lightweight per-Gaussian MLPs for temporally/spatially aware appearance control; (3) a Holistic Geometry-Preserved Style Transfer module that enhances spatio-temporal consistency via contrastive coherence learning and content preservation.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on Style4D-Bench show Style4D achieves state-of-the-art performance in 4D stylization, delivering fine-grained stylistic detail with stable temporal dynamics and consistent multi-view rendering.
AI.conclusion: Style4D-Bench is a valuable benchmarking resource for the stylized rendering of dynamic 3D scenes and is expected to catalyze future research. The paper provides project code and a dedicated page for accessibility.

title: Get Global Guarantees: On the Probabilistic Nature of Perturbation Robustness
summary:
In safety-critical deep learning applications, robustness measures the
ability of neural models that handle imperceptible perturbations in input data,
which may lead to potential safety hazards. Existing pre-deployment robustness
assessment methods typically suffer from significant trade-offs between
computational cost and measurement precision, limiting their practical utility.
To address these limitations, this paper conducts a comprehensive comparative
analysis of existing robustness definitions and associated assessment
methodologies. We propose tower robustness to evaluate robustness, which is a
novel, practical metric based on hypothesis testing to quantitatively evaluate
probabilistic robustness, enabling more rigorous and efficient pre-deployment
assessments. Our extensive comparative evaluation illustrates the advantages
and applicability of our proposed approach, thereby advancing the systematic
understanding and enhancement of model robustness in safety-critical deep
learning applications.

AI.tldr: Introduces tower robustness, a hypothesis-testing-based metric for probabilistic robustness, alongside a comprehensive comparison of existing robustness definitions and assessment methods to enable efficient pre-deployment evaluation in safety-critical DL.
AI.motivation: To overcome the costly-precision trade-offs of current pre-deployment robustness assessments and provide a practical, statistically grounded framework for evaluating robustness under imperceptible perturbations in safety-critical deep learning models.
AI.method: Perform a comprehensive comparative analysis of existing robustness definitions and assessment methodologies, and propose tower robustness as a novel metric based on hypothesis testing to quantify probabilistic robustness.
AI.result: Extensive comparative evaluation demonstrates the advantages and applicability of tower robustness, enabling more rigorous and efficient pre-deployment assessments.
AI.conclusion: Tower robustness advances systematic understanding and enhancement of model robustness in safety-critical deep learning, offering a practical, scalable approach for pre-deployment robustness evaluation.

title: Articulate3D: Zero-Shot Text-Driven 3D Object Posing
summary:
We propose a training-free method, Articulate3D, to pose a 3D asset through
language control. Despite advances in vision and language models, this task
remains surprisingly challenging. To achieve this goal, we decompose the
problem into two steps. We modify a powerful image-generator to create target
images conditioned on the input image and a text instruction. We then align the
mesh to the target images through a multi-view pose optimisation step. In
detail, we introduce a self-attention rewiring mechanism (RSActrl) that
decouples the source structure from pose within an image generative model,
allowing it to maintain a consistent structure across varying poses. We
observed that differentiable rendering is an unreliable signal for articulation
optimisation; instead, we use keypoints to establish correspondences between
input and target images. The effectiveness of Articulate3D is demonstrated
across a diverse range of 3D objects and free-form text prompts, successfully
manipulating poses while maintaining the original identity of the mesh.
Quantitative evaluations and a comparative user study, in which our method was
preferred over 85\% of the time, confirm its superiority over existing
approaches. Project page:https://odeb1.github.io/articulate3d_page_deb/

AI.tldr: A training-free method (Articulate3D) edits 3D mesh poses via language by generating target views with a modified image generator and performing multi-view pose optimization using keypoints, preserving identity; user study favors it over rivals.
AI.motivation: Pose editing of 3D assets via natural language remains challenging and often requires training data or compromises on identity/consistency; a training-free, generalizable solution is highly desirable.
AI.method: Two-stage approach: (1) modify a powerful image generator with a self-attention rewiring mechanism (RSActrl) to decouple source structure from pose so the same structure is maintained across poses; (2) generate target images conditioned on the input image and a text instruction; (3) use keypoints to establish correspondences between input and target images (instead of differentiable rendering) and perform multi-view pose optimization to align the mesh to the targets.
AI.result: Demonstrates effective pose manipulation across diverse 3D objects and free-form prompts while preserving mesh identity; quantitative metrics and a user study show strong performance, with over 85% of participants preferring it to existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: Articulate3D demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of a training-free, language-controlled 3D pose editing pipeline. The RSActrl mechanism and keypoint-based optimization contribute robustness and identity preservation across poses, though limitations may lie in keypoint reliability and articulation complexity; the method achieves strong user preference and outperforms competing methods.

title: Emotions as Ambiguity-aware Ordinal Representations
summary:
Emotions are inherently ambiguous and dynamic phenomena, yet existing
continuous emotion recognition approaches either ignore their ambiguity or
treat ambiguity as an independent and static variable over time. Motivated by
this gap in the literature, in this paper we introduce \emph{ambiguity-aware
ordinal} emotion representations, a novel framework that captures both the
ambiguity present in emotion annotation and the inherent temporal dynamics of
emotional traces. Specifically, we propose approaches that model emotion
ambiguity through its rate of change. We evaluate our framework on two
affective corpora -- RECOLA and GameVibe -- testing our proposed approaches on
both bounded (arousal, valence) and unbounded (engagement) continuous traces.
Our results demonstrate that ordinal representations outperform conventional
ambiguity-aware models on unbounded labels, achieving the highest Concordance
Correlation Coefficient (CCC) and Signed Differential Agreement (SDA) scores,
highlighting their effectiveness in modeling the traces' dynamics. For bounded
traces, ordinal representations excel in SDA, revealing their superior ability
to capture relative changes of annotated emotion traces.

AI.tldr: We propose ambiguity-aware ordinal emotion representations that model annotation ambiguity via its rate of change to capture temporal dynamics, and show superior performance on unbounded (engagement) and bounded (arousal/valence) traces on RECOLA and GameVibe.
AI.motivation: Emotions are inherently ambiguous and dynamic; existing continuous emotion recognition often treats ambiguity as static or ignores it, leaving a gap for temporal modeling of ambiguity.
AI.method: Introduce an ambiguity-aware ordinal framework that encodes ambiguity through its rate-of-change and applies ordinal representations to emotion traces; evaluate on RECOLA and GameVibe with both bounded (arousal, valence) and unbounded (engagement) labels.
AI.result: Ordinal representations outperform conventional ambiguity-aware models on unbounded labels (highest CCC and SDA), and show superior SDA on bounded traces, indicating better capture of relative changes and dynamics.
AI.conclusion: Modeling ambiguity as a dynamic, rate-of-change quantity via ordinal representations effectively captures temporal dynamics of emotion traces, especially for unbounded signals; the approach improves performance over static ambiguity models.

title: VoxHammer: Training-Free Precise and Coherent 3D Editing in Native 3D Space
summary:
3D local editing of specified regions is crucial for game industry and robot
interaction. Recent methods typically edit rendered multi-view images and then
reconstruct 3D models, but they face challenges in precisely preserving
unedited regions and overall coherence. Inspired by structured 3D generative
models, we propose VoxHammer, a novel training-free approach that performs
precise and coherent editing in 3D latent space. Given a 3D model, VoxHammer
first predicts its inversion trajectory and obtains its inverted latents and
key-value tokens at each timestep. Subsequently, in the denoising and editing
phase, we replace the denoising features of preserved regions with the
corresponding inverted latents and cached key-value tokens. By retaining these
contextual features, this approach ensures consistent reconstruction of
preserved areas and coherent integration of edited parts. To evaluate the
consistency of preserved regions, we constructed Edit3D-Bench, a
human-annotated dataset comprising hundreds of samples, each with carefully
labeled 3D editing regions. Experiments demonstrate that VoxHammer
significantly outperforms existing methods in terms of both 3D consistency of
preserved regions and overall quality. Our method holds promise for
synthesizing high-quality edited paired data, thereby laying the data
foundation for in-context 3D generation. See our project page at
https://huanngzh.github.io/VoxHammer-Page/.

AI.tldr: VoxHammer is a training-free method for precise, coherent 3D editing in latent space. It inverts a structured 3D generative model to obtain per-timestep latents and key-value tokens, then swaps preserved-region denoising features with these inverted latents to maintain consistency. It introduces Edit3D-Bench for evaluation and reports superior 3D consistency and quality over prior work.
AI.motivation: Current 3D editing pipelines often rely on editing rendered views and re-synthesizing 3D geometry, which struggles to keep unedited regions intact and maintain global coherence. A training-free, latent-space approach promises more precise, coherent edits with less data/compute.
AI.method: Predict the inversion trajectory of the input 3D model to obtain inverted latents and per-timestep key-value tokens. During denoising/editing, replace denoising features of preserved regions with the corresponding inverted latents and cached tokens, preserving context to ensure coherent reconstruction. Construct Edit3D-Bench (human-annotated with labeled editing regions) for evaluation. Compare against prior methods on 3D consistency and quality.
AI.result: VoxHammer significantly outperforms existing methods in 3D consistency of preserved regions and overall quality in experiments. The authors also provide a dataset (Edit3D-Bench) to benchmark region-preserving fidelity and argue the approach is well-suited for generating edited paired data for in-context 3D generation.
AI.conclusion: A training-free, latent-space editing framework can achieve precise, coherent edits in 3D by preserving regional context through inverted latents/tokens; VoxHammer’s strategy and the Edit3D-Bench dataset advance 3D in-context editing and data synthesis for future 3D generation tasks.

title: Understanding Tool-Integrated Reasoning
summary:
We study why Tool-Integrated Reasoning (TIR) makes Large Language Models
(LLMs) more capable. While LLMs integrated with tools like Python code
interpreters show great promise, a principled theory explaining why this
paradigm is effective has been missing. This work provides the first formal
proof that TIR fundamentally expands an LLM's capabilities. We demonstrate that
tools enable a strict expansion of the model's empirical and feasible support,
breaking the capability ceiling of pure-text models by unlocking
problem-solving strategies that are otherwise impossible or intractably
verbose. To guide model behavior without compromising training stability and
performance, we also introduce Advantage Shaping Policy Optimization (ASPO), a
novel algorithm that directly modifies the advantage function to guide the
policy behavior. We conduct comprehensive experiments on challenging
mathematical benchmarks, leveraging a Python interpreter as the external tool.
Our results show that the TIR model decisively outperforms its pure-text
counterpart on the pass@k metric. Crucially, this advantage is not confined to
computationally-intensive problems but extends to those requiring significant
abstract insight. We further identify the emergent cognitive patterns that
illustrate how models learn to think with tools. Finally, we report improved
tool usage behavior with early code invocation and much more interactive turns
with ASPO. Overall, our work provides the first principled explanation for
TIR's success, shifting the focus from the mere fact that tools work to why and
how they enable more powerful reasoning.

AI.tldr: Formal analysis showing Tool-Integrated Reasoning (TIR) expands LLM capabilities via tool use; introduces Advantage Shaping Policy Optimization (ASPO); empirical gains on math benchmarks using a Python interpreter; presents first principled explanation for TIR's success.
AI.motivation: There is no established theory explaining why tool integration improves LLM reasoning. A principled account is needed to understand the mechanisms and guide future design.
AI.method: Provide a formal proof that tools expand an LLM's empirical and feasible support; propose ASPO to shape policy by modifying the advantage function; conduct experiments on challenging mathematical benchmarks using a Python interpreter as the external tool; analyze tool usage patterns and emergent cognitive behaviors.
AI.result: TIR-based models outperform pure-text LLMs on pass@k metrics; gains extend beyond computation-heavy tasks to problems requiring abstract insight; emergence of cognitive patterns in how models think with tools; ASPO leads to earlier tool invocation and more interactive sessions.
AI.conclusion: This work offers the first principled explanation for TIR's success, shifting focus from whether tools work to how and why they enable more powerful reasoning; introduces ASPO as a practical mechanism to guide tool-enabled policy and better tool usage.

title: Predicting the Order of Upcoming Tokens Improves Language Modeling
summary:
Multi-Token Prediction (MTP) has been proposed as an auxiliary objective to
improve next-token prediction (NTP) in language model training but shows
inconsistent improvements, underperforming in standard NLP benchmarks. We argue
that MTP's exact future token prediction is too difficult as an auxiliary loss.
Instead, we propose Token Order Prediction (TOP), which trains models to order
upcoming tokens by their proximity using a learning-to-rank loss. TOP requires
only a single additional unembedding layer compared to MTP's multiple
transformer layers. We pretrain models of 340M, 1.8B, and 7B parameters using
NTP, MTP, and TOP objectives. Results on eight standard NLP benchmarks show
that TOP overall outperforms both NTP and MTP even at scale. Our code is
available at https://github.com/zaydzuhri/token-order-prediction

AI.tldr: Token Order Prediction (TOP) uses a learning-to-rank objective to order upcoming tokens by proximity, improving next-token prediction (NTP) more reliably than Multi-Token Prediction (MTP) and outperforms both on eight NLP benchmarks, with minimal architectural overhead (one extra unembedding layer).
AI.motivation: The exact future-token prediction objective used by MTP is too difficult, yielding inconsistent gains. A simpler, more robust auxiliary objective is needed to better guide language model training.
AI.method: Introduce TOP as an alternative to MTP. Train models to rank upcoming tokens by their proximity using a learning-to-rank loss, requiring only a single additional unembedding layer compared to MTP's multiple transformer layers. Pretrain models of 340M, 1.8B, and 7B parameters under NTP, MTP, and TOP objectives. Evaluate on eight standard NLP benchmarks.
AI.result: TOP consistently outperforms both NTP and MTP across the evaluated scales and eight benchmarks, indicating that the learning-to-rank token ordering objective provides a stronger and more scalable auxiliary signal for next-token prediction.
AI.conclusion: Token Order Prediction is a practical, scalable improvement over MTP for enhancing NTP in language models, offering better performance with reduced architectural overhead. The authors provide open-source code for reproduction.
